DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 November, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Connolly had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House
(1) expresses its disapproval of the Government's failure to change the direction of its social welfare policies to meet the needs of the Australian community;
(2) condemns the Government for its failure to create a level playing field for various classes of annuities and pensions;
(3) expresses its strong concern at the wide-ranging cutbacks and complex changes imposed by the Government on veterans and war widows since May 1989;
(4) reiterates its support for the Veterans' Children's Education Scheme as being a scheme of compensation and as such falling in a separate category to the general Austudy scheme; and
(5) expresses its concern at delays and inconsistencies in the determining system leading to wide-ranging variations in determinations, particularly by the Veterans' Review Board'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some remarks about the long process of reform which has now been brought to a head in the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989. I congratulate in particular the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on the way he has gone about integrating the social security system and the system of training people to get them back into employment. It seems that some of the new ideas offered under the Opposition's so-called Economic Action Plan do not even attempt to build on the good work that has been done. In fact, they tend to reverse the ship of state, leaving people with hardly any choices whatsoever-there is only the damning choice of either getting out and working or being thrown onto special benefits, for instance.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the dole bludger mentality is back in Australia. I thought that way back in 1982-83 we had killed that sort of awful characterisation of people who have been unable to get employment in this country. Honourable members will remember that at that time there were about 700,000 unemployed people in Australia. The only way that the Liberal-National coalition could handle the anguish of that many people was to blame them for not being able to get a job. We overcame that. We calmed things down, we told those people that it was not their fault that they could not get a job and we went about creating jobs.

However, there is always a lag effect. No matter how many jobs we created, there was always the very real situation that some people, often older men and women, could not get back into the work force because they no longer possessed the skills and, in some cases, the will to get out there and work. That did not make them bludgers. They were people who were right for programs to get them back into the work force. Those are the sorts of programs that the Government has been building on and improving over six years. Those programs would be destroyed under a Liberal-National coalition.

The statistics show that the number of people on the unemployment benefit has dropped consistently since the March quarter of 1984. From that time until November this year the number of unemployment beneficiaries has dropped consistently. We have not cooked the books. We have not said that after nine months people will have to go off the unemployment benefit and cop some other sort of benefit, like special benefits, if they are poor enough or go to blazes and get no support from the people of Australia. We would never take that attitude. We have recognised two things. First, jobs must be available so that people can be taken from the very considerable disadvantage of being on the unemployment benefit and put back into the work force. Secondly, if people are finding it difficult to gear themselves up to get back into the work force, a program must be provided.

One program that has been extremely successful for some months now is the Newstart program. Newstart assists in getting the long term unemployed back to work. The people on the Newstart program are not your young beach bums. They are not kids with blonded hair and bronzed physiques who sit down on the beach. They are 55-year-old men and women who are at the end of their tether. They are extremely poor. In some circumstances they are without hope and they need considerable assistance and a gee up to get them back into the work force. The Newstart program does this.

I want to report on some figures from my area of Redcliffe which show the marvellous success that this Government's Newstart program is having. The Department of Social Security (DSS) and the Commonwealth Employment Services (CES) jointly interview people to find out not only how they are coping, why they lost their employment and what they have been doing in the intervening period but also how best they can be put into some form of training to get them back out to work. It might seem as though this has been a long time coming. There have been other programs. These people have been under scrutiny, if you like, by the CES, to ensure that they continue to try for a job.

It is not as though there have not been all sorts of programs in place to get people back into the work force. But the programs have not always worked. We are talking about people who have been out of work for a considerable period of time and who need assistance to get back into the work force. We have found that, through the Newstart program, about half of a select group of 120 people in the Redcliffe area have been able to return to work. This has been due to a new intensive approach of interviewing people, talking to people, giving them some new skills and telling them again how to find a job. Many people in this category have lost their skills. Anyone who is out of work for a considerable time feels deflated. The pressures of having to pay off the mortgage, pay rent or bring up children must be awful.

Let us remember that being unemployed is no joy ride. I am not talking about people with lots of dough sitting out the back having fun and drinking tinnies. These people do not have money. A lot of them do not have much hope. We are not using, as morally we must not and should not, a great big stick. We are not saying that we will throw people off the unemployment benefit after nine months and that they can go down to the DSS which can provide a special benefit if it thinks they are poor enough. We put enormous pressure on people and encourage them to get back the life that they have lost. We are providing the opportunity for people to get back into employment, to make friends again in the workplace, to bring money into the house and to derive a sense of ownership which one loses when one becomes unemployed.

The Opposition's punitive attitude annoys me. I cannot believe that, after six years of watching us being so successful in getting the unemployment figures down, honourable members opposite all of a sudden think that the problem can be solved by using a big stick. That is not so. We have been at this game for a long time. We have done a marvellous job in getting those figures down. Schemes like Newstart are really meant to cap off our efforts. They are dealing with the last and most difficult cases in order to get those people back to work.

There is no doubt that the Newstart program has ferreted out some people who are not interested in going to an interview. I am not quite sure of all the reasons. Perhaps some people have not been fair dinkum in looking for a job. There are others, I suspect, who prefer just to exit quietly. Some people who are perhaps near to retirement age or who are to let an older partner look after them cannot face any further interviewing, training and whatever. Let us consider those sorts of people. It might be true to say that some of these people who do not make the jump from the DSS office to the CES for this intensive program might simply walk right out of the system. They do so at no cost to the Government. But what is the cost to them? The critical point is that we are not forcing them off the dole. We encourage them into work, and that is an enormous, fundamental and important difference-and I want to stress that.

The manager at the Redcliffe CES office is operating a unique scheme which involves discussions with the 120 people that I have referred to and it has been possible to get half of them back to work. The next target relates to the older people, those over 55, who have been unable to get into the work force. A pilot scheme is about to commence in my electorate. The Government is awarding $60,000 to a local group. We do not know which group it will be but, for instance, it could be the local Skillshare group, which is a community based training organisation.

A Newstart-type process will be used in respect of the older unemployed. These people will be taken aside and talked to about what it takes to get them back into the work force. This does not involve punishing someone who is perceived to be some sort of joyrider by arbitrarily throwing him off the unemployment benefit after nine months and telling him to get special benefits. That is like saying, `You have failed: not only can you not get yourself a job but you will receive the meanest payment in the whole system-special benefit. It is the lowest benefit, the last stop; you cannot go any further'. The rules that apply to special benefit are fairly tough and one must really go begging, in a sense, to a departmental officer and say, `I am destitute and I need some benefit'. That is what special benefit is. Thank goodness we have it in this country, but it is a last calling post. That is not the sort of approach to use to encourage people back into the work force.

I do not care how many long term unemployed the 60 Minutes program or Mr Carlton interviews to indicate that there are bludgers out there because, when Mr Carlton finds one person who should be in the work force, there are another 100 who are working. I have stood in front of perhaps 500 young people at Skillshare programs-young people who have tried courageously to get into the work force. They use a Government community program like Skillshare, pick up some new skills and then go back out into the community. I am not sure that I would have the guts to do all the work those people do to try to get back into the work force. I am not sure that I could cope with that, yet we expect so much of these people who are often less qualified than we are here and often less capable in some ways. We expect more of them than we do of ourselves, yet the Opposition wants to be punitive; it wants to punish them further. Enough of that.

I will close on the point that Newstart and similar programs are designed to take people off benefits and get them back into the work force. Programs of this sort are not our first in this area, and they will probably not be the last. We try to establish programs that are sensitive to the needs of those who are unemployed. We listen to the unemployed and we react, and we get them into the work force. We have done that successfully for six years. I congratulate the Minister and his Department for their good work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill gives us the opportunity to have quite a wide-ranging debate on matters relating to social security. I would like to deal with a number of topics, and I will probably be able to deal with some of them only briefly because of the time limitation on this debate. The first matter that I wish to raise relates to the purchasing power of pensions that we provide to those who qualify for a pension or benefit of one kind or another. There is and has been bipartisan support for the proper adjustment of pensions as circumstances in our economy change. There has been and continues to be bipartisan support for the twice-yearly indexation of pensions and adjustment in accordance with the movement of the consumer price index (CPI). There has also been bipartisan use of the comparison between the present pension and another measure, namely, average weekly earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation points to the proposal that pensions should be fixed at a level whereby they are not less than 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. I support that, as do my colleagues, but, if we have regular half-yearly adjustments in accordance with the CPI, there are two matters that need to be drawn to attention. Firstly, there is the timing of the adjustment, and that needs to be examined from time to time to ensure that pensioners are not disadvantaged by time-lags in the movement in pension rates in accordance with some prior adjustment in the CPI. Secondly, there needs to be a regular review of the comparison of the pension and benefit rates with average weekly earnings, because the two indexes do not move in step and at the same rate.

There have been times in our economy when, because there has been substantial wage restraint, the CPI has moved faster than average weekly earnings. Indeed, the Government's claim that it has lifted the level of the pension closer and closer until eventually it has reached 25 per cent of average weekly earnings has been significantly achieved because of wage restraint and a higher movement in the CPI rather than as a result of any particular generosity on the part of the Government in relation to pensioners. On the other hand, there are times when the economy moves in a different direction, when average weekly earnings move more quickly than does the CPI. In that event, if this Parliament has a bipartisan commitment to CPI adjustments and a pension of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, there needs to be an ad hoc adjustment, or perhaps in the future this Parliament will determine that there should be a regular review to make an adjustment of the average weekly earnings for a catch-up in the event that the CPI adjustment falls behind the average weekly earnings benchmark.

Other areas of the pension system have been indexed, too, and that is a good thing. The assets test limits were indexed from the outset after a fairly rigorous debate about whether or not there should be an assets test. I have strong views about that, but that is for another day. The other adjustment that is made in this legislation is to index the free area. That is an interesting adjustment because it also relates to the proposal ultimately to exempt pensioners from tax altogether, in the first instance exempting the income test free area. The Government has made a lot of that and has said that pensioners will be free from tax, but it has not spelt out very much detail. We do not know how the system will operate, but I assume that the model that will be used will be that currently being used and that it will be done by the grant of an aged persons rebate. That is fine. All women of 60 years and over and all men of 65 years and over will become entitled to this rebate and will receive a tax exemption.

It must be pointed out to the aged population and to the community at large that this will do two things. It will give a very much higher tax free threshold to one section of the community without giving it to other sections. Personally, I believe that the tax free threshold should be substantially higher than it is today. That can be achieved in a couple of ways. One is, at very great cost, by leaving the current rate structure in place. The other way is to raise the threshold for people who have a very low income but then have the ingoing marginal tax rate somewhat higher than it is at present-perhaps 30c instead of the 21c or 25c that it has been. One could then achieve a situation where there is clear water between the pension level and where tax impacts over a range that is equal to the income test free area now to be indexed-I think $50 a week for a single pensioner.

Personally, I believe that the tax threshold should be lifted for all up to that tax free area because it then means that the universal marginal tax rate can be maintained for people just above that threshold, whether it is the age threshold or the general threshold, both of which, in my view, should be the same. If it is done in the way that the aged rebate has been implemented in the past, it is a wasting rebate, a disappearing rebate. Once the tax free threshold is reached, tax is paid at the marginal rate set by the tax structure as applicable to the population in general, and then there is an abatement of the rebate. The rebate is withdrawn by a certain number of cents in the dollar-say 12 1/2c in the dollar-and that marginal rate is added on top of the general marginal tax rate.

So there is then a very high effective marginal tax rate imposed on people as they move from the artificially created tax-free area. That situation has some grave disadvantages. One disadvantage is that those on low incomes who are not aged are paying tax on very low incomes. There is also the disadvantage that those who are aged when their income reaches the threshold are suddenly confronted with a very high marginal tax rate. It can be moderately high or very high. That judgment is made from time to time as to whether one wants to claw back very quickly the tax otherwise paid or whether that should be done more gradually. In either event, it has some effect on incentives. It may be argued that for the retired population it will not have an effect on the incentive for their work force participation, but it will have an effect on their investment and savings strategies. In my view that is undesirable.

This legislation is also interesting because it starts to look at providing common definitions in the social security legislation as are applicable in the tax legislation. I wish the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) had adopted that approach generally. I am pleased that he has now introduced a precedent, and I hope that in time we can look at income for tax and social security purposes and say that the definition will be the same under both regimes.

It may be that we would then want to have some exceptions, but let those exceptions be clear, explicit and justified by sound and good reasons. There is really no justification for many of the different definitions applying now in the legislation, except to say that something has been done for a long time in one area and some different definition has been used for a long time in another area. Most age pensioners were once taxpayers. They therefore have come to understand the definitions in the tax system, so when they reach the age of retirement they should be able to simply lift those definitions into the social security system, and have a clear understanding of their rights and entitlements and how they determine their eligibility under the income test.

The other matter I want to raise relates in one sense to a very special aspect of this proposal-the home equity conversion. It is really designed to tidy up some ineffective or doubtful definitions in the legislation so that people can borrow against their house without then being penalised under either the assets or income tests. That is good and is a pointer to the way in which we should go. However, I want to look at the broader concerns that we must have in the changed environment that has occurred.

A de facto compulsory savings scheme is being put into place in Australia today. It has come about because of the 3 per cent superannuation arrangements. As a consequence of the implementation of that arrangement and the possible increase from 3 per cent to 6 per cent, young people, middle aged people and older people are forced to save through industrial deals which are done and which are quite sensible in many respects. People are taking superannuation entitlements in lieu of pay packet cash payment. That is having a massive effect on tax revenue. It would be interesting to assess the effect on government interest in respect of the loss of revenue as a consequence of people saving through this compulsory superannuation scheme.

The point I want to make is that I believe that people should have the right to opt out of the compulsory channelling of those superannuation savings into superannuation funds and life insurance companies, and be enabled to use their savings to put a deposit on their house, extend their house, buy their house, or even undertake a business, subject to one proviso-that they will not come back onto the social security system, to the extent that they have taken their resources out of those secured, prudentially controlled superannuation funds.

I am personally convinced that, just as this home equity conversion arrangement requires mortgages, it would be possible to introduce a scheme whereby those who wanted to do so could take out their resources to buy their first home for their family and young children, embark on a business enterprise or use them for some other purpose. This would help us to get our balance of payments into better order and it could be allowed, provided those people delivered to the Government a performance bond by an approved financial institution. The arrangements that institution then has with the individual and the cost of granting that performance bond could be a matter between the institution and the individual. People could then make their own free choice judgment whether they wanted to take that action.

I would have liked to talk on one other matter in relation particularly to overseas pensioners in Australia, but time is very limited and I will save those remarks for another day. I ask the Government to take into account the views I have expressed on the topics about which I have had the opportunity to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes I have available, I want to address a few points raised last night in this debate by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), the Opposition spokesperson on veterans' affairs. The honourable member for Farrer last night did as he always does when he speaks on veterans' affairs matters and raised the old nine points-which used to be 10 points-about the dreadful things which this Government is supposed to have done to veterans. Of course, he had not one word of commendation or credit for this Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, which will be of inestimable benefit to the veterans of this country, particularly in relation to their income over the next few years.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Farrer quoted from a letter that the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) had written to one of his constituents. I have a letter written by the honourable member for Farrer to a veterans' organisation in South Australia. It is a form letter, with a photocopied signature, that he presumably sent to veterans' organisations right around the country. What does the shadow spokesperson on veterans' affairs have to say to ex-service organisations around Australia? Does he tell them about the Opposition's policy on retirement incomes or anything else to do with the Opposition's veterans' affairs policies? He does not. He states:
Dear Office Bearer

This is to advise that today in the Federal Parliament, the Coalition moved to bring on the Crimes (Protection of the Australian Flag) Amendment Bill; an important amendment to prevent burning the flag at demonstrations and the like.
You might like to know that the Government, including marginal Members from narrowly held Labor seats, voted four times against debating and considering the Bill.

I am not sure what the reference to `marginal members from narrowly held Labor seats' has to do with the matter. And so his letter goes on. I have nothing against the Crimes (Protection of the Australian Flag) Amendment Bill, and I am sure that most of my colleagues have nothing against it. Probably most veterans have nothing against it either, and think it is quite a good idea, but it is not exactly a burning issue. To coin a phrase, I have 20,000 veterans in my electorate, and they are not beating a path to my door demanding that the Government bring on this flag Bill for debate.

What they have been demanding is that the Government do something about the retirement income system, the service pension system, which affects them so much. I am sure that if the veterans were asked which of the two Bills they would have preferred to be brought on for debate this session-the Crimes (Protection of the Australian Flag) Amendment Bill or the Bill before us, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, which largely concerns the retirement incomes system, which is of vital importance to the future welfare and financial security of the veterans of this country-they would have chosen the latter Bill which they would consider as most important for their welfare and future. As I have said, we have nothing against the flag Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, why don't you pass it?
—Order!

—Because we are short of time this session. I think, and I am sure most veterans think, that the Bill before the House dealing with their future financial security is of greater importance than the flag Bill.
—Well, we will give you the flag Bill next week.
—That has nothing to do with me.
—Order! The honourable member for Hume will cease interjecting.

—I would simply like to say that this Bill, and particularly the retirement incomes aspect of it, is a revolutionary measure in this country in the approach to retirement income policy. As a former member of the retirement incomes task force I would like to say, as the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) said last night, how proud I am to have been so closely associated with the production of this policy and this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989. This Bill proposes to amend the Customs Tariff Act 1987 through a series of amendments contained in nine schedules to the Bill. On the whole, the Bill reflects a housekeeping of the tariff in that a deal of its amendments relate to correcting anomalies that have been created through changes to the harmonised tariff system. It also implements changes recommended by the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority and fulfils our obligations in relation to the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement (ANZCERTA).

SPEECH.PARA: The significant changes in this Bill relate to the Government's decisions on the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report into the mining, construction and agricultural equipment industries. Schedule 1 of the Bill amends schedule 4 to insert a new subheading to allow for the continued duty free importation of ethyl hexanol. Ethyl hexanol was incorrectly classified when the Government's decision on the chemicals and plastics industries was being implemented. The second schedule to this Bill, which has effect from 1 January 1988, allows for a duty free rate on rye grass seed. Also, gasoline and other oils, under subheading 2710.00.59 of the tariff, are to gain a duty free rate through the removal of a 2 per cent revenue duty.

To ensure alignment with the harmonised system schedule under Customs Cooperation Council requirement, schedule 3 proposes a descriptive change. Operative from 1 March 1989 are amendments contained in schedule 4. These amendments implement unrestricted duty free access for footwear of New Zealand origin under ANZCERTA and also provide duty free importation of certain New Zealand fabrics. This schedule also seeks to remove quota restrictions and impose a duty rate of 15 per cent for metal parts of footwear under subheadings 6406.10.00 and 6406.99.90. Prior to 1 March 1989 metal parts of footwear were quota free and dutiable at 20 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't know that.

—I think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs should pay a great deal of attention to what I am saying because he will learn a great deal from this Customs Tariff Act. Following the November 1986 decision, these goods were lumped in with other footwear parts, which meant they were subject to a quota attracting a base rate of 40 per cent. Not unexpectedly, metal parts importers, retailers and footwear manufacturers who noted that these goods did not form part of the IAC inquiry which led to the November 1986 decision objected to the consequent increased production costs. So the duty reverts, with a 5 per cent discounting to take account of the May 1988 economic statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Certain protective garments, such as those used by firefighting bodies or by persons involved with harmful chemicals, are also to have quota restrictions removed and a 15 per cent duty imposed. Prior to 1986 these types of items were subject to a tariff classification order and as such were imported at minimum rates. However, in 1986 the Australian Customs Service changed their classification, which resulted in those suits without breathing apparatus being entered under quota and subject to a base rate of 55 per cent. The out of quota rate is 120 per cent. This change made the suits very expensive for the local authorities and so on which used them and, of course, meant a substantial increase in the amount of protection afforded Australian producers. Schedule 4 affords similar treatment to these suits as to the metal parts of footwear. Schedule 4 also removes tariff rates applicable to tender extension provisions for goods from New Zealand, as is required under Australia's ANZCERTA obligations.

The next schedule, schedule 5, which covers amendments to schedules 1,3,4, and 5 of the Act, also looks to Australia's obligations under ANZCERTA and proposes the removal of both tariff duty and quota restriction on apparel from New Zealand. Under the current situation, both Australia and New Zealand have made available to each other about $A20m in access to apparel exports. This amendment accelerates by a year the move toward free trade in apparel on a reciprocal basis.

Following quite a deal of discussion in relation to the importation of soda ash, changes have been made, as the Government undertook to do during the debate on the customs and excise legislation amendment Bills earlier this year. Under this amendment the added protection afforded soda ash due to changes in customs valuation legislation has been adjusted. Briefly, the situation here is that when the Government announced that it intended tightening the `Customs Act to combat fraud and avoidance of import duty' the Minister stated that in the exceptional cases where the new valuation arrangements significantly raised protective levels he would consider requests for review by the IAC.

The 1989 amendments provided that the value of imports for duty calculations include all foreign inland freight and foreign inland insurance. With soda ash this meant an increase in the dollar value for duty assessed as these imports were valued on an ex-mine basis. It has been estimated that the increase in the dollar value of import duty was around 40 per cent. The IAC inquired into this and this amendment is now in place. This amendment reduces the phasing rates already applying from 17.5 per cent to a proposed top of 15 per cent to 7.5 per cent from 1 January 1992.

Other significant changes in this particular schedule relate to the Government's decision following the IAC report No. 413 into mining, construction and agricultural equipment industries. Many of the pieces of equipment and parts covered by the report are not made in Australia during the normal course of business. Among the changes in rates proposed by the Bill are that engines, NSA, having a power not exceeding 3.6 kilowatts-8407.32.20-have a reduced rate of 15 per cent from 21 per cent; pumps of 8413.30.12 are reduced from 21 per cent to free; mobile lifting frames on tyres and straddle carriers of 8426.12.00 and goods under 8426.1 are reduced from 27 per cent to 21 per cent; and mechanical shovels having a shovel capacity exceeding 5 cubic metres are moving from 18 per cent duty to free.

In order that other speakers can participate in this debate, I would like to place on the record my support for all of those speakers who have condemned the way the Government has been running the business of this House. The guillotine was imposed on us yesterday. It is also being imposed today and it will be used again tomorrow. This is an outrageous indictment of the Government's inability to manage what goes on in this chamber. It shows, if it needs to be shown any further, how tired, how arrogant and how out of touch the Government is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the honourable member for Deakin realises that this is not a procedural debate at this stage. Debate is confined to a customs tariff amendment Bill. I am sure he will confine his remarks to that.
—Because of the Government's mismanagement I am precluded from going through the various other changes that the Government proposes to make.
—Where is the honourable member for Ryan?

—The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) is winning an election for us in Queensland and he is making sure that those opposite lose it. The Minister has said that these other changes provide `a boost to Australia's main export industries'. If there is one thing that Australia needs, it is an increase in its exports. This Government's gross mismanagement of the economy, which has led to an absolutely appalling situation with our balance of payments and a blow-out in our overseas debt, has provided a situation--
—Who wrecked the industry?

—It will cost my friend his seat. The Government's mismanagement of the Australian economy-what it has failed to do with inflation, what it has failed to do with the balance of payments and what it has failed to do in containing overseas debt-will cost the honourable member his seat.
—Promise?
—Yes, I promise that it will cost him his seat.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments contained in schedule 6 are to have effect from 1 August 1989. These amendments cover certain fabric woven from polyvinyl chloride (PVC) coated polyester and woven cut corduroy, and provide quota free and duty free access for certain ski boots and certain cross country ski footwear. In 1987 the Government decided upon duty free treatment for woven cut corduroy which is not produced in Australia. However, this fabric was, to use the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority's words, `inadvertently excluded' from implementation of the decision and as a consequence became dutiable at a rate phasing to 35 per cent. Under these amendments it will be duty free, as will PVC coated polyester, which from 1 January 1988 jumped from minimum levels to 25 per cent-a rate which did not reflect the Government's textile, clothing and footwear policy intentions. The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) will need a PVC coated polyester covering to protect himself from the fire of his electors, who will boot him out.

Yet another correction is contained in this Bill's schedule 7, which reinstates pre-January 1988 levels of protection on cast coated paper and paperboard. In regard to refunds, the Minister in his press release of 12 October 1989 said:

This change will be effective from today but duty will still be payable on entries of these goods until seven days after assent to the amending legislation, after which refunds will be available on application to Customs.

Schedule 8 amendments again reflect a broad sweep of subjects. Under the schedule, Hungary and Poland are added to the list of countries, contained in schedule 1, to which Australia affords preferential treatment. This addition means a loss of Customs revenue of an estimated $1.7m.

The Bill also cancels a couple of redundant items, fixes up some tariff anomalies identified by industry, which have been in place since the harmonised tariff was introduced and, in most cases, adjusts them to the levels which were in force prior to January 1988. The schedule also seeks to insert new items into part 3 of schedule 4 of the Customs Act of 1987, thus allowing duty free entry for specified parts and accessories for use in the manufacture or assembly of machines for working metal and duty free entry of specified parts of machines incorporating a computer controller. The coalition parties do not object to the passage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) is another omnibus Bill; it makes a whole range of changes, legislative alterations, many of which are fairly minor in nature. As such, I do not intend to try to cover everything that is encompassed in the Bill. I would like to focus on schedule 8 of the Bill, which in effect adds Poland and Hungary to the list of countries which qualify for preferential treatment under the Australian system of tariff preference. The purpose of referring to that section is that it provides an opportunity to make some comment on developments in eastern Europe and what their implications might be for the rest of the world, including Australia, and, more importantly, how the Western world ought to respond to those developments.

SPEECH.PARA: As is pointed out in the second reading speech on the Bill, this measure is designed to lend support to the process of democratic reform taking place in those countries. I think it would be true to say that the extent and pace of developments there have surprised everybody. Nobody anticipated that within the space of a year we would be looking at a situation where a non-communist Prime Minister could emerge in Poland and where the prospect of free elections is now firmly scheduled in Hungary. More recently in East Germany we have seen, in effect, the fall of an old line regime which seemed for a considerable period to be impregnable. It is interesting that Bulgaria has joined the ranks of those countries which are undertaking change. The Czechoslovak regime and the Romanians are very much out on their own. There was talk earlier of the Czechs hoping to forge a Prague-East Berlin axis but, unfortunately from their point of view, that possibility seems to have faltered.

What has brought about the possibility of these developments is the change which has taken place in the Soviet Union, with the reform program implemented by President Gorbachev. I recall that in the early period of Gorbachev's rule there was widespread scepticism as to the real implications of those changes. Were they merely cosmetic changes designed to buy a bit of time so that the whole authoritarian state apparatus in that country and the system which it represents could be perpetuated for a further period? There was quite a debate in Western circles about what the actual meaning of these changes was.

There is really no doubt about it any more. In the last couple of weeks an issue of Time magazine had a front cover affirming that this is for real, that major and fundamental change is taking place. However, there are some very distinct problems. It seems that those countries undergoing a transition to a more democratic system of politics and economics need to go through a difficult period of transition in which, for a time, material living standards may actually worsen. We have seen that situation develop in the Soviet Union, where stocks of goods in the shops have been cleaned out as a result of increases in money wages which have been forced on the government because the work force is now actually able to mobilise, organise, take strike action and so forth.

That increase in money incomes has resulted in an absolute clean-out of supplies of consumer goods in the shops. That is a major problem. It seems that unless Gorbachev can put substantial amounts of consumer goods on the shelves in the Soviet Union in the coming period, particularly over this coming winter, politically he will be in real difficulty.

In order to bring about fundamental change in the economy of the Soviet Union and to improve living standards, certainly in the short term but also in the long term, a necessary condition is that there be a major cut in military expenditure. That goes to the whole question of the way the West responds to these things. There is a reciprocal requirement between the United States and the Soviet Union. The United States has its chronic problem of a large public sector deficit which has proved very difficult to deal with. One way of tackling that, obviously, would be to cut into the military budget. The Soviet Union must reallocate economic resources from the military-industrial complex to consumer goods production if the Government is to have any prospect of success in carrying through its reform program. Therefore, the question of whether the West seeks to assist to reduce East-West tensions and to provide economic assistance to facilitate that process of change is crucial. This legislation in a very small way adds Australia to the list of those countries which are aiming, in a positive sense, to facilitate that process. As such, this measure is to be applauded.

Another way of looking at this set of developments is to ask what is the more cost-effective way of ensuring the security of a state like Australia or other Western countries. Is it to continue the massive arms build-up that took place during the 1980s, with very large real increases in military expenditures, which we have seen in Australia as well as in a variety of other countries? We have had very substantial real increases in defence expenditures over the last few years. Is it better to do it that way, to try to guarantee one's security by the so-called peace through strength doctrine, or is it more cost-effective to expend some economic resources in accelerating the process of benign change in the Eastern blocs so that the whole question of threat is significantly diminished and the prospect of large scale multilateral disarmament becomes real? My view is that Australia is overspending on defence. On forward estimates it looks like we will continue to see large real increases in defence expenditure. Those expenditures are at the cost of other things that the Government could be doing, in areas that the Government could be spending on, not only in the area of social provision but also facilitating the process of structural change in the Australian economy. So I take the view that this change in international circumstances offers us an opportunity to rein in what has been a substantial rate of growth of defence expenditure. I would hope to see that occur.

It is worth noting that within the United States and in the West generally there has been quite a debate about how to deal with these developments in Eastern Europe. There is a hard line school of thought, reputedly associated with the present Defense Secretary, the Deputy National Security Director and various others in the Administration, including the Vice President, as I understand it, which says that the West really has no business in actively seeking to facilitate and improve the prospects of change in the Soviet bloc. I think that is a very short-sighted view, for the reasons I have outlined. I certainly hope that that point of view within the US Administration does not prevail.

There is another view, which, I am pleased to say, seems to be being taken up to some degree by the present Secretary of State, which says that facilitating and assisting this process is very much in the interests of all concerned, not only those countries which receive the assistance but also those countries which are presently members of the Western alliance. Hopefully, all this will lead ultimately to the break-up of this whole system of alliances and a totally different world order. I think that is the sort of thing President Gorbachev envisages. It is in all of our interests that that sort of change take place.

I thought I would make those observations which relate in a direct sense to schedule 8 of this Bill. It is unusual to talk about such a broad subject on such a narrowly focused Bill with a whole string of essentially machinery amendments but I have been looking for an opportunity to make a few comments on those developments and what their implications might be for Australia for some time, so I welcome having had that opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4), which we are considering this morning, covers a number of changes to customs and excise legislation. I will concentrate on two of these changes and the issues which they raise, but if time permits I will go on to refer to the quite significant changes to the tariffs for mining and agricultural equipment. The changes I will focus on are of interest because they illustrate a point often forgotten by those interested in foreign affairs-that in the relations between different countries and the people of those countries contact of a commercial kind predominates over formal diplomatic, cultural and other interaction. There is no better example of the importance of commerce in international relations than in the way that Western countries are attempting to help those seeking to abandon communism in eastern Europe by freeing access to Western markets for those countries which appear to be making genuine efforts to reform their systems of government. Part of this legislation represents Australia's contribution to this process.

SPEECH.PARA: Another issue I will discuss is the closer economic relations (CER) agreement with New Zealand, which has led to amendments contained in this legislation to the tariff regime for textiles, clothing and footwear trade between the two countries, which is of interest also. It is arguably counterproductive that protection in Australia is so high that there can be a significant benefit to any country by listing as a favoured country under the Australian system of tariff preferences. However, given that the benefit exists, it is highly desirable to extend those benefits as far as possible. It is particularly desirable to be able to use those benefits to assist eastern European countries which are struggling to throw off the bitter yoke of 44 years of communist rule which they have endured since the end of the Second World War.

The two countries which this Bill proposes to grant preference to are Hungary and Poland. Both are countries which have suffered greatly in recent history. Poland was devastated by the war and this destruction was compounded by the oppression of Soviet occupation after the war. The people of Poland have suffered because of oppression, which has been a feature of all communist regimes, and from the inability of centralised command economies to deliver the prosperity and the most essential of services. This is perhaps a debatable point, but there is a lesson to be learned in Australia from the failure of centralised government. Although our political system is different, although we are by no means a totalitarian state of the kind to which I have referred, centralised economies and centralised government is also a factor in the momentous changes taking place in eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

In the early 1980s, Solidarity-in some respects a trade union-with the broad support of the church, academics and other Poles, conducted a series of strikes about living standards, the supply of food and lack of political freedom. This eventually resulted in the declaration of martial law and the banning of Solidarity. Over the past two years the economic position in Poland deteriorated further, causing a strong increase in support for opponents of the Government and a crisis in the communist Government itself. Negotiations with Solidarity followed, leading to elections, the overwhelming rejection of the communist Government by the people of Poland, and eventually a government dominated by Solidarity members but continuing to have members of the former regime in significant positions.

Poland has not yet had fully democratic elections, and it is well to remind ourselves of that. The Communist Party still dominates positions of power within the military, the judiciary, and government departments. However, if the present Solidarity-led Government fails, there will be little prospect for free elections and for genuine economic and political freedom in Poland in the long term. The survival of the present Government in Poland, at least in part, depends on the progress it achieves in economic reform.

To aid these developments, Western countries are offering direct and indirect aid to the Government of Poland. The French Government recently announced $820m in economic aid to Poland. The measures proposed in this Bill amount to a concession of $1m on imports from Poland, worth about $31m in the past year. However, the monetary benefit to Poland will not be as great as the benefit of increased trade and increased economic contact with the non-communist world. The Bill also proposes concessions to Hungary which will cost $0.7m in revenue on total imports worth about $28m. Hungary is yet to hold open elections. However, the ruling party has renounced much of its past and only a couple of weeks ago implemented a new Constitution which guaranteed certain individual rights and established a framework for democracy in that country in the future. It has opened up its borders to free travel, leading to the recent exodus of Germans from East Germany. Leaders of the ruling party in Hungary have claimed that capitalism is the highest economic achievement of mankind.

These changes in eastern Europe should be encouraged. I believe that the measures contained in this Bill are likely to meet with the wide support of Australians. The promise of the changes taking place in Poland, Hungary and, to a lesser but increasing extent, the other nations of eastern Europe is yet to be fulfilled. Change should be encouraged and helped, but there is a danger in assuming that it has already occurred, a danger made all the more acute by the tragic repression of those seeking liberty in China. Measures such as those contained in this Bill show appropriate caution.

The closer economic relations agreement between Australia and New Zealand, to which I now wish to turn, was developed under the most recent coalition Government and has been taken further in recent years. It allows for the gradual creation of something like a free trade zone including Australia and New Zealand. It is a bilateral agreement which has already created considerable benefits for both countries. It is a good example of the potential benefits of free trade throughout the world. Although companies in both countries compete strongly and a number of trans-Tasman takeovers have occurred, as we all know, it has simply not been the case that one country has come to dominate the other. Despite the conflict between Australia and New Zealand over ANZUS, the closer economic relations agreement has remained firmly intact and is being strengthened. Free trade has been a strong force for peace and international cooperation and I believe will continue to be so for as long as we allow it to happen into the future.

Schedule 4 to this Bill contains provisions which speed up the liberalisation of trade in textiles, clothing and footwear between Australia and New Zealand under the CER agreement. The textiles, clothing and footwear industries are the most heavily protected of all Australian industries. This Bill will see the environment of largely free trade in these goods across the Tasman achieved one year earlier than we had expected. That is a desirable result in an industry which in the past has been inefficient, uncompetitive, and, particularly for those who do not work in the industry, a burden on other Australians.

The establishment of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Authority was a backward step on the very slow path which this Government has followed towards overall reductions in protection, which I acknowledge. It has reduced the role of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) in the scrutiny of protection of the TCF industries. It was accompanied by initial increases in tariff protection to offset the elimination of what had been particularly onerous quota protection. The problems with such protection are not just the particular benefits conferred on some interest groups consisting of both industry and trade unions; the costs imposed on consumers by this protection are high and particularly obvious in the area of textiles, clothing and footwear. People are well aware of the lower prices of clothing in most countries in our region. The costs of protection fall most heavily on those who can least afford it. Efforts in this legislation which recognise that no industry can be exempted from a general need to reduce protection and a `practise what we preach' approach in the realm of free trade are highly desirable. I believe that the benefits to Australians and New Zealanders from closer economic relations represent a model for the future reductions of protection across the board.

This package of customs legislation is unusual in its largely sensible and generally non-protectionist implementation of agreements with other countries and its implementation of the recommendations of the IAC. The final concern which I raise today is about the future of the IAC under the new Industry Commission. In recent years, the IAC has had to face upheaval and changes which have reduced its effectiveness as a protector of the general interest, rather than vested interests, in industries assistance matters. The IAC has been hamstrung by the present Government in the recent past, in part because it proved a damning critic, when necessary, of the Government's industry plans and policies. The acceptance of the independent and critical role of the IAC, or its successor, by all governments is a challenge which this Government has not yet had the courage to face up to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 and other Bills which will come before the House today are a continuance of the Government's major micro-economic reforms in this country. It is quite interesting to compare the Government's stance on the removal of protection and the opening up of Australia's markets to international competition with the stance of the Opposition. I listened with interest this morning to the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), who gave a long-winded speech but said nothing and did not reveal or discuss at any stage the Opposition's attitude to this major micro-economic reform. If we read the much vaunted Economic Action Plan, as it is called, of the Opposition, we will hunt in vain for any discussion in that document on the Opposition's attitude to major macro-economic or micro-economic change in industry areas.
—No different from the previous Government.

—The Minister is right; it is no different. Members of the Opposition do not want to talk about where they stand on tariffs or protection. They do not want to talk about what they would do; yet, without that kind of discussion, without a rational argument or a rational base that they can put forward on their tariff and protection position, they do not have an economic policy. That is one of the great nonsenses being run around Australia today about the Opposition's so-called Economic Action Plan: it is not; it is a shallow and hollow document which fails to address the most pressing fundamental economic questions facing Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is quite simple: the Opposition created the protected market that Australia now faces. The Opposition created a centrally managed economy-the very sort of economy for which the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who spoke before me, criticised the communist countries of Europe. Members of the Opposition stand here today and say, `We know that centralised economies do not work. We know that managed economies do not work'. Yet they were the very people who set forth tariff protection and destroyed Australia's manufacturing industries in the process. So it is always amusing for people on my side of politics to sit in this place and listen to honourable members opposite, who still will not give any indication of where they stand as a party-either the Liberal Party or the National Party-on removing barriers to international competition and free enterprise and trade.

I note that the shadow spokesperson on treasury or finance matters, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), has refused to be drawn into a debate of this kind at all. I find that a great tragedy. There is no doubt whatsoever that a country with 16 1/2 million-pushing 17 million-people is not in a position today to create industry or enterprise in many areas of production which are cost effective or technologically competent to compete with other major producing countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventeen, to be fair.

—The Minister says 17 million people. I will accept that. Australia is not in a position now, and will not be in a position in the future, to build video cassette recorders, television sets and much of the high-tech computer gear through to the smaller component areas because we do not have a large enough market to induce the massive investment required of investors going into those production areas. That means that we are ever more reliant upon importing into this country that new technology through computers and other electronic equipment. This country will probably never be in a position to conduct extremely heavy engineering or to produce heavy engineering equipment on a cost effective or competitive basis with overseas suppliers. Frankly, our market is too small; therefore, we need to enable imports into this country of the equipment that our industries need and, as honourable members on this side of the House keep saying, we need to look for industries which will on-cost the natural resources and the things that we produce so well in this country to maximise our profit.

SPEECH.PARA: An interesting debate is occurring now in Australia on what degree of government intervention should occur in the marketplace through tariffs and other industry controls as opposed to whether there should be no government intervention in the marketplace at all. I must confess that I find myself somewhere in the middle. I take the view that those countries that are importing into Australia are the very countries that have the most distorted trade practices against our exports. I do not find that it is necessarily in Australia's interests, for example, to allow imports into this country from areas where cost production is distorted or which cause difficulties for our exports into their marketplaces. I think there is a limit to the degree of open marketplaces that Australia should be prepared to tolerate from countries that are not prepared to exercise free trade themselves.

Let me digress just slightly on an issue in the tariff customs area-that is, the proposed importation of pig meat into Australia from Canada. Currently we produce about 300,000 tonnes of pig meat a year. It is a non-protected industry and it is open to free market forces. No equalisation program or subsidisation by government is involved in our local pig meat market. Canada wants to have the right to import pig meat into Australia. The Canadians have a stabilisation or equalisation program which, in effect, adds a benefit of about 2.3c per kilogram for its pig producers. In the province of Quebec there is yet another equalisation program which puts a subsidy on Quebec meat producers' pig meat products. It seems to me that, if the Canadians want the right to enter the Australian marketplace, they should be allowed to do so only if they produce pig meat without subsidy so that they come into this marketplace at a free and open competitive level. If the Canadians cannot do that, I believe we have an obligation to our own producers and to the Australian marketplace to say that we do not want to reduce our own cost-effective supplies by unfair competition from Canadian pig meat.

I know that many farmers and pig producers in Australia argue that we should not allow pig meat to enter because of quarantine. There are concerns that particular viruses present in the pig industry in Canada could damage our own local pig meat industry. I think those arguments are quite fallacious. I believe that the greater argument and the greater concern, which I share with Australian farmers on this issue, is the fact that Canadian pig meat is subsidised. The Americans have recently imposed a bounty on the import of Canadian pig meat into the American marketplace. The Americans have agreed that the Canadian pig meat is subsidised and, under General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) arrangements, the Americans now impose a bounty on its import into the United States market. My own view-and I will push this view-is that, if we are going to allow Canadian imports, we should take the same action as the United States Government has taken.

Of great pleasure to me in this Bill is the fact that heavy agricultural equipment, which is not produced in this country, and the parts associated with that heavy agricultural equipment will now be tariff free. That will be a great boon to our Australian farmers, who have after all been the great sufferers of the whole tariff protection system in Australia. It has imposed upon our farmers a great degree of additional cost on their input side. I am pleased that this Government is moving down the track and reducing that tariff cost to Australian agricultural producers. We can never forget that it is our agricultural producers that are still the largest income earners of this country and that are so vital to our economic success in the future. It is a major step, and I trust that the National Farmers Federation will congratulate this Government-after all, it has been pushing for this for a long time-and recognise the major macro-reform and micro-reform which is occurring through this legislation.

It is also appropriate in this place to acknowledge the work done by the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), and by Senator Button. They are both quiet achievers in many ways. It is not often recognised that the major macro and micro changes occurring through the customs area are of significant value in the economic reform of this country. I congratulate both those Ministers on the work they are doing. We often have our disagreements. As the Minister well knows, I have rather strong views on dumping. I am still not quite satisfied that our dumping legislation is effective and is necessarily doing the job which it should do and which it can do under the GATT agreement. Nevertheless, despite those minor disagreements that occur within government and political systems from time to time, the Minister at the table and Senator Button deserve our respect and congratulations and the respect and congratulations of the Australian people for the work they have done in this area. They are the quiet achievers of government and they have gone a long way down the track to redressing many of the protection problems this country faces and to opening up our marketplaces to more international competition.

Before I close, I would like to issue a challenge to the Opposition. If it is really serious about major economic reform and micro-reform, why does it not tear up the document it calls the Economic Action Plan and put some of its policies on the table? It should let the Australian people and industry know where it stands on these major reform areas, instead of running away and refusing to debate in real terms its position on protection. It is time it came out and presented to the Australian public a major economic statement, which statement is not contained in its current policy or documentation. That is the challenge I give to the Opposition-to do some work, instead of being lazy, and to produce some policies on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to comments made by honourable members who participated in the debate. I thank the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) for his comments. We have had occasional vigorous discussions about dumping. He is well on the way to being an economic rationalist but not where his own electorate applies, which is true of many members in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up one point about Australia's capability to produce something that can make a significant international contribution in this era of the level playing field, something to which I think even the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) has become a slight convert. In some areas, such as micro-electronics and computers which the honourable member mentioned, it is probably a bit late in the day for Australia to achieve a significant share of the world market. I make the point that, if we look for niche markets and develop a high level of specialisation, it is possible to make a significant penetration.

I have often cited the example of Sweden. I will refrain from citing Sweden this time and give another quite useful example, that of Finland. Finland is a country with only four million people, a very tiny local market and, apart from timber and scenery, not much in the way of natural resources. But it has identified a number of niche areas where it makes a very significant contribution. Prima facie, one would say that it would be ridiculous for a nation such as Finland, with four million people, to be able to compete with the United States of America on telecommunications-the United States with its 260 million people, and having initiated the telephone system back in the nineteenth century and having been regarded as the world leader. When there was a race to see which country would be the first to produce a fully digital telephone exchange, the race was won not by the United States but by Finland. Throughout the European market, and in some parts of North America, pro rata, there is a far higher degree of success from the Finnish company, Data Saab, starting from a very tiny base, than from the United States.

The other illustration that often comes to mind is in medical technology. In some cases the most sophisticated machines for assaying samples taken from patients are produced by the Finnish firm Kone. The most sophisticated American assay material can survey about 12 physical qualities in the samples at once. Kone can do as many as 24. It is far in advance of the American capability. At first glance, Finland's lead does not seem to make too much sense. One would think that the Americans would lead in every one of these areas. In fact, they do not. I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate and wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: COURTS AND TRIBUNALS ADMINISTRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 November, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Courts and Tribunals Administration Amendment Bill 1989 seeks in effect to detach the government from the day-to-day running of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Federal Court of Australia and the Family Court of Australia and to make the President of the Tribunal and the chief judges of those courts responsible for their administration. As is probably understood by honourable members, the day-to-day administration and running of those three bodies is the responsibility of the Attorney-General's Department. The view has been expressed, which we accept, that relieving the Attorney-General's Department of its present daily control of these bodies will enhance their efficient and effective operation. Therefore, it should come as no surprise to the House to hear me say that the Opposition supports this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The administrative affairs of the Tribunal will be the responsibility of the President and the administrative affairs of the Federal Court and the Family Court will be the responsibility of the chief judges of those courts. In their work they will be assisted by the Registrar of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Registrar of the Federal Court. The Family Court will have a Chief Executive Officer. The reason for creating this new position to assist in this administrative work is that the Family Court already has registrars and deputy registrars who perform quasi-judicial functions and it is therefore necessary to establish a new position. These three administrative officers will be appointed by the Governor-General and will act under the direction of the respective judicial heads of the two courts and the Tribunal respectively.

The Bill requires the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the two chief judges of the courts to prepare an annual report on the administrative affairs of the bodies and a financial statement for the previous financial year. Those reports, together with a report by the Auditor-General, will have to be laid before both Houses of the Parliament. Of course, it is appropriate that that be done because the Parliament still has an overriding responsibility, as it must have, for the proper running of the courts and to ensure that they provide to citizens the service that they are expected to provide. The intention is that estimates will be prepared each year for each of the three bodies but that no expenditure will be made on any of them other than in accordance with estimates that have been approved by the Attorney-General. So the overall financial responsibility will be in the hands of the government as a whole.

It will be known that the High Court has for some years had a similar responsibility for managing its own administrative affairs. I have not heard any criticism of that structure since it was set up; it seems to work well. We are confident, therefore, that the proposals under this Bill are worth while implementing, at the very least to see how they go. We have been told in the second reading speech that the proposal is supported by the two chief judges and by the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which support is welcome. We support the Bill because we believe the probability is that it will contribute to efficient resource management and flexibility in the administration of these bodies.

Having said that, it should also be said that court reform in general is important. The courts are an important part of the structure of our country at both the Federal and State level. They provide vital services for citizens to resolve disputes. It is important that a good and efficient system of justice should be administered through the courts. Unfortunately, when one looks at the whole court structure of Australia, one cannot say that it presently meets that desirable objective. It has traditionally been very difficult to get governments to focus on the importance of court reform and, indeed, to provide the funds that are clearly needed for the proper administration of the courts. It has been written into the mythology of this country that there are no votes in the law, in the courts or in having a more expensive and efficient system of justice administered through the courts. It is very difficult to determine whether that is true. But, irrespective of whether there are any votes in it, the reality is that the courts play a vital part in our civilisation and it is important that they be properly funded, that there be adequate numbers of judges and that prompt justice be administered for citizens through the courts. To the extent that that is not provided, it is a very severe shortcoming which should be rectified.

The second point that should be made is that the present situation is far from satisfactory. One can say without any shadow of doubt that the service provided in the Federal courts is much better than that provided in the State courts. Virtually all of the State courts are jammed with long lists of cases which in many cases take years to come on for hearing. I understand that in the Supreme Court of one of the States one can expect to wait from seven to eight years in some areas for a matter to come to trial. Of course, by that time, if witnesses and parties are not dead, they have certainly forgotten the evidence, which results in an adequate system of justice in which witnesses are expected to recollect events that happened five, six or seven years ago. Of course, that is not as bad as would be the case if we were to have prosecutions under the War Crimes Act when witnesses would be expected to remember events that occurred 50 years ago-but it is bad enough. That situation which exists, unfortunately, in some of the courts, mainly the State courts, really is thoroughly unsatisfactory.

One of the reasons that the present system is not working adequately is that the procedures are archaic. It is time that governments in Australia turned their minds to doing whatever they can to ensure that the courts apply modern and efficient systems. Many of the procedures that still apply in the courts were first used hundreds of years ago and have basically not changed. In many cases, they are cumbersome and archaic. They use most peculiar language, which is a foreign language to well over 90 per cent of the population. Those procedures are in urgent need of overhaul. Given that reality, it is really not surprising that people, particularly those in the commercial world, are looking away from the courts to other methods of having their disputes resolved. That is one of the reasons for the rise in arbitration, particularly commercial arbitration. We gave credit to the Government for introducing the Bill on international commercial arbitration, which we still support. It is not really surprising that there is an emerging demand, especially from the commercial community, for modern, swift, efficient methods of alternative dispute resolution when the traditional method of doing it through the courts has become unsatisfactory because of cost, delays and, in many cases, archaic procedures.

The question of cost is another and permanent problem in the administration of justice. One of the reasons that the present court system is in many respects unsatisfactory is the great cost involved. In this country one can go to law if one is poor or if one is rich. But, if one is part of the middle class, one has to pay for it oneself, and it is extremely difficult and very costly to litigate. That difficulty means that there is a denial of justice to those citizens, and our whole society suffers.

I should say, however, that as to the Federal structure, these days when one makes inquiries about the Family Court, by and large the news is becoming better. One must place on record again the improvements that have taken place in that court under the present Chief Judge, Mr Justice Nicholson. Wherever I go-and, of course, I move amongst lawyers-I find that there are two things that they say regularly. The first is, `Do your best to get rid of the present Government'-and I readily accede to their requests in that regard-and the second thing is that the Family Court has got much better in recent times and that the present Chief Judge has introduced a new spirit into the court. There is a life and activity in that court which is very commendable and very good to see.

That therefore leads me to say that the problems that I have touched on are not really problems which are at their most apparent and most obvious in the Federal structure. They are basically State court problems. Nevertheless, we should continue to remind ourselves of those sorts of problems, because the Federal Government is responsible for a large section of the judicial structure of this country. The Federal Government is responsible for the largest court in the country, the Family Court, and it is responsible for a wide range of judicial and semi-judicial tribunals. It is timely to remind ourselves that they play a very important part in our society. They must run efficiently, they must have adequate funds and they must have an adequate number of judges to do the job.

I conclude by saying that it seems to the Opposition that this Bill is a step in the right direction. It will make the courts themselves responsible for their own administration. The responsibility will be on them, although of course there will still be an overriding responsibility on the part of the Government and, indeed, on the part of this Parliament. It must be said that we believe that the Bill may well contribute to better resource management in the courts and to flexibility and administration within those bodies themselves. Those people who work within them, of course, being closer to them and closer to their own workings, must know better than anyone else just how a court or tribunal should be run day-to-day. The Opposition supports the Bill. We trust that when we see it in full force and effect we will see the benefits of this measure in improved and better administration of the Federal Court, the Family Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened quite intently to the words of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), and all in all I can say that many of the remarks that he made were very fair and relevant to the intent of the Courts and Tribunals Administration Amendment Bill. I am a little disappointed that the honourable member referred to the fact that as he goes around the country talking to lawyers, judges and so forth, they tell him to get rid of this Government.
—Not judges; I didn't say that.

—Not judges; just lawyers, yes. I would not think that judges would be prepared to say that, first, because of the fact that they always try to stay apolitical and, secondly, because I think they would be the first to acknowledge, particularly those in the Federal sphere-in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Family Court or the Federal Court-that this Government has done a lot during the three terms that it has been in office to streamline the whole of the judicial system in so far as it relates to matters that come under Federal jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: I also note that the shadow Attorney-General said that governments must consider the question of the whole operation of the administration of justice in this country. I think that this Government has in fact done that. In the past six or seven years the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has probably done more in relation to amending legislation and streamlining the administration of justice and the way in which justice is carried on in this country than any other government has ever done. I remember speaking to a number of Bills, particularly relating to the Family Court.
