The Family Court is now able to dispense justice a lot more quickly. There are now judicial registrars and all sorts of reforms have been undertaken in the Family Court. Even the shadow Attorney-General has acknowledged that these have improved the situation quite dramatically in the Family Court. I acknowledge that probably the present Chief Judge of the Family Court has had a lot to do with making that situation occur. By the same token, he can only work under the laws that exist and under the legislation that is passed by Parliament. The improvements come first of all from us; they come from this Government and from the Attorney-General, who is presently at the table.

The Bill obviously deserves support. It is part of the streamlining of the processes so that courts can operate independently and more efficiently. It is also true to say-and I acknowledge again what the shadow Attorney-General said-that there are really no votes in the law. The law is a mundane sort of thing in many respects which really only lawyers understand. The Attorney-General, of course, is a very well regarded lawyer. He understands these matters and therefore many of these reforms have been undertaken not because we want to get votes but because we recognise that the law needs to be reformed in some areas and that access to the law needs to be made easier for people. The reforms that this Government has made in terms of legal aid and other areas I think have been nothing short of magnificent.

This is the first time that the Family Court, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court will have their own moneys that they can use. In other words, they will be able to plan their budgets a lot better. At the beginning of this financial year, separate appropriations were made for each of these courts. That can only augur well for the administration of the courts. Now the chief judges of both courts and the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-via the Chief Executive Officer of the Family Court and the registrars of the Federal Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-will pick up the responsibilities under this Act. They will now be able to plan better. They will now know exactly what moneys they have available. They will be able to manage their human resources. It will probably also lead to a shortening of delays in cases being heard.

The Federal system as it applies at the moment, with all the reforms that we have brought in over the past six years, is probably one of the better systems in terms of the administration of justice in this country. The shadow Attorney-General was correct in saying that there are massive delays in some of the State Supreme Courts. It is true that some of them are of seven or eight years duration. From my experience in the Queensland Supreme Court, it seems that it does not matter how many judges are appointed; there are always continual and very long delays. As one who has practised, particularly in the area of personal injury law, I can say that it is very difficult to explain to people when they come in that their case is on the call-over list and that it is expected to come up in the next 18 months or two years. After one has done all the work, has lodged all the pleadings and done everything that has needed to be done, the case simply sits in the court waiting for a judge to have time to handle it. Some of the delays are up to two years.

In the Federal system that does not occur. The Federal Court of Australia jurisdiction is probably one of the better jurisdictions. People can get there fairly simply and inexpensively. It is inexpensive in so far as what one has to pay to the court. The expensive part of it comes in when one needs to pay the barristers and solicitors. It is mainly the barristers; the solicitors do not get all that much. By the same token, one is able to go to the Federal Court of Australia with a minimum of fuss, whereas with most of the State Supreme Courts there are lengthy delays. Again, I put this down to the fact that the Government has done a lot to reform the Federal jurisdiction, and it is working.

Up until perhaps 12 months ago the Family Court of Australia did have a lot of delays. There were very long delays in contested cases, particularly when it came to the question of maintenance, the custody of children and property settlements. Once again, many of these cases are now settled because that jurisdiction has been given the apparatus to settle these matters out of court, and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is in the same situation. In fact, I am often told by my colleagues in my old legal practice that most of their cases, particularly those relating to veterans affairs' matters, are settled over the telephone. They actually talk over the telephone with the Registrar and the parties get together and many of these matters are settled, once again because the apparatus is there to allow them to do that. That is part of the major reforms that we have been implementing over a long period and no doubt with the prospect of this Government being in power for many years to come they will continue for many years into the future.

One point that pleases me is that my State of Queensland-of which Brisbane is the capital, of course-is now the principal registry of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for Australia. I want to thank the Attorney-General and those responsible for allowing Brisbane to become the headquarters of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal under a very able judge, Mr Justice Hartigan. I am sure, knowing Mr Justice Hartigan, he will be very happy, as will the chief judges of the other two jurisdictions, with the content of this Bill. As I say, they will have a budget, a certain amount of money which will be appropriated to them. Hopefully, they will not be in a position where, because of certain factors, they may run out of money half-way through the year and have to go cap in hand to the Attorney-General's Department. They will be able to say to themselves that, because they have an allocation of several million dollars and an average number of cases, they will need so much of this and so much of that and all the rest of it and it will be much simpler for them to plan and budget and know exactly where they are going.

As previously stated, I believe also that, even though the delays are fairly minimal in the courts that undertake Federal jurisdiction, the delays that are there may well be eliminated or at least shortened because of the fact that they will know where they are going and because administratively they will now be in charge of their own affairs. As the shadow Attorney-General said, the High Court of Australia has to a great degree over the past several years had that autonomy and it has now been given to the other courts exercising Federal jurisdiction. I think it has worked well with the High Court.

I notice that the Bill provides for the High Court of Australia to hand back its power to levy charges-in other words, to set its own court fees. I notice that that will now be done by regulation. Perhaps this is just as well but, by the same token, it has had the power to look after itself administratively, and I accept that it has done that quite well. I do not want to dwell on the other things that the Bill will do, but I point out that it satisfies the Government's intention to confer administrative independence on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Family Court of Australia and the Federal Court of Australia. I think that those jurisdictions and the tribunal will be very gratified with this approach. I commend the Attorney-General for what he has done in this respect and I think that it augurs well for the proper and smooth running and reform of these institutions in respect of the Federal jurisdiction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can declare an acute objectivity in this debate because I am not a lawyer but a layman. One might ask why a layman is interested in the administration of the courts, and I have asked myself that question. I have had sufficient contact with the courts, particularly the Family Court of Australia and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is a different beast and I will explain why, as I understand it, in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: It strikes me that, firstly, we should recognise that the Family Court of Australia and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) are only 15 years old; they are very new jurisdictions. The intention of the Courts and Tribunals Administration Amendment Bill of financial independence for the Federal Court of Australia, the Family Court of Australia, and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal does not cap off the matter entirely; it is another step along the way to providing efficiency in the administration of the courts which ultimately brings justice to those people who appear before them.

The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), spoke about the archaic procedures of the courts. My only recollection in this respect relates to the period when I was working for the Victorian Government some five or six years ago when Jim Kennan was the Victorian Attorney-General. Mr Kennan put out a press release referring to the death of the `purple gutser'. I had no idea what this was, although it was touted as a great administrative reform in the Victorian courts in those days. It turned out that the purple gutser was the purple roneoed sheet which had been used for 50 years in the Victorian courts to provide the transcript of cases. So, that was the great administrative reform. Of course, I am not belittling that reform, but this was my first introduction to the archaic nature of the administration of some of the courts in the land. As I said, it took until 1983 or 1984 to implement a system within some of the Victorian courts whereby they did not have to rely on some poor person running off roneoed sheets in order to obtain a reasonable transcript of a case for lawyers and barristers to read and check their remarks. The death of the purple gutser was a significant move in the law courts of Victoria only five years ago. Fortunately, our courts, and certainly the Victorian courts, are now far more sophisticated in respect of the way they seek to administer their affairs.

In Queensland recently I spoke to the Family Court judge who will be responsible for putting together the budget for the Family Court Australia-wide. He was very excited about this prospect and we were able to talk about it. The prospect for him involves a situation whereby each year he will receive an allocation from the Government's Budget and, while that gives him enormous freedom to run the courts as efficiently as possible, it also imposes an enormous discipline because if he goes over budget that is it-he has had it. I think that that sort of discipline has shaken up in a good way the Family Court of Australia. As a result, many of the administrative people and the senior judges are talking about how best they should use their resources to one end; that is, to get the greatest number of cases decided at the highest quality. To the extent that this reform building on others might achieve that, I congratulate the Government.

The thing about the Family Court is that it is probably the one jurisdiction that most readily comes to mind because people always go there in circumstances which are of their making. A person's marriage breaks down because he or she is fighting with his or her spouse, but they often attach blame to the Family Court. Officers of the Family Court work strenuously towards the resolution of conflict in a marriage breakdown. They use a string of different officers in the Family Court from the judges through to the judicial registrars on the second rung and down to the court counsellors. The Family Court demonstrates more than the other two jurisdictions the need for some administrative flexibility because that court, which is only about 15 years old, has shown that it is possible to bring a softness to very delicate and often emotionally crippling proceedings, giving people the chance to sort out their problems in their own mind. They can separate, divide their property, allocate the care of children, and so on. They are very sensitive matters, and the Family Court of Australia is to be congratulated for the way it has been able to do that. It must also be congratulated in terms of its personnel. To get the judges, judicial registrars and court counsellors-all of whom have very different skills, backgrounds and experiences-to work together is quite an achievement, believe me, because in some ways they should be pulling in different directions.

Court counsellors seem to work extremely well in trying to get people initially to reconcile and talk over who should have responsibility for the children and for what periods of time. The judicial registrars might have the responsibility for some of the pre-hearings in the sense of saying, `Look, if we can decide outside the court on the division of property, you can save yourself a lot of money.' So, in a sense, the judicial registrar second guesses a decision that a judge would make.

Should all these matters not be resolved, people actually end up in court, where they have their day before the judge. To run all of that efficiently takes a great deal of work. I believe that it is a brave and correct move for the Family Court in particular to want financial autonomy and to run its own affairs. Of course, that has nothing to do with the separation of judicial powers. I am addressing purely administrative matters.

I now wish briefly to refer to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As far as I can understand, the administrative tribunal system is very separate from the courts, which always deal with matters of law. Since the early 1970s, we have decided in this country that decisions of administrators-say, those who are handing out social security or veterans' affairs pensions-ought to be reviewable, not by the Minister, as that is too difficult. There should be a set of rules whereby officers know that they can make a decision but that, if they get it wrong, the individual, who may not have got a pension, can have the decision reviewed by a tribunal at no or little cost. Then the correct decision can be made, and maybe the decision of an individual public servant will be overturned.

My small experience in this area was as a member of the Veterans' Review Board (VRB) for a couple of years. It seemed to me that a discipline was imposed on the first rank decision maker-the person sitting in the Repatriation Commission-who was the first person to decide whether digger X was to get, say, a disability pension. If the person making the first decision got it wrong, the digger was able to go to the Veterans' Review Board-a panel of three people-which would decide not the law but simply the merits of the case. Of course, as well as we could, we had to apply the law to the facts of a particular case. Largely, that body worked well and got most of its decisions correct. In other words, on occasions we might have affirmed the decision of the person in the Repatriation Commission not to give a pension, and that might have been the end of the matter. On the other hand, we could overturn the decision of the person in the Repatriation Commission and say, `No, you were wrong in applying the law or the rules to the merits of this individual digger's case; the pension should be granted.' The digger would then go away happy.

If the digger was still unhappy he could appeal again to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is the most senior administrative tribunal in the Commonwealth. It is not a court, since it does not make decisions on the law. It applies the facts or the merits of the case to the law as it is handed to it. Beyond that, if one is still unhappy and wants to appeal against a decision of the AAT, one goes to the Federal Court.

It is a sign of maturity of administration as such in government where we can have a set of tribunals that oversee the individual decisions of public servants. To the extent that those decisions are explained, the public servant has a guide. The person in the Repatriation Commission can begin to read the decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and of the Veterans' Review Board in an effort to get decisions right in future cases. Such a person may think, `I have been knocking out too many diggers by forbidding them to have a pension, but if I read these cases I have some idea as to how I make a decision about whether or not to grant a disability pension.'

Thus, the effect of the Tribunal is educative, not just to decide right or wrong or the merits of a case. Its purpose also is to tell those further down the line, `This is how you should decide cases X, Y and Z.' It is saying, in effect, `Apply your own thoughts to the matter but have a look at these decisions as guides.' We have found that, largely, that works well and that process begins to lower the cost of decision-making. If the first public servant deciding a case about who should or should not get a pension gets it right most of the time, the cost to the whole system falls dramatically, because there are not thousands of appeals drifting through from the VRB to the AAT, to the courts and so on. We have found that this process works and largely, during the past 10 years, we have been getting it right more often.

The quality of decision-making at the initial stage is improving. We do not have people now who just look at the departmental handbook and who know the Act backwards. They also have cases that they can knock around and decide whether or not they are applying a given rule to a particular case. That seems to me to be an excellent practice in terms of getting a quality primary decision made. The fact about administrative appeals or tribunals is that they tend to deal and are most useful in dealing in high bulk areas, such as tens of thousands of veterans, Department of Social Security pensioners or whatever. We could not possibly have that number of cases going through the court. It is an expensive proposition for the individual. The courts are essential, but once a person has to pay experts to go there and put a case the tariff is fairly high.

The notion of the tribunals is that one can go there as an individual. One can have someone hold one's hand and help to put the case but one does not pay a legally trained person. That is a good situation. It does not mean that one is denied the abilities of a lawyer, as a lawyer can write the case, but one goes before the tribunal as an individual to talk about the merits of one's case. One goes there without cost and without prejudice and knowing that if one is still not happy with the decision one can go up to the next rung. Largely, there is a sort of trickle up effect; very few cases get to the third rung of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal because generally the decisions at the lower level are getting more and more accurate. That is saving money.

I leave my remarks there. I congratulate the Attorney-General and the Government on these further reforms to administration. As a layman, I can see the benefits of these reforms, which build on major changes to our court and tribunal systems that have been built in only the past 15 years. The Family Court and the AAT have been with us only a short time. The whole notion of administrative tribunals and the review of administrative decisions has been with us only in the last decade and a half. We should be proud of those achievements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that both sides of the Parliament should welcome the measures before the House today. They are to be welcomed because they give a greater emphasis to the need for efficient administration of the affairs of the courts. It has been one of the scandals of the judicial system from time immemorial that delays and inefficiencies seem inherently part of the process. As a practitioner of the High Court and of the courts in Tasmania and other jurisdictions, I have become aware from time to time of injustices occurring to individuals because their cases have not proceeded expeditiously or because the administration of the judicial process has been unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: Almost every practitioner in Australia would be able to recount one or two instances of this type. They are usually exceptions to the rule; nonetheless, they occur often enough for us to be very concerned. This is not a new phenomenon; it was a dramatic theme of Charles Dickens and writers in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries in Great Britain. Novels such as Bleak House dealt with the long delays in justice being delivered.

One of the problems in the legal system in this country is that there is no proper process to train those who administer justice. Judges are appointed because of their competence and skills as practitioners-as lawyers. Although one may be a leader of the Bar and capable of the most extraordinary skills of mental agility when presenting a case on behalf of a client and because of those skills be a competent, fair-minded and impartial adjudicator, there is no reason to expect that such a person will naturally be a skilled and well-trained administrator. Unfortunately, the proof of the pudding has too often been in the eating and persons who have considerable skills and eminence within the legal profession are, in fact, the most appalling administrators. They have demonstrated that, unfortunately, to the disadvantage of litigants.

I know this is a matter that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has been very concerned about, not just for the simple dollars and cents reason that obviously court delays often lead to calls for more appointments of judges and more judicial officers and, therefore, increase the cost of the delivery of judicial services, but from the point of view of a genuine concern about the well-being of those of the Australian public who want to be able to go to a court or tribunal without delay and without the prospect of their case being adjourned three or four times because the papers, or the judges, are not in a position to proceed. It is bad enough, of course, that quite frequently lawyers are not in a position to proceed, but when the court itself is responsible for delay then naturally there is a sense of grievance created.

How does one go about changing a system which has been bedevilled by these kinds of problems for so long? The first thing to do is give responsibility to those within the system because, if we do not give responsibility, we can hardly expect accountability. Secondly, we must make sure that there are those who have skills and the training within the system to effectively administer the judicial system. This measure that the Attorney-General has placed before the House achieves both objectives. Firstly, it gives responsibility for administration to the courts through their chief justices and, in the case of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, through the President of the Tribunal.

I mention in passing that it may have been thought that a more appropriate mechanism to have adopted would have been a collegiate system such as applies in the High Court of Australia and in the Supreme Court of the United States of America. However, I can understand that process being rejected for the larger courts, particularly the Family Court, which is so large that a process of collegiate management would be out of the question simply because of the scale of the operation. Nonetheless, I hope that in the carriage of their responsibilities the chief justices and the President bear in mind that good administration will involve carrying the rest of their court or tribunal with them, and that that process should involve extensive consultations with their brother judges. Perhaps that expression is now passe and one should not use such language. I should say their `colleagues', rather than their `brother judges', which suggests a sexual composition of the court which hopefully is no longer as it once was.

Thus, we give responsibility to the judges; we give them the power to manage their own affairs. Therefore, in turn, we can require of them some accountability and expect them to look to the performance of their functions as being not only impartial and fair but also efficient and effective. Secondly, we ensure that we are not just making a token gesture and giving administrative responsibility to untrained personnel by constituting statutory officers with the expectation that those persons will have the background, training and skills necessary to administer large organisations. In each instance, with the tribunal and the two courts-the Federal Court and the Family Court of Australia-under the President or the chief justices are the positions of Registrar and Chief Executive Officer, who will be expected to carry out the day-to-day administration of the court system under the direction of the chief justices or the President.

The Bill provides measures that ensure that those new responsibilities are vested in officers who have both appropriate legal powers to exercise their functions and the appropriate administrative training to carry out their major functions. We really do now have an obligation to see not only that fairness is achieved in any judicial process but also that delay is avoided, inefficiency is rooted out of the system and the kind of indifference to litigants' convenience which so often irritates outsiders in the legal system is abolished.

These measures should be welcomed not only by practising lawyers but also by political parties on both sides of the House. I am sure that the Attorney-General has found that that has been the response to these measures. It certainly is very pleasing that the courts and tribunals themselves are prepared to accept this additional responsibility. It would be a cheap jibe to make of tribunals and courts that they are not as efficient as they ought to be, if one is not prepared to give the responsibility to the tribunals themselves to ensure that they have the management techniques and the powers to respond to the legitimate concerns that the community raises.

There are, no doubt, areas in the administration of justice in Australia which can be much improved. Some elements of the Federal Court system are models of efficiency, courtesy and good management. In other cases, it would be fair to say, there have been quite substantial criticisms from the profession of the conduct of registries, the failure to provide efficient retrieval systems of information to the courts, the failure of listing systems to ensure that matters get on promptly, and the lack of a system to ensure that, if matters fall off the list for one reason or another, other matters are lined up ready to take their place so there is no wasted court time. In all those matters the transfer of responsibility to the courts should allow for heightened expectations about what the court system will deliver, and for the expectation of the courts that they will play their parts in making sure that there is a more efficient and effective judicial system. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for their support. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), who led for the Opposition, indicated that the Opposition supported the Courts and Tribunals Administration Amendment Bill. My colleagues the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) and the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) also made very worthwhile contributions. Without delaying the House, I just make the point that this is an innovative measure. It gives all the courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal independence, their own budget, the opportunity for self-management and the responsibility of public accountability. It will add to the efficiency of the courts and certainly help the administration of justice.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of points were raised during the course of the debate. I welcome the praise of the courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That in itself is a tribute to the courts, particularly their leadership. The High Court of Australia has its own budget and it has had to meet its requirements within a relatively difficult budget period. I thank Sir Anthony Mason and the judges for their cooperation. The Federal Court is recognised as being a most efficient court, which it is. Again, my thanks to Sir Nigel Bowen and his team for the excellent work that they are doing.

People can think of ways to criticise the Family Court of Australia. This most difficult jurisdiction now has almost 60 judges. Last year about 47,000 divorce applications were lodged. One can see the spin-off that would relate to that sort of work. The court has had its ups an downs and it still has its difficulties in terms of getting every part of Australia up to a required efficiency. I pay tribute to Chief Justice Alistair Nicholson and his able assistant, Mr Justice Barblett, and the team, who are continuing to look at this area. They started off 15 years ago with inadequate premises and that has bedevilled them. We are still trying to find adequate capital to re-house them properly. But we are getting there.

The Administrative Appeals Tribunal is an outstanding success. The Tribunal inherited from the board of appeal 97,000 taxation cases that were not able to be dealt with. The total is now down to a mere fraction of that number. Mr Justice Hartigan and his team have immensely reduced delays. This is a most efficient method of dealing with justice and I thank the honourable member for Petrie for his recognition of that fact.

There has been a substantial amount of praise for this legislation. At present we are still discussing judicial salaries. I hope that they will be dealt with in the Senate tomorrow and that the Bill will be passed. This will lead to some amelioration of the problem. The judiciary and the legal profession play a substantial part in the administration of justice in this country and are a bulwark of democracy. There will be many disgruntled people if we cannot deal with delays in the courts.

In recent times it has often been thought that economists run the country. No doubt they do, but their remuneration seems to be getting well in excess of that paid to the judiciary. Whilst I can understand the reasons for it, I note that these learned people in economics have to have other people representing them when they go to court. It is from that group that we select the judiciary. In recent legislation, which was properly supported by the Opposition, we were able to increase the remuneration of the Family Court judges to what is deemed to be a reasonable amount. In other words, the Executive itself has had to top up their remuneration over and above what had been determined by a tribunal. The judges will always be anxious to offer their services, as they have over a period of years. But it is fair that they get adequate recognition for what they have done. This Bill gives them an opportunity to administer their own judicial areas to the benefit of Australia at large. When comparing our jurisdictions with others in the world, we have nothing to be frightened of. We do have the difficulties of delays and increased pressures on the courts but the legal profession is certainly pulling its weight, and I thank it for that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989 has very little to do with tax administration or tax reform. It has much more to do with issues such as arrogance, ego, ignorance, confrontation and government greed. The key elements of this Bill are some decisions which I described as fairly draconian the day after the Budget where they were announced. Basically they amount to the rape of the corporate sector, in particular the small and medium sized business sector. It was decided to bring forward the payment of tax into this financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, this legislation really has nothing to do with tax administration. Sure, it has been dressed up in the name of tax equity, but it has nothing to do with tax administration. It has much more to do with the arrogance of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), his ego and his desire to fudge his fiscal record. He wanted the Budget surplus this year to look better than it otherwise was going to be. Honourable members can just imagine the meetings that took place in his office or in the Treasury as he called in the guys and said, `I'm stuck. I need nearly $1 billion more to make this surplus look respectable'. Honourable members can imagine them going through the various ideas and hitting on the idea of bringing forward the payment of corporate tax, of hitting a few large companies by bringing forward that payment into this year with the practical effect of nearly $900m of corporate tax revenue, which would otherwise have been collected next year, being brought into this year. It was contrivance; it was a sleight of hand to make the Budget surplus look better. But if passed-and we will be seeking to amend the legislation in a number of important respects-this Bill will have draconian effects on small and medium sized business.

The legislation is confrontationist because there was no consultation in the development of this and other sections of the Bill, particularly the decisions in relation to the introduction of a self-assessment procedure for the corporate sector. It is just fundamentally wrong to make those sorts of changes without consultation in an area as important as that, where there is already an enormous amount of criticism about tax administration and the exercise of discretion by the Commissioner of Taxation.

This Bill reveals, as have a number of other decisions, the Treasurer's true colours when it comes to tax. I mentioned the concept of government greed and his colours are well established in this respect. He has collected, for example, $13 1/2 billion net out of bracket creep over the life of the Hawke-Keating Government. That is, over and above the tax cuts this Government has given, the Government has collected $13 1/2 billion simply because people have been pushed into higher tax brackets as a result of inflation impacting on their income. As a consequence, there has been a substantial blow-out in the public sector. In our Economic Action Plan we have given a commitment to hand back bracket creep annually. The Treasurer keeps ducking and refusing to give a similar commitment.

Secondly, one could look at the superannuation decision that was brought in this year after the worst handling of any tax legislation in the history of this country. The fundamental desire behind that legislation was to bring forward the payment of tax in relation to the superannuation industry, much the same sort of motivation as underlies the key elements of this Bill.

The Treasurer parades the country-indeed, he is now parading the world-lecturing everybody about what they are doing wrong and how they can fix their systems. He dresses up what he has done in the concept of a level playing field. But he puts his own potholes in his own playing field to look after his mates. The union movement is not hit by these tax changes. It is exempted from the capital gains tax. Canteen lunches did not get caught by the fringe benefits tax. I could go on. The Treasurer looks after his mates and parades in the cloak of tax equity. There is no tax equity in this legislation. As I say, it is all about Government greed. It might give the Treasurer a warm inner glow to know that his Budget surplus is $900m bigger than it otherwise would have been but it will send thousands of small to medium sized businesses to the wall.

In making the decision that he has made on this Bill, the Treasurer has revealed an acute ignorance of the current plight of small business. Small to medium sized businesses are out there today struggling under the burden of 21 to 25 per cent interest rates-record level interest rates which, in themselves, are enough to send a lot of those businesses out backwards. Not many businesses in this country can earn the rates of return over a sustained period that would justify paying interest rates at that sort of level. Only a third of the top 500 companies in this country earn more than the long term bond rate on shareholders' funds. This is a ludicrous position to put the small business community in.

Small businesses are fighting those interest rates at a time when there is a very tough liquidity squeeze on them. They are facing the prospect next year, as a direct result of this Government's high interest rate policy, of a substantial slow-down in the demand for what they produce. Indeed, the bottom line, as revealed by a number of people, could be a recession next year. There will still be high interest rates then because the Government has no solution to the balance of payments, inflation and debt problems. The liquidity squeeze will still be on. The prospect of a downturn will grow. The Government has made some wonderful decisions in relation to small business taxation. The capital gains tax to which business is subject--

TALK.START.PARA: —They hate small business.

—They do hate small business. The capital gains tax has removed the incentive to start a small business, to expand a small business, to take in a partner, to inject capital or to liquidate the business at which time one is basically subject to double tax at top marginal tax rates. It is little wonder that the number of corporate failures and personal bankruptcies is now approaching record levels. Next year the large companies, many of which include the mates of this Government, will make record level profits over and above the record level profits they made this year. At the same time we will have record numbers of small business failures and personal bankruptcies. That is the bottom line of this Government when it comes to issues of economic management and taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is a total insensitivity on the part of the Treasurer to the difficulties that he was imposing on small and medium sized business simply because of his ego and his arrogance. He wants his Budget surplus to be bigger than it was the year before; so he dresses it up and slams the corporate sector, the small and medium sized business sector in particular, to the wall.

We will not be opposing this Bill but we will be amending it in a number of important respects. We will be amending it in relation to the decision to bring forward corporate tax, to the direct benefit of small to medium sized businesses. We will oppose the provisions of the Bill in relation to self-assessment. It is ill-conceived, it is undeveloped and it is not appropriate that it is being introduced in this way where it significantly reduces the protection that is afforded taxpayers and increases the discretion granted to the Commissioner.

In the context of a decision to bring forward the payment of company tax, the self-assessment provision could be a double whammy. The corporate sector, struggling to meet the burdens of increased tax, suddenly gets hit with a self-assessment system which leaves it particularly exposed and significantly reduces the protection it has previously enjoyed in relation to disclosure and dealings with the tax administration. So we oppose the provisions of the Bill in relation to self-assessment.

We do not like this legislation at all. We undertake firmly to review the key elements of this legislation in government. We cannot accept the concept of bringing forward the payment of corporate tax. We cannot accept the nature of the self-assessment provisions. The whole Bill, in those important respects at least, will be reviewed when we gain government. Unfortunately, in opposition we do not have enough information to be able to accurately cost and determine the impact on the small and medium sized business community as a result of these decisions but, importantly, the decision to bring forward corporate tax will result in a substantial increase in the borrowing costs of the business sector because where else will a small business find the money to pay its tax in current circumstances unless it borrows that additional money? It will be forced to borrow that additional money at interest rates of 21 to 25 per cent. An unbelievable, inconsiderate burden has been added to that community as a result of these changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keating's arrogance, isn't it?

—All to placate the Treasurer's arrogance. Let me make comments about three parts of the Bill: firstly, the decision to bring forward the payment of corporate tax; secondly, the self-assessment procedures; and, thirdly, a very good feature of the Bill, which is the decision to allow the deductability of costs incurred by taxpayers in connection with the management or administration of their income tax affairs. The company tax collection arrangement was announced, as I say, in the Budget. The Treasurer said that companies, complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts would be required to pay their company tax in two instalments each year. That is, instead of paying company tax in four instalments throughout the year, they would be allowed to pay those company tax instalments only twice during the year. Eighty-five per cent of the notional tax liability would be required 15 days after the end of their income year and late balancing companies would continue to be treated as though they were balanced in June.

SPEECH.PARA: The second and final payment would be self-assessed and would be made on the fifteenth day of the ninth month following the balance day. Penalties modelled on those currently applicable where the taxpayer varies instalments were to apply where the actual liability was underestimated by more than 10 per cent.

Those arrangements were widely condemned by the corporate sector. I remember that the day after the Budget was announced I referred to this as the rape of the corporate sector. The Treasurer laughed. He thought it was a great joke. The laugh is now on the other side of his face because the business sector en masse, but particularly the small to medium sized business sector, turned up the heat on this Government over that decision. In particular, it drew attention to some of the real weaknesses of the Bill, not only the decision to bring forward the payment of tax but also the fact that some companies would be put in the position of paying 85 per cent of their tax liability several months before the end of their financial year.

Companies have enough trouble determining their tax liabilities well after the end of their financial year. But the idea of requiring them to pay 85 per cent of their tax before the end of their financial year was anathema to most people in the business and reveals the basic fact that the Government has absolutely no idea how to run a business. It has no idea what it is like to be in business, to try to determine one's accounts and to be subject to penalties if one is wrong by more than 10 per cent. Obviously that was not considered. It was all about ego and arrogance. It had nothing to do with what was the appropriate way to run a system of corporate tax collection.

The Treasurer said that he would gain from this decision $885m in 1989-90 and a further $150m in 1990-91 and 1991-92. There would be significant savings of public debt interest to the extent of $330m as a continuing saving from 1990-91. As a result of the pressure, the Treasurer backed down in two respects in drafting this legislation on the back of that Budget time decision. Firstly, he changed his mind about late balancing companies. They will not be treated as if they balanced in June for tax collection purposes. In effect, that did away with the problem that companies could get caught having to pay 85 per cent of their tax liability before the end of the financial year.

Secondly, he identified some small companies which were to be exempted from the original decision. The exemption is that on a tax payable of $20,000 or less they would not be required to make the initial 85 per cent payment on the fifteenth day of the month following balance date. Such companies would be able to elect to defer that payment until the fifteenth day of the sixth month following balance date when the total self-assessed payment would fall due. That is a bow in the direction of the small business community, but it does not go anywhere near far enough.

One of our amendments will involve increasing the limit from $20,000 tax payable to $80,000 tax payable. That is, the taxable income threshold would rise from around $51,000 to around $200,000. We think that is fundamentally important in dealing with the small to medium size business sector in Australia. The latest published statistic suggests that about 90 per cent of companies paying tax have a taxable income up to $200,000 but pay only 10 per cent of the total corporate tax that is collected. We strongly urge this amendment, which is to raise that threshold and exempt the small business sector. I foreshadow that, under the brutal restraint of the guillotine, I will try to move several committee stage amendments which specifically deal with our changes. I now move, as a second reading amendment:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) recognising the plight of small businesses in Australia, calls on the Government to increase substantially the threshold at which the new two instalment company tax arrangements will apply;
(2) rejects the Government's proposals on self-assessment of company tax because of the inadequate safeguards and protection of the integrity of taxpayers; and
(3) condemns the Government for its flagrant disregard in its taxation policies of the circumstances faced by many small businesses in Australia''.

To summarise in the minute that I have remaining, our position is that this Bill has nothing to do with tax administration; it is principally designed to make the Treasurer's Budget surplus look better, to satisfy his ego by contriving the size of the Budget surplus, but at the substantial detriment of the small to medium size business sector, which is being asked to pay its tax unjustifiably early. Out of concern for the draconian decision that has been taken in that respect, we are moving amendments to remove the impact of this tax from the small business sector particularly on companies with taxable incomes up to $200,000. We are also opposing the provisions of the Bill for self-assessment. Not only is the legislation shoddy, but also it will result in a significant reduction in protection afforded taxpayers and will significantly increase the discretion granted to the Commissioner of Taxation in that respect. It will also-this is perhaps the most important feature of that-have an impact that could well be a double whammy on the small to medium size business sector. That is, over and above bringing forward company tax for these companies, they could run into real difficulties in relation to the procedures outlined in the Bill for self-assessment.

As I say, we do not like this legislation and we undertake to review it in government. We would meet the cost of our decision to increase these thresholds this year by reversing the Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd decision and by terminating the payment of compensation for the airline industry. We do not mind taking from large Australian companies or foreign companies to fund our deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to a question I directed to him in this House on 1 March this year concerning his promise in January this year, prior to the Western Australian election, that home loan interest rates would not rise further this year. I ask him whether he recalls that he responded to my question in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: I am quite confident that the answer that I gave then-
that is, prior to the Western Australian election-
was correct and that, by the end of this year, they-
that is, home loan interest rates-
will fall.
Does he still stand by this answer to the Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition has come back to this issue a number of times. I am quite happy, in terms of questions or answers or any motion that the Leader of the Opposition would like to move, to argue with him on the question of the conduct of economic policy in general, the outcome and level of interest rates under the policies of this Government and any alternatives that he would implement. The statement I made then was made on the basis of the assessment we had of what was going to happen to the level of activity in this country. As most commentators within the Government and within the private sector would acknowledge, the economic activity in this country has continued at a significantly higher level than was expected. That being the case, the requirement of responsible economic management was to ensure that all arms of economic policy were kept appropriately tight to ensure that we would not inflict upon this country the economic disasters that the Opposition inflicted upon it when it was last in office. That required the three arms of policy to be tight.

ANSWER.PARA: For the edification of the Leader of the Opposition I will remind him what those three arms of policy are. I refer firstly to fiscal policy. I go to fiscal and wages policy because there is some implicit suggestion in the sort of nonsense that has been talked about from the other side of the House that there is some exclusive reliance upon monetary policy in conducting economic management in this country. Of course, the opposite is true. Let us look first at fiscal policy. Never in the records of this country has fiscal policy been as tight as it is now.
Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —The laughter of honourable members opposite is no substitute for analysis. Let me give them the proof and, if they have the ability afterwards, they can try to refute the facts and substitute that for their hollow laughter. Very simply, the facts are these: In terms of establishing the tightness of fiscal policy, for four successive years now real Commonwealth outlays have declined. Commonwealth outlays as a percentage of gross domestic product are now at 23.7 per cent, which is back to the level of the early 1970s. The public sector borrowing requirement has turned around by 8.1 percentage points. As a result of the massive turnaround that we have brought about in this country-the exact symmetry, if you like, turning around the previous Government's $9 billion deficit to a surplus of $9 billion-we now have a public sector borrowing requirement in surplus which, in annual terms, means a contribution of $30 billion per annum on that score. So on the record-honourable members opposite can argue the facts if they like; they will not get anywhere-fiscal policy is tighter than it has ever been before.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn now to wages policy. If honourable members opposite study the facts they will find that there has been an 11.2 per cent reduction in real unit labour costs, never before equalled and certainly not approached by them. The contribution of honourable members opposite, in the absence of a wages policy, was to have a 17 per cent wages blow-out in 1981-82, which brought the worst recession in this country in 50 years. It is against the background of the tightest fiscal policy and the tightest wages policy that we are also relying on monetary policy. But even under that monetary policy we have not managed to reach the high level of 90-day rates the previous Government reached in April 1982, when its 90-day rates were 22 per cent. Under this Government they are now 18 per cent; they were 4 per cent higher under the previous Government.

This Government is responsibly doing what the previous Government was never able to do because it never had a wages policy. All arms of economic policy-fiscal, wages and monetary-are at the necessary level of tightness to ensure that what happened to this country under the irresponsible economic management of those opposite will never happen again.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health.

QUESTION.PARA: Mr N.A. Brown interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Menzies will cease interjecting. I warn the honourable member for Menzies.
—Has the Federal Government opposed--
—What about Bob Bell?

—The honourable member should go back to Four Corners. Has the Federal Government opposed the massive October increase in charges for private patients in public hospitals in Queensland? Why has the Federal Government taken this stand and what results have flowed from its actions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Petrie for his question, which shows a real interest in both the physical and the financial hardships imposed on Queenslanders, particularly people with private health insurance. I think all honourable members will recall, because I spoke on this matter some weeks ago, that the National Party Government in Queensland, following the pattern of its conservative colleagues in New South Wales, massively increased the charges for private patients in public hospitals from 1 October. The increase was of the order of $150 to $170 per day-a rise of 13 per cent, which is twice the rate of inflation and, in fact, the second such increase in the last 12 months. Indeed, the full effect of those Queensland changes over the last 12 months has been a 30 per cent or $40 per day rise.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the Federal Government opposed increases of this order not only because of their effect on inflation in this country but also because of the impact they would have on private health contribution rates. They would have significantly forced up those rates. We offered to the Queensland Government what we believed was a fair compromise to accept a bed day charge of $160 a day and asked the Queensland Government to accept that as fair and reason- able. Unfortunately, the National Party Cabinet rejected our offer, went ahead with the increase and imposed a $10 out-of-pocket levy on privately insured patients in public hospitals. That was a mean and miserable tax on the ill and injured and it has caused particular hardship to old and chronically ill Queenslanders, who are high users of hospital services.

The Queensland public hospital system and the private health funds in Queensland protested to the Queensland Government. We heard not a sound or a squeak out of the Federal Opposition, which is supposed to be interested in these matters, but there was considerable pressure on the Queensland Government. Even when the New South Wales Government saw sense, changed its policy and abolished the out-of-pocket levy, the Queensland National Party went on with its measure and continued to impose this charge.

Of course, as one might have expected, the electoral collapse of the National Party in Queensland has forced a rethink. I predicted in this House three weeks ago that a Goss-led Labor Government in Queensland would abolish the out-of-pocket payment when elected to office, and Wayne Goss made that promise clearly in a statement this week. Almost immediately the white flag appeared from the National Party Cabinet. I understand that the Cabinet, in a last desperate bid to win votes, has reduced those private bed day charges to $160. I say I understand that to be the case because the Queensland Government is often slow in telling the Queensland people what it has done. But I understand that that decision has been made. If so, the Queensland Government has accepted the compromise we offered two months ago and what Wayne Goss has promised. So I think it is a victory for commonsense for people in Queensland with private health insurance but I think it will do little to save the Cooper Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime Minister that, only a few minutes ago, in answer to a question I asked him about his statement earlier this year that interest rates would fall, made during the Western Australian State election, he said that that comment was made on the basis of advice available at the time. I remind the Prime Minister that, earlier this year when being questioned on this issue and when asked on whose advice he made the claim in Western Australia and what it was based on, he replied to the effect that he had taken no advice but that it was based, as I recall it, on his `considerable intellect', or words to that effect. Without questioning the extent of that intellect, which was quite clearly wrong, I ask: What is true? Was it on the basis of advice or was it just a gambit in the election campaign?

—If in this Question Time we were going to get into the area of gambits at election time, I could take a considerable amount of time exposing the impossible gambits of those opposite and their beleaguered colleagues in South Australia and Queensland. Much as I am tempted to get into that area, I will exercise the restraint for which I am very well known. I, as distinct from the Leader of the Opposition, when it comes to matters economic have the great advantage. As well as having advice available to me I have the capacity, as a result of my training and my application-neither of which he has-to understand that advice and also to form my own opinions within the range of the advice I get. There is no dichotomy between the fact that I can come to judgments myself on a range of advice and on my own reading of the situation and on what is being said by those advising. There is no dichotomy. One day, if the Leader of the Opposition applies himself a bit more assiduously to the study of economics than he ever has in his generation in public life, he may begin to understand these things.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and it relates to Aboriginal education and funding for Aboriginal education. Can the Minister inform the House of progress in the Government's campaign to improve the access to education of Aboriginal people, who by any measure can be regarded as the most disadvantaged of all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and in doing so acknowledge his very particular interest in this area, recognising that it bears upon the future of a very large proportion of the electors in his constituency. The Government has made extraordinary progress in improving the educational opportunities of Aboriginal people. If we take the period from 1982 to 1988, we find that Aboriginal school enrolments have risen by 28 per cent, Aboriginal retention rates to year 12 have risen by 126 per cent, and Aboriginal tertiary enrolments have more than doubled. From a handful a decade ago, there are now over 1,000 Aboriginal graduates from higher education institutions in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Despite that very significant improvement that we have seen over the years, we recognise that we have a considerable distance to go. If we try to measure the extent of lack of opportunity for Aboriginal people, we find that one in eight Aboriginal children between the ages of five and nine years have never attended school. Eleven per cent of all Aboriginal people 15 years and over have never attended school. Only 30 per cent of 16- to 19-year-old Aboriginals are participating in formal education or training compared with the national average for the same age group of some 75 per cent.

It was with those figures in mind-with the understanding that we had a fair distance to go-that the Government decided to launch an Aboriginal education policy which proceeded from very substantial consultation with the Aboriginal communities and those who have had a long time interest in improving Aboriginal education policy. What we have decided to set as our objectives for this policy is to ensure that there is greater Aboriginal involvement in policy-making for education issues. We also want to ensure that there is equity of access to education. We wish to raise Aboriginal participation rates to those for all Australians, and we want to achieve equitable and appropriate educational outcomes to ensure that Aboriginal people have a full opportunity to participate in all the areas of education and training with a view to improving their prospects in employment as well. We have provided new funds to support this program as well as reviewed the way in which existing funds have been expended.

We hope that over the next few weeks and months we will be able to work with the States in developing appropriate policies and appropriate programs to assist the circumstances of Aboriginal people, whether they live in some of the more remote locations in the country, such as some of the small outstations in the honourable member's electorate, or they live in metropolitan locations.

I should make the point, particularly in the context of the Northern Territory, that the Northern Territory Minister for Education should not for a moment think that this provides him with an opportunity to shirk his own responsibilities as far as the education of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory is concerned. The Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory and their education are just as much a responsibility of the Northern Territory Government as is the education of anyone else who lives in the Northern Territory. Our approach is a preparedness to work with them and to improve the programs in the Northern Territory and elsewhere. I do not take too kindly to the suggestion from the Northern Territory Minister that somehow we are not doing enough in the face of this major expansion of funds.

I also find it a little hypocritical that he should say that we are not spending enough when, if he were to view the policies of his mates on the other side of the House, he would see that they have a quite specific policy of reducing funds for Aboriginal programs generally. They wish to slash some $100m from the funds which support Aboriginal people across the areas of education, training and general community welfare. What I find particularly gutless as far as the Opposition is concerned is that that would mean that there would not be an additional dollar-in fact, there would be cuts-in funds to support Aboriginal education.

Notwithstanding the fact that those opposite have promised to gut this program which we are introducing, they supported the legislation which included the appropriations to find this money. In other words, they do not have the guts to stand up now and say that one of the consequences of their policy of cutting funds for Aboriginal programs would be that this policy of the Government would not proceed were they to be elected. They sit back trying to bask in the reflected glory of our policy by saying that they put their hands up for it. When it came to this Parliament, they did not have the courage to vote against it, as was their real intention, because this is a program which cannot proceed under the Opposition.

I think this issue, like many other issues, displays that it is only a Labor government that is entitled to govern for all the people. It is only a Labor government that is prepared to put the needs of people in the community, however impoverished they might be, ahead of the interests of the rich and powerful who are so close to the Opposition and who are so directly involved in producing its policies. It is only a Labor government that can do something about improving the circumstances of those who are worse off in the community, including Aboriginal Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of a petition from 42,000 farmers who, I assure the Acting Treasurer, are not rich and powerful and who want to know when interest rates are coming down, a petition which I am now presenting, I ask the Prime Minister: In the light of the speech given by the President of the--
—Order! The honourable member cannot present petitions at Question Time. If the honourable member does not get to his question, I will call somebody else.
—Let me apologise, Mr Speaker. I had forgotten that the Government changed the procedure on petitions.
—Order! For the information of the Leader of the National Party, the whole House changed the decision on petitions. Get to your question, or I will call somebody else.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. In the light of the speech given by the President of the National Farmers Federation to the NFF annual conference this morning, when he said that the No. 1 problem facing the Australian community was the stifling and unsustainable level of interest rates and that our national debt had increased by 1,000 per cent during the 1980s, does the Prime Minister believe that the answer given yesterday by the Acting Treasurer, that farmers were extraordinarily full of praise and congratulations for the Government's performance, is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the advantage over the Leader of the National Party of Australia--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think even the Leader of the National Party would contradict what I was about to say. I was about to say that I have the advantage over the Leader of the National Party that I was invited this morning to open the national conference of the National Farmers Federation. It invited me-not, surprisingly, the Leader of the National Party-to open its conference. I felt a certain amount of pride at three points of this morning's exercise.
—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. Despite the Prime Minister's pride in relation to the National Farmers Federation, he complained bitterly about its presenting a petition.
—Look at the petition.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—First of all, I was, of course, proud that the National Farmers Federation invited me to open its conference. Secondly, I was very proud of the laudatory comments that were made by Mr John Allwright, the President of the National Farmers Federation, when he introduced me. It is true that the Federation expressed concern about the level of interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If just for once those on the opposite side of the House would put the whole story instead of part of the story, they would recognise two things: firstly, Mr Allwright expressed considerable gratitude to the Government for many aspects of its policy. Secondly, in thanking me at the end of my speech, Mr Wally Peart did the same thing and expressed a great deal of confidence in many aspects of the Government's policy. Thirdly, as distinct from the Leader of the Opposition, after I had delivered my speech I made myself available for questions. Those people do not know what it is like to have the opportunity of having a question period with the Leader of the Opposition. He runs away from them at a million miles an hour because he knows nothing about economics and refuses to expose himself to any sort of questioning. But I spoke at the National Farmers Federation conference and then said, `Now would you like to ask me some questions?'. They asked a question about interest rates and about the exchange rate. They listened with considerable attention to the answers that I gave.
—Did they believe you?
—Order! The honourable member for Adelaide will cease interjecting.

—I would not be at all surprised to see a petition from 42,000 or 400,000 people about the level of interest rates. The important thing is that at a time of my choosing several million people-not just 42,000-will be given the opportunity not just of putting their name on a petition, which they can do at any time, but of deciding whether they want this Government--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Now, now now, now!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Call it on.
—Order! The honourable member for Dundas will behave himself.
—We want it now.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—When the people are called upon to make that decision, they will have to choose between the economic policies of this Government and the alternatives of those opposite. Of course, between now and then I will take a considerable amount of time to expose the total inadequacy of what those opposite are about. But, for the sake of the record now, I will give the Leader of the National Party an indication of the judgment made by an informed commentator about the utter emptiness and stupidity of what those opposite have been about. I refer to an article by Ross Gittins headed `Dr Hewson leads us to a different world'. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: This was where Dr Hewson revealed his great insight . . . This discovery, termed the ``integrated economic strategy'' will, he says, constitute a ``different world'' to the one we have known.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be.
—We will deal with the honourable member for Wentworth when he pops up; there is no need to worry about him.
—Thank you.
—We will not worry about him. Mr Gittins said:

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, it will confound the conventional wisdom as to how economies are managed.

The Hewson breakthrough is simply stated. His strategy will have as its central objective the control of inflation. Inflation and wage growth will be down to the level of our trading partners by the end of the first term. But this will be achieved with less, rather than greater, reliance on monetary policy and won't involve a rise in unemployment.
What does Gittins say to that? He says:
See what I mean? It's path-breaking stuff; Nobel Prize material.

This mob opposite has a policy which will mean that interest rates will go through the roof. By the time the election is called people will know which choice to make and they will do as they have done on the past three occasions-go for the side of politics that can deliver responsible economic policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment and Education Services. Will the Minister tell the House what progress has been made with the Skillshare network and whether the community has supported its development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I know of his keen interest in the Skillshare projects, three of which are in Oxley, particularly the project in Ipswich which is one of the best in the nation and which has demonstrated a very clear commitment to the principles of caring, high quality training for unemployed people and others disadvantaged in the labour force. I know that other members of this House share the same sort of interest in Skillshare as he does, particularly a number of honourable members opposite. Of course, the reason that so many honourable members have been interested in these projects is undoubtedly that this partnership between the community and the Federal Government has been one of the most successful schemes of its type ever in dealing with long term unemployed people and others who are disadvantaged in getting into the labour force. This year we expect that 60,000 people will be assisted by Skillshare projects and we anticipate that the community contribution in all of the projects will move to 20 per cent of the cost of running those projects. The 360 projects throughout the nation will continue to provide the opportunity to long term unemployed people to which they are entitled.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that this program will be threatened with abolition in the unlikely event that the Opposition ever gets on to the treasury bench. That is not a likely event, but nonetheless the people of Australia ought to know about the way in which the Opposition intends to abolish the Skillshare program lock, stock and barrel. The Opposition will shut down the whole program. It will save $61m. Every dollar allocated for the Skillshare program will be withdrawn under the proposals that the Opposition has put forward. It is disgraceful. What is more disgraceful is the hypocritical way in which honourable members opposite have, on the one hand, supported at the national level a policy of abolition and at the micro level, in their electorates, written to people saying how much they support the Skillshare projects. My office is full of this duplicity-of letters from people on the Opposition benches asking me to ensure that the Skillshare projects in their electorates continue to be funded by this Government.

I can tell people that we will continue to support the Skillshare projects because they are economically and socially sensible responses to the needs of long term unemployed people. The Opposition is saying in defence of its policy stance that it will transfer Skillshare projects into Jobtrain. But it does not propose to give the Jobtrain program one extra program dollar to do that. It is a ruse and a farce to suggest that that could happen. It is also economically stupid, because when one looks at the relative costs of the programs and what they are designed to do one finds that Skillshare is a very economical program from the point of view of the Federal Government. The cost per place with Skillshare was $751 this financial year. The cost of a Jobtrain place is $1,388. What the Opposition is proposing is stupid not only in broad economic terms but also in the way that the program dollars are to be allocated.

As I have said, what we have seen from honourable members opposite is pretty hypocritical, and it is particularly hypocritical in relation to the regional and rural areas of this nation. I have had numerous representations, particularly from cockies' corner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—I have had numerous representations from people in the rural and regional areas, urging support for Skillshare, urging that we increase, not decrease, the dollars available. In fact, the honourable member for Riverina has actually gone on television in his electorate, seeking to ride on the coat-tails of the Government's initiative, trying to seek a bit of kudos for the Skillshare program. He has come right out 100 per cent behind it, saying what an excellent program it is-and now he is supporting its abolition.

ANSWER.PARA: This sort of duplicity needs to be exposed so that the people of the nation can see just how duplicitous the Opposition is being in its approach. Honourable members opposite do not give a damn; they do not care about the unemployed people of this nation. The tremendous results that we have had in cutting back on the long-term unemployment created by the recession in 1982-83, over which honourable members opposite presided, are apparently to be cast aside by this Opposition. Honourable members opposite created the problem; we are creating the solution, and now they want to abolish the solution. It is not good enough. The Australian people will not cop it for a moment. Those honourable members opposite who have been so good as to go out and offer their services to Skillshare projects, to present certificates and the like, ought to have enough guts to return to those projects and explain just how their support has translated into a promise to abolish the projects.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the speech by Mr John Allwright, President of the National Farmers Federation (NFF), to which he referred in an earlier answer when he indicated that he was pleased that the President of the National Farmers Federation had so willingly and fulsomely praised the Government. I refer to just a few quotations from that speech:

QUESTION.PARA: Their-
that is, the Government-
pampered support for interests which are perceived to be sensitive politically is deplorable.
In reference to Kodak, Coronation Hill and the deal with the major banks:
That degree of adhockery is dangerous and tremendously worrying to industry.
He went on to say:

Whoever wins the Federal Government next year is going to face a mess . . . The Labor Party therefore should come forward with its plans for at least the next three years. So far, most attention has been on the Opposition's policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition is getting to his question?
—Yes. He goes on to say:

QUESTION.PARA: I am concerned that they're-
the Government-
running out of steam-becoming cynical and splintered.
Will the Prime Minister advise which one of these he regards as laudatory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, the Leader of the Opposition is quite incapable of presenting a total picture. What I said--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister might resume his seat until the House comes to order.
—Table the speech.
—I warn the honourable member for Bass.

—As I say, the Leader of the Opposition, as he is in all matters, has been totally selective. What I said was that of course there were aspects of this Government's policies of which the NFF was critical. I also said that both in the speech and in his welcome to me, as well as in the thanks that were passed on by Mr Wally Peart on behalf of the meeting, there was also considerable congratulation for the Government's policy. These are facts which honourable members opposite can check if they like. Their stupid behaviour will impress nobody.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Leader of the Opposition wants to have some analysis of what happened this morning it might be interesting to refer to the matter in a little more detail in one respect. We have heard a lot of noise from those opposite about the question of micro-economic reform. Indeed, this was one of the items to which Mr Allwright referred in his speech. So I tackled this issue head on. I gave a list in considerable detail of the micro-economic reform that had been undertaken by this Government prior to 1987, between 1983 and 1987, and then I referred to the fact that in the 1987 election speech I had said that in the third term of the Labor Government there would be a continuous emphasis on micro-economic reform. I then listed at considerable length what the Government had done in this area. I then put a challenge to the audience-which, of course, was not taken up. I put a very simple challenge.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.
