—It was a very simple challenge: I said that, prior to our coming to office in 1983, for 30 of the 33 years before then this country had been ruled by the conservatives. I listed all that we had done, particularly in the period since 1987, in implementing that promise and I said to the audience, `Can anyone begin to suggest any period in Australia's peacetime history, particularly including those 30 years, which came within cooee of what this Government has done in its period of office?'. Of course, the answer was a thundering silence. During the time when those opposite were in office they did not have the wisdom or the guts to take on the issue of micro-economic reform.

ANSWER.PARA: I made to the meeting the following point, which I make in conclusion here in this place: this Opposition does not have the guts to take on the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. I asked the question, which I repeat in this place: `If you do not have the guts to take on the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, how do you think you would get on on the waterfront?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Treasurer to the numerous articles that have been written discussing a proposal to abolish the capital gains tax. Does the Government endorse the view generally expressed in these articles, and what are its intentions in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question.
—No child will have a capital gains tax.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Adelaide.

—I do not suppose that there has been a part of the Opposition's so-called economic platform which has received such scathing treatment, such universal condemnation, as that part of its policy which relates to the abolition of the capital gains tax. I should remind the House that it was this Government which took the sensible, if difficult, decision to introduce an inflation adjusted capital gains tax, as part of its overall taxation reforms-not just because we thought it was a tax that ought to exist within the tax system, but rather because we knew that it was essential to making the tax system fairer, to ensuring that all Australians paid their taxes in accordance with their ability to pay. That is a very fundamental proposition in relation to taxation principles.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member referred in his question to a number of articles which have been written in condemnation of the decision of the Liberal Party to reverse that sensible decision of this Government and do away with the capital gains tax. The authors of these articles are not Labor Party pamphleteers; they are responsible journalists and, in many cases one presumes, editors of leading newspapers in this country. I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 25 October, which states:
By putting it-
that is, the abolition of this tax-

on the agenda, the Opposition has created a political issue by proposing a weak and philosophically unconvincing proposition. Its policy response, instead of showing some fiscal spine, lacks any philosophic coherence and will harm revenue.

In other words, not only does it take from people who cannot afford to pay, damaging the revenue at the same time, but also it is clear evidence that the Opposition has no consistency and no guts in terms of trying to handle the major fiscal policy issues that confront us.
Again, Terry McCrann, not always the greatest fan of this Government, said on 29 October:

Mr Peacock proposes to turn back the clock and once again unleash the assembled might of the legal, accounting and financial professions in the drive to turn otherwise taxable income into tax free capital gains of five years standing. This is unacceptable not only on equity grounds but in terms of promoting the very changes necessary to make Australia more competitive and more efficient.

At least Mr McCrann has been consistent about that objective of making this economy more efficient and competitive. The Opposition says that it is interested in that as well, but on this policy it takes a decision which is entirely antithetical to achieving that objective. It is not necessary to remind anyone who sat in this House in the years leading up to 1983 of the chaos that existed in the taxation system in this country largely because of the absence of a capital gains tax. Honourable members will remember the telephone book of letters and documents coming from the Taxation Commissioner as he pleaded with the then Government in increasingly desperate terms for it to do something about the haemorrhaging of the revenue which was brought about by the antics of the accountants and taxation lawyers who had a freewheeling ability to make their own rules about taxation laws in this country, largely because of the absence of a capital gains tax.

The response of the then Government, because it did not have the courage to confront the issue of a capital gains tax head on, was to engage in an increasingly frantic attempt to bring in increasingly artificial pieces of legislation to try to make the system work. In the end, it was a futile attempt and it was only when this Government came to office that the taxation system could be made to work, and work fairly for all Australians. Again, on 2 November an article in the Age stated:

The abolition of capital gains tax and its replacement by a short-term gains tax would, apart from providing almost immediate windfall profits for the rich, again open the tax system to abuses by the tax avoidance industry. It would increase the incentive to pour money into negatively geared property and shares instead of productive investment, allowing patient speculators to pick up tax deductions on interest payments and then to reap tax free profit on sale.

I think that is particularly important in the context of the line of questioning which has come from the Opposition today. The Opposition will not face up to the fact that one of the clear consequences of this decision to abolish the capital gains tax will be an increase in the burden of our balance of payments, an increase in the burden of our external debt and the forcing up of interest rates. In other words, the Opposition will not come clean and detail its monetary policy, although it says that our monetary policy is about right. The Opposition will not release its monetary policy, but it says that it will abolish the capital gains tax. That will have the clear and unambiguous effect of forcing up interest rates as people scurry around adjusting their investments and activities in order to take advantage of this taxation measure. Much worse than this, the shadow Treasurer tries to disguise the real effect of the abolition of the capital gains tax.
Dr Hewson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Wentworth will cease interjecting.

—The shadow Treasurer will not own up to the fact that only 2,500 companies are paying it along with one per cent of individual taxpayers, the richest one per cent of taxpayers in the country. Instead, he goes on with this fantastic nonsense that somehow 5.75 million Australians will benefit from the abolition of the capital gains tax. I can tell the House that more than 5.75 million people will be harmed by the abolition of this tax, and a small minority of very privileged Australians will stand to benefit from that. It may well be that the shadow Treasurer believes in the new world, but I rather suspect that the capital of that new world might well be located on Fantasy Island. What this policy reveals more than anything else is the stark difference between where we stand in terms of fairness in policy-whether it be on taxation or welfare-and where the Opposition stands. More and more it is becoming apparent that the real architects of this policy and indeed all the other policies of the Opposition are the rich and powerful in Australia, as typified by Mr Elliott who, increasingly, is becoming the ugly face of an increasingly ugly party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the undertaking of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to debate any economic motion that I put forward, I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Government for its high interest rate policy which is having a disastrous impact on Australian families, farmers and small businesses.

I am grateful to the Prime Minister for indicating during Question Time that he would respond to any motion that I moved in respect of any economic matters or interest rates. Until today, the Prime Minister has not wanted to talk about interest rates one bit, other than when he is careering around the country to see group after group. He assures each individual group that interest rates will fall by the end of next year. Of course, with only about 5 1/2 weeks of this calendar year left we have heard nothing in this House at any time when we have called on the Government to indicate to us just what it would do to provide relief not only to the 42,000 people who have signed this petition but to Australians in general.

Under this Government three things are certain: firstly, high interest rates; secondly, high inflation; and, thirdly, high taxes. The fact is that only today the President of the National Farmers Federation said:

So far, most attention has been on the Opposition's policies. Mr Hawke and Mr Keating have been allowed a considerable degree of latitude, but they also have a responsibility to detail their prescriptions for the next three years.
All right, we have a document which details our prescriptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Well may the Leader of the House react. I am most grateful to the Leader of the House for drawing attention, through his laughter, to this document. I ask whether honourable members are aware that the Leader of the House in recent weeks has been taking out full page advertisements in local newspapers in his electorate. It is the first time in his membership of this Parliament that he has ever done it; and it is because he is running scared before an election has been called. Week after week the newspapers have had to reduce the size of the photograph, otherwise it would occupy the entire page. Having used a machine to reduce the size of the photograph, there he is occupying the full page.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is not in order to falsify facts before the House. I regularly take out advertisements in newspapers in my area on a monthly basis.
—Order! There is no point of order. I ask the Leader of the House to resume his seat.
—I will leave that point.
—The Leader of the Opposition might come back to the matter before the House.

—Advice that we have received indicates that these full page advertisements occurred recently because of the fear that is developing not only on the part of the honourable member but amongst all Western Australian members. There have been these full page advertisements in local papers. Why? Because we have the answers and the people have spoken, indicating that they support the Economic Action Plan brought down by the Opposition. It addresses, as we have explained time and time again in this Parliament, what we will do on fiscal policy, in terms of labour market deregulation, and in setting wages in relation to productivity, thus permitting a steadier monetary policy aimed at getting inflation and interest rates down.

SPEECH.PARA: We have stated the reforms we will make in the great service industries to enable them to deliver their services effectively and efficiently so that the trading industries can produce their goods more efficiently. We have also referred to the whole schedule of privatisation to reduce the size of government. All those matters have been spelt out by us, quite apart from the tax and expenditure program, whereby people can see the real relief to families, those millions and millions of Australians who have been totally forgotten by this Government other than as a means to raise more revenue. Our plan addresses that, but we do not hear about it from the Government, whose record is abysmal.

In recent times, the Government has developed what might be called a policy paralysis. We get no answers to questions about interest rates and there is no movement on micro-economic reform. This is the third term of the Hawke Government. Although I rarely stand here and address members of the press gallery, they will recall that, after the last election, the backgrounding was constant for weeks that the hallmark of the third term of the Hawke Government was to be micro-economic reform. Yet we have heard nothing at all during the term of this Government other than wrangling, because there has been a policy paralysis.

I will go through the five steps, as I see them, of the policy paralysis of the Government. First, instead of policies, we have the politics of the big lie. Secondly, we have the politics of the quick fix. Thirdly, we have the politics of personal abuse. Fourthly, we have the politics of hypocrisy. Fifthly, and above all, we have the politics of confusion. I will substantiate each and every one of those points. First, instead of policies we have the politics of the big lie. Remember it? `By 1990 no child will live in poverty'. I will not dwell on that disgraceful statement. Secondly, `Interest rates will fall'. Thirdly-and what a gem this was-`The pilots dispute is over'. They are just three statements that substantiate the first point-the politics of the big lie.

Secondly, the politics of the quick fix: for substantiation, consider Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, Coronation Hill, and bank interest subsidies. We heard it all today. Those three elements were spelt out in the speech of the President of the National Farmers Federation. Thirdly, the politics of personal abuse: Elliott, Parbo, the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, and even poor old pensioner Bell. I simply say on that point that any person who describes an age pensioner as a `silly old bugger' does not deserve to be Prime Minister. Fourthly, the politics of hypocrisy: What is the substantiation of that? What of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the man responsible for fiscal restraint, for propriety in taxation? The travel allowance--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you lost your place?

—No. I was hesitating as to whether, in the presence of this man, who has been identified as a participant in bottom of the harbour deals, I would bring him in with the Treasurer on shonky tax returns.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I require the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw that absolutely untrue remark.
—The Standing Orders require that members are not allowed to make imputations about other members. In those circumstances, I ask the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw.
—I withdraw `bottom of the harbour' and substitute `bottom of the sandpit'.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the implication is that I have offended against the tax laws of this country. I have not.
—You have.
—I have not. The Leader knows that and he should withdraw unqualifiedly.

—I will withdraw in terms of the requirements of the House and simply say that the Minister is the physical embodiment of what I am saying about hypocrisy. I will go back to the Treasurer rather than the Acting Treasurer. I refer to travel rorts, tax returns-we know all about it. I refer to the exclusion of trade unions from the application of the capital gains tax-the politics of hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, there is the politics of confusion-Blewett and Staples; Howe and Keating on a $5.8 billion tax trade-off; Keating on enterprise unions; and Hawke, if you like. We have Richardson and Kerin on the environment and development. It is a total shambles. On each point-the politics of the big lie, the politics of the quick fix, the politics of personal abuse, the politics of hypocrisy, and the politics of confusion-there is substantiation not by what we dream up but by the words and actions of members of the Government. By those words and actions, they will be judged. Day after day in this country they inflict hardship on those they pose to represent-their own constituency, which is bit by bit deserting them now because they will not attend to the arms of economic policy available to them to get interest rates down.

Why does the Government think that 42,500 people have signed a petition calling on Government members to address elements of policy other than high interest rates to fix this country's ills? It is because they are suffering, and the Government has chosen clinically and coldly to adopt this policy. This has been done in an atmosphere of abuse of J. D. Elliott to hide over the Government's own close association with those cigar smoking billionaires with whom Australians know it associates. Or is the Government devoid of policy? Does it simply allege that it has solved the problems and then walk away from them? It is in fact a disgrace to the movement it poses to represent. This is no more a Labor government than we would pretend to be, and we do not indulge in that pretension. Honourable members opposite will rue the day they put on the clothes of another. If they have any central purpose and ideology, let them spell it out now and relate it to the programs, remedies and policies that will give relief to millions of Australians. To date, the Government has not been able to do so. At root, the policy process in the Government has become nothing but a cruel farce-cruel for Australians and a farce in the enactment.

Ministers are now publicly campaigning against Ministers. Major policy statements are made without consultation, whether it is Keating on enterprise unions or Howe on family policy. Key policy areas are given over to special interest lobbies. Money is dolloped out to provide the quick fix. What about tax relief? The Opposition proposes it; what is the Government's approach? It might dream up a tax policy, but it cannot do it until after Bill Kelty comes back from his Christmas leave. Then, both the tax and wages policies will depend on the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

We come to development in this nation. God help us if we do not expand the manufacturing base of this country; we can imagine what it will be like in the twenty-first century. But no, the Government is not concerned about the national interest; it has its eye on the election. The Government is too scared to fix the date of the election, but it has its eye on it. The Government will bow to any extreme environmentalists, giving them veto powers over mining projects such as Coronation Hill. Clearly, industry and the Australian people are calling for clear guidelines, because the Government is not providing them. So the Business Council of Australia has been moved to bring about a summit on debt, because the Government has abdicated any leadership role in this direction. It has absolutely abdicated, and it is no wonder that there is mounting criticism about the policy processes in the Government.

There is a need for the foreign debt conference, there is the criticism of the accord and there is criticism-other than from the Government-of the capital gains tax. I point to the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Small Business Association, Eric Risstrom, representing small taxpayers and the like. The Government should tell them to come in here and buy its rhetoric on the capital gains tax. It is Government members-masking themselves in clothes-who are supposed to stand for the small man in this country. They should go down to their corner shops-if they can ever get out of their government cars and government aircraft and recognise what is happening in this country today-and ask the proprietors and owners how much of their profits they will have to put back into their businesses to improve them.

If they try it on, they will see what it is like today trying to operate a small business, forced by high interest rates to constrain one's activities. Can they not comprehend that at any normal time a small business is constrained in terms of capital growth? Small businessmen have had to go to the bank time and again in order to expand their business. They forgo profit, year in and year out. They take that profit in a more tangible form and put it back into the business. In the past they hoped that some day they would build up a reasonable amount of capital in their businesses. What the hell was the country on about but giving people the incentive to do just that-to save, to invest, to gain something down the line and have a form of nest egg through a business operation? Businesses are not all the same size as those of the friends of the Government. They are somewhat smaller.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Fosters Liberal Party?
—Order! The Minister will cease interjecting.
—How much money has come from his Western Australian business friends to pay for his ads? What about the stories of corruption now coming out in his State from his peers, colleagues and friends?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Beazley interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will cease interjecting.

—Four hundred million dollars has gone down the drain on the petro-chemical plant alone. What about all the featherbedding he has indulged in? He knew about it at the time? That is why he is advertising now.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Beazley interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence will cease interjecting.

—The reality is that the coalition's plans and policies to replace Labor's capital gains tax with a tax on speculative gains will help millions of farmers, countless small business people, individuals contributing to superannuation funds and individuals with small investments. The Government does not want to know about them.
—What about the worker?
—`What about the worker?', the honourable member for McMillan asks. He is in favour of the capital gains tax, is he?
—Yes.

—Good. I am glad I got that answer. That will be reported in the honourable member's electorate and in the local paper too. Every small business person in the honourable member's electorate will be alerted to the reality that the honourable member wants to wipe out his endeavours. The Opposition happens to be concerned about the plight of small businesses. That is why we will move an amendment-and I can say very little about legislation that is to come before the House-to the Government's legislation to bring forward company tax payments. All companies with a tax liability over $20,000 will be required to pay 85 per cent of their tax within 15 days. The Opposition's amendment will raise this threshold to a taxable income of $200,000. Moreover, we will review this legislation when in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether it is the economic package revolving around fiscal policy, wages policy, monetary policy, significant structural reforms, privatisation or the micro-economic arena that we have totally addressed in our Economic Action Plan, or whether it is the tax relief to families-recognising those whom the Government would never do anything for other than to call on them to pay more-the Opposition has a program, a blueprint and a schedule that will not only get inflation down but also get interest rates down. Our Economic Action Plan offers the only hope for a sustainable lowering of interest rates. The Government has offered nothing-just more of the same, more high interest rates.

The Opposition has given the Government the opportunity to explain and it has rejected that opportunity altogether. Because of the Government's constant rejection of our calls to explain to the nation what it will do to relieve Australians and rebuild this country, it is not surprising that the President of the National Farmers Federation said today:
I'm concerned that they're-
that is, the Government-
running out of steam-becoming cynical and splintered.

Mr Speaker, you will recall that at Question Time I read out half a dozen of the statements that were made: the adhockery that is dangerous; the actions that were tremendously worrying to industry, that the NFF perceived actions by the Government as deplorable, that it felt that the Government should spell out its plans and that it believed that all the discussion was on the Opposition's policies and that no prescriptions were coming from the Government. I asked the Prime Minister to indicate which of those descriptions were laudable and, of course, with very wordy evidence, he showed he could not so do. The reality is that not only has the Government lost the confidence of so many Australians today, but also it has lost the confidence of organisations which would normally-because most Australians are fairly polite-welcome the Prime Minister and hold back from public dissemination the thrust of their major criticisms. They normally put their views privately and constructively. Not today. This report by John Allwright, the President of the National Farmers Federation, is a damning indictment of this Government. And so it ought to be. It complements the 42,000 signatories to the petition which called on the Government to do something about interest rates. The Government has shown itself to be chronically incapable of so doing because it has no policies or direction and soon it will have no support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to reply to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and I hope I will be given the opportunity to be heard on this matter. First of all, I will go directly to the three points that the Leader of the Opposition made. He said that three things are certain under this Government. I will list them and then ask the House and the people of this country to contrast the achievements of this Government in respect of each of those issues with the achievements of the Opposition. The first was interest rates; the second, inflation; and the third, taxes. I will look at them in turn.

SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated in answer to a question in this place, under this Government, the 90- day bill rate is currently at 18 per cent. In April 1982 it reached 22 per cent under the coalition Government. This Government has not approached the level of interest rates reached during that Government's period in office. Secondly, the coalition Government walked out of office at a time of double digit inflation. It achieved what no other government in history had ever achieved-that is, simultaneous double digit inflation and unemployment. The inflation rate under the coalition Government was over 11 per cent. At no point has this Government begun to approach that level of inflation.

Taxes were the third point. What did the coalition Government do in relation to taxes? When it walked out of office, the top rate was 60c in the dollar and the lowest rate was 30c in the dollar. That was the coalition Government's achievement in the area of taxes. The top rate was 60c for one very simple reason. Because of its philosophical and ideological commitment to the privileged, it refused steadfastly to ensure that those people in this country with the greatest capacity to pay tax and make a contribution to the public revenue were required to do so.

The most damning indictment of the legacy that we inherited from the coalition Government was provided by two people who were in no way associated with the Australian Labor Party. Firstly, I refer to the coalition Government's own royal commissioner. The Opposition will recall the immortal words of Royal Commissioner Costigan who, when referring to the previous five years-which were, conveniently, 1976 to 1981, the period of the coalition Government's stewardship-said that the fastest growing industry in this country was the tax avoidance industry. The second damning indictment came from Professor Russell Mathews of the Australian National University. His words were probably the most damning indictment from any economist ever delivered upon any government in this country. He said, `It has become increasingly a matter of choice for the wealthy as to whether they pay their tax'. There you have it. Those opposite have the audacity to stand up here and talk about tax when, at the end of their stewardship, they had rates of 60c in the dollar, their own Royal Commissioner was saying that they had created the fastest growing industry in the country-the tax avoidance industry-and Professor Russell Mathews was saying of their administration and stewardship that it had become increasingly a matter of choice whether the wealthy paid their taxes. I doubt whether there has ever been a more damning independent indictment of a government than that made by the Opposition's own Royal Commissioner and by Professor Russell Mathews. The reason that the top rate of taxes was 60c in the dollar was precisely that those opposite refused to draw from those areas in the community with the greatest capacity to pay the contributions which they should have made.

In terms of interest, inflation and taxes, this Government has not come close to the records achieved by those opposite. What was the meaning of that for this society? I use that as a basis to accept the challenge to spell out what it is that we believe. I accept that challenge gladly. I do it in the context of the achievement of those opposite. I do so not simply to recite history but precisely because the Opposition promised, in its Economic Action Plan, a return to the prescriptions, the philosophy and the ideology of the past. Let me tell the House what this meant for the people of Australia as they laboured under the coalition's miserable philosophy, which was committed to the sustenance of the privileged and the ignorance of those in need.

Those opposite talk about children. Let me go to the most important factor which determines a child's capacity-not only in his childhood but for the rest of his career-to prosper and grow and to make a contribution, not only for himself but also for his society; that is, education. Let us look at the achievement of honourable members opposite in their seven years in office. What was the increase in the participation rate in education in this country during their seven years? As we look around the children here in the gallery and others in the country, we ask: what did those opposite do to ensure that there would be an increasing opportunity for the kids of this country to stay on in the education system? Answer: in their seven years, the participation rate increased from 34 per cent to 36 per cent-a miserable increase of 2 per cent. Those opposite walked out of office leaving Australia with virtually the worst participation rate of any developed country. If those opposite want an indictment of their ideology and their time in government, it is this: they wilfully denied themselves revenue because they allowed the rich to escape their duty to pay tax and, in denying themselves that revenue, they did not have it to spend on expanding the educational opportunity for our kids.

I have been asked to spell out what we believe and what we are about. I spell it out precisely, as I did in 1983, when I said, `That is not good enough for this country'. If there is one damning indictment of any government and of any society it is that a government denies itself revenue by allowing the rich not to pay their taxes and, in so doing, it does not expend money on education for kids. I said, `We will change it'. Have we changed it? We certainly have. The 2 per cent increase in the participation rate during the previous Government's seven years in office-it left it at 36 per cent in 1982-has been changed by a government which said, `We will ensure that those with a capacity to pay, pay'.

We have now created an equitable system. We have created a system in which now the wealthy pay. We have used that money to increase the education allowances to the low income and middle income families of Australia. What has been the result? There has not been a 2 per cent increase in participation rates, as occurred during the seven years of conservative government, which propped up the rich and the privileged; under this Labor Government the participation rates have moved from 36 per cent to 60 per cent. They are moving up to the point that we promised.

We have been asked what we believe in. We do not utter rhetoric; we deliver on the promises that we have made. We said that we would create a society in which it is not the wealth of the parent which determines whether the kid will stay in the education system; it will be the talents and the desire of the kid to stay on in the education system. We now have the situation where the kids from the poorer and the middle income suburbs are, as are the kids from the rich suburbs, staying on in the school system. The kids of the rich have every right to be educated but they have no greater right than the kids from the low and middle income families.

The face of this society is being changed. We are now building up a population in which all the talent of the young children of this great country is being drawn not from the exclusive suburbs alone but from every suburb. The kids who have the talent and the desire to stay on in the education system are staying in it. And that has not happened by accident; it has happened because we have more than doubled the secondary education allowance that goes to the kids.

The No. 1 priority of those opposite was, as Costigan and Mathews have said, to protect the rich and the privileged: do not get them to pay their revenue. So the previous Government did not have the money to spend on education. We said, `The rich and the privileged will pay their share. We won't keep a top tax rate of 60c in the dollar and the lowest rate at 30c. Because we make everyone in the community with the capacity to pay, pay, we will have a fair, reasonable and economically efficient tax system and out of that efficient tax system we will then target expenditures in a way that economic justice and social decency become the characteristics of the Australian society'.

If there is one issue by which a society shall be judged as to whether it is decent and as to whether it is efficient in the allocation of its resources, it is whether it will ensure that those with a capacity to pay, pay and that that revenue so derived is then expended on ensuring that the talents of the kids of the country are developed in a way which will fulfil them personally and which will enable them to make a contribution to their country. That is the test by which any society will be properly judged. And by that test, those opposite were an abject failure.

If it were only a history lesson I was delivering, it would be bad enough but, unfortunately, the tragedy is that those opposite have learned nothing. They have said that they will return to that prescription of the past. If people want to understand the hypocrisy, if they want to understand what determines the formation of conservative economic policy in this country, they should read what the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), said before he was rolled by his Foster parent. When he came into the Parliament earlier, he was asked what was his view about a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax. What was his answer? Professor Hewson's answer was very simple: `I'd go for near uniform taxation of all forms of income'. In other words, the pure, clear view and position of economist Hewson, before he was rolled by his Foster parent and those who determine the priorities of liberalism and the National Party in this country, was that we should have a capital gains tax. But he was rolled.

We do not expect anything from the Leader of the Opposition because he knows nothing about economics and he cares nothing about social decency. But at least we expect a professor of economics, who has said that there should be a capital gains tax, to tell the conservative parties of this country, when he has the opportunity to do so as the shadow Treasurer, that the right thing to do is to retain the capital gains tax. But, as I say, he was rolled by the Foster parent of the Liberal Party. Of course, therefore, when I analyse what has happened in the previous seven years when this mob were in government, when they established what their credo was, what their policies would be, what their outcomes were, all that is not history but an analysis and a certain prescription of the abject misery and the perversion of priorities that would mark this country if the Australian people were to go back to them.

I also noticed that the Leader of the Opposition, in his speech, had the temerity to refer to the environment as though this Government was captive of the environment movement. Let me make a point that I have made in this place before. I assert-and I have done so consistently-that those who attempt to present our position in terms of it being development or environment entirely misrepresent that position. The fact is that one can have and should have both. One can have development. We have had economic growth under this Government twice as fast as under the previous Government and a rate of employment growth five times as fast. At the same time, we have had the World Heritage Bureau say that no country has done more to advance World Heritage values than Australia. One can have both. One can have decency and one can have economic rationality in this country but one cannot have it with the mob opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point I would make is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did not utter the words `interest rate' in 20 minutes. His performance was an embarrassment to his own side and, quite frankly, it was an embarrassment to me. Sitting where I was, I was astounded. The President of the National Farmers Federation might be worried about adhockery in the Government, but let me say that I am worried about the relevance of the Prime Minister. He is an anacronism. I am also worried about his stability. His speech was the rhetoric of the 1970s, not answers to the problems of the 1990s, and he knows it. He is gone. He should see the polling on his seat. He is finished. He should go and talk to the pharmacists, do a bit of doorknocking and see what the mothers at the supermarket say about him. He should think about it when they buy mince instead of steak because they have to pay the mortgage. The Prime Minister has had it. If he has to buy one page advertisements, then he had better go and buy the newspaper because he has no hope. He is gone, finished, wound up.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Lavarch interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —As for the honourable member for Fisher, he has no hope-none whatsoever. I cannot believe that this Government has fallen so far so fast. This Parliament has the opportunity to debate something of significance to the Australian people, that is, the impact of the Government's policies on people. This is not a clinical economic debate; the Government's interest rates are paid by people. It is their money, which they do not have a lot of these days. They have the choice of paying the Government's interest rates on their mortgages or spending it on food for their kids. And this is the sort of performance we get from Government members. They are a disgrace. The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) is the only bloke in the building who actually bulk bills his colleagues. What sort of person is he? What sort of professional is he?

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Prime Minister raised a number of issues, let us address them. He was talking about this Government's `proud record of development'. Sitting right behind him, glowering over his shoulder, was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). We all know what the Minister thinks about the Prime Minister's attitude. Let us talk a little about Coronation Hill. Let us examine the Coronation Hill decision of this Government; this Government that has such a proud record. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) forecast that this country will have a current account deficit of $18.5 billion this year. That is even bigger than last year. It will put more pressure on interest rates, not down but up. Let me say that the $18.5 billion forecast will be wrong; it will be considerably more. In that context, a consortium led by one of Australia's great companies put up a proposal to redevelop an existing mine. That mine was called Coronation Hill. Every honourable member opposite has a copy of the environmental impact study. None of them have read it, otherwise they would not have put up with the rubbish that passed for a decision by the Cabinet.

Let us have a look at Coronation Hill. It is a mine. It was mined for uranium in the 1960s and it was rediscovered for palladium and platinum. So instead of importing $40m worth of platinum to go in car exhausts, we could export it. Do honourable members opposite know anything about the current account deficit? Do they know anything about the economic position of this country? No, they do not. All they have is empty rhetoric. All they can do is sit in here and rabbit on. They would be better off out there in their offices ringing up some constituents. They might get a vote, and they need a few of them.

Let us talk about something a bit more significant than this ratbag over here. Let us talk about the state of this economy and go back to Coronation Hill. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd put up a proposal to develop that mine for palladium and platinum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gold.

—No gold, and the honourable member knows it is no gold. That is El Sherana. The honourable member is totally ignorant. He knows nothing about the issue at all. That mine is worth between $500m and $700m and the Government spent $12m doing the environmental impact study. The Cabinet met and spent an hour and a half talking on the telephone to the conservation movement, because that is the Prime Minister's corporate philosophy. He thinks that if he does a deal with the conservation movement all the green vote will arrive en masse. It does not work like that. In the face of that economic position-$18.5 billion worth of current account deficit and more pressure on interest rates-this Government declined approval to develop Coronation Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell honourable members what the significance of that is. If we are to address that $18.5 billion deficit-and it will be larger than that-we have to discover and develop a Coronation Hill mine every 14 days. We have no hope of doing that. When we discover one, this Government, for blatantly political reasons, in the craven pursuit of votes, vetoes it. Worse, in one of the most prospective mineral provinces in the world, by the Government's own estimates with a value of between $7 billion and $15 billion, what does it do? It sterilises the area for further exploration. It is not even prepared to go along with the proposal that one looks at each project item by item.

Where is this Government's concern for the future of our economy? This Government's commitment to the environment is as deep as a ballot box, and everybody knows it. That is the sort of ad hoc decision-making that John Allwright and the National Farmers Federation are complaining about. It is followed through by decisions like Kodak, decisions that the Treasurer cannot stomach and that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is absolutely repulsed by. But because the Prime Minister thinks that sort of decision-making will get him re-elected, this Government is spending the taxpayers' money going down that track.

If one has a look at what the Government does to small business, the real engine room of our economy, one understands why it is arrogant and out of touch. This is the Government that requires 85 per cent of company tax to be paid within 15 days. This same Government has $36m to subsidise Kodak. This same Government is prepared to spend hundreds of millions of dollars subsidising the airlines. In fact, we know that we are subsidising only one airline-Sir Peter Abeles's Ansett. We know exactly what the priorities of this Government are.

As I have said, the comments of the Prime Minister in this place were just the rhetoric of the 1970s. There was not one policy for the 1990s, not one answer for Australia's problems. Where is his equivalent of this? What document did he bring into this place? Where are his answers? What is the Government's response, other than more of the same? As I have said, what we are talking about today is an issue that relates to people. It is an issue that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) knows is a people issue. That is why he is spending money probably donated by the corporate sector-the big end of town-on taking out one page advertisements in the newspapers to promote himself. He is supposed to hold a safe Labor seat and this is what is being done. One page advertisements are being taken out in the newspapers when the election is not going to be held. He is running scared, just like every back bench member of this Government. They know they are gone, and they are gone a million.

This Government is also prepared to spend vast amounts of the taxpayers' money trying to get itself re-elected. What about the $30,000 stamp allowance Government members gave themselves? What is that being used for? How many Government members are looking after their marginal seats?
Mr Pratt interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Adelaide is not assisting the Leader of the National Party. I suggest that he stop interjecting across the chamber. Members on my right will also assist the Chair and the Leader of the National Party if they stop interjecting.

—Thirty thousand dollars worth of stamps was allocated for Labor seat holders-not one member on this side of the House has used it-and $4 for pensioners. There are the Government's priorities. Let us get serious for a moment. Instead of those opposite carrying on like hyenas or galahs, let us talk about an issue that relates out in the community. If the Government was really doing its job it would be expressing some concern about the impact of interest rates on families. It is true that in this country the second mortgage has replaced the first child. What has happened under Treasurer Keating's interest rate regime is that women who want to be mothers are out in the workplace trying to put a roof over the family's head and not having children. That is why we get the majority of our population increase from migration and not native born Australian kids. The sanctimonious, hypocritical criticism of the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) will not earn him one vote. You are gone, my friend; absolutely gone. I would ring up and find out what the superannuation payout is because the honourable member is irrelevant. He does not know what the issues are out there in the community and he is going to be swept aside. What those opposite should really be talking about is the pressure that the Treasurer's and the Government's policies are putting on families.

SPEECH.PARA: In this place we cannot say that the Prime Minister has lied, and of course I would not say that, but I would say that the majority of Australians believe that he has. We have only to look at the history of this Government and its spokesmen over seven long years of deceit to see exactly how callously they treated the Australian people. Let us go back a bit to 1984. It was stated:
. . . because inflation is coming down-
that is a joke, because it is going up-
and inflationary expectations are down, interest rates will come down too.
That was a statement made by Mr Hawke in an interview with John Laws on 2UE on 5 November 1984. The next quote is a classic:
We've ploughed the fields and sown the seeds. In the very near future we will harvest the crop.

The reference was to the crop of lower interest rates. The Government must have had a drought, because it did not arrive. Let us go on a bit further to 1985. This is how callously this Government treats the Australian people. It gets an attack of low interest rate predictions every time there is an election coming on, you realise, Mr Deputy Speaker. In 1985 it was stated:

. . . the very low deficit as announced by the Treasurer last night. . . will have the consequential effect of lowering pressure on the public sector borrowing requirements, and that, of course, is good news with regard to general interest rates and that means it is good news for housing interest rates also.

What happened? Where are the low housing interest rates? Of course the Government knew exactly what was going on when it made these statements. Nothing has changed. Let us go through to 1987. It was stated:

The Government's expectations that interest rates can begin to fall this year are based on a thorough and continuous assessment of all the factors which go to make up the total macro-economic picture.

This is the Prime Minister relying on his not inconsiderable competence, or was it advice? Whatever basis that statement was made on was totally wrong, but of course that was in 1987. The Treasurer, the great economic guru of the Australian Labor Party, in an election campaign, in election mode, stated:

The re-election of the Government will be an enormous fillip to confidence. . . It will clear the decks for further interest rate declines. As those interest rates come down, they will grease the tracks to higher investment.
That statement was made by the Treasurer three weeks before the 1987 election. Holy cow! It was further stated:
Interest rates, as you know and appreciate, are falling and will continue to fall and will be reflected in falls in mortgage rates before the end of 1987.

That statement was made by the Prime Minister, and we are still waiting. In 1989 there is the same old story from the Government. No matter who it is, whether it is the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, or his campaign director, it is the same old story, it has not changed. It was stated:
There is no reason why interest rates should rise.

That statement was made by the Prime Minister in April 1989. He was as wrong then as he was in 1984. The Prime Minister has never told the truth to the Australian people about interest rates and he is not telling the truth now. The fact of the matter is that this Government has no policies, no answers and does not know where it is going. Its entire emphasis is a political strategy. We have seen the Prime Minister in here today frothing at the mouth and carrying on. We have seen him cry over drugs, we have seen him cry over Israel, and we have seen him cry over Tiananmen Square. I ask: When are we going to see this Prime Minister shed a tear for the hurt and damage that he and his Government are inflicting on Australian families?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perhaps necessary to remind the House why we are having this extraordinary debate. It is because the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said that he challenged the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to have a debate on economic policy and particularly on interest rates. I had thought as the debate went on that maybe it had more to do with some State elections occurring in South Australia and Queensland, but if that is the case I find it particularly extraordinary that the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt) would stumble into this particular debate because, after all, it is the National Party in Queensland that is staring defeat in the face. It is his own Party on today's polling which suggests that it has been reduced to the support of some 19 per cent of the people of Queensland. I would have thought that the Leader of the National Party may have been well advised to hang his head in shame, or at least try to engineer some semi-plausible excuses why the National Party is doing so appallingly in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Leader of the Opposition is genuinely interested in participating in the economic debate of this country, then it is curious that he is not prepared to engage in the practice of most leaders of the Opposition; that is, to hold regular press conferences. He has not had a press conference since the launch of the Opposition's Economic Action Plan. He has not been allowed by his minders to have a press conference or to allow the journalists of the press gallery to have a full ranging scrutiny and cross-examination of what it is the Liberal Party leader and his Party really stand for. As much as I listened to him today, as carefully as I could-after all, this was a debate he requested, a debate in which he wanted to engage the Prime Minister, he said, in substantive matters of economic policy-I did not hear anything of substance which the Leader of the Opposition advanced which might help us to resolve the problems confronting this country. Therefore, in order to get the debate back onto some kind of even keel, on behalf of the Government it is my intention to amend the motion moved by the Opposition. I therefore move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`this House

(1) notes the widespread public condemnation of the Opposition's proposal to abolish the capital gains tax and replace it with a so-called speculative gains tax, as demonstrated by the attached representative example of newspaper commentary;

(2) expresses its concern that the abolition of the capital gains tax would stimulate the flow of investment away from productive activity towards non-productive activity, thereby causing Australia's balance of payments deficit and external debt to worsen, leading to higher interest rates and crippling Australian families, farmers and small businesses;

(3) notes the widespread concern that the abolition of the capital gains tax would lead to a resumption of the tax avoidance practices that occurred on a massive scale during the administration of the previous coalition Government;
(4) notes that such practices harm the efforts of the Australian nation to surmount its external challenge, thereby also contributing to higher interest rates;

(5) notes the fundamental inconsistency in the Opposition's professed concern about the impact of interest rates on families, farmers and small business and its deleterious proposal to abandon the capital gains tax; and
(6) calls on the coalition parties in the national interest to support the present arrangements for the taxation of capital gains.'

It is important to move that amendment because we need to make it quite clear what we are talking about. The Opposition has said that it is opposed to our current monetary policy and that it has a policy of its own. So I decided to dig up the Opposition's Economic Action Plan to discover what the Opposition's policy is in relation to monetary policy. It states:
The next Coalition Government will conduct monetary policy with the medium-term objective of reducing and eventually eliminating inflation.
It goes on to state:

A monetary policy pursued steadily over the medium term, in conjunction with our industrial relations, fiscal and structural policies, provides the only means of reducing inflation and hence interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —What claptrap!

—I, like the honourable member for Kingston, find that an extraordinarily baffling set of policies. When we look at the document we see that there is absolutely no substantive connection between the Opposition's policy and its objectives. The Opposition has the medium term objective of reducing interest rates and eliminating inflation but, when we try to discover how the Opposition will eliminate inflation, we find that it has some mystical link with its policy on industrial relations. So I thought I would go to the Opposition's industrial relations policy in the hope that I would find the answer to the mysterious secret as to how it will operate its monetary policy in the interests of reducing inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition states that its aims are to ensure a much closer link between wages and productivity; to introduce incentive and reward for effort, thus encouraging higher productivity; and to achieve lower labour costs at least in line with those of our partners. I guess that they are laudable objectives. They are objectives that the Government could agree with. Indeed, the objectives of higher productivity and lower labour costs in line with our trading partners are already the objectives being successfully pursued by the Government. But in our policy it is quite clear how we get to the objective of wages based on productivity and lower labour costs through a set of clear policy arrangements. In the first place we have the accord, which has ensured that we are able to pursue, with the agreement of the trade union movement, sensible changes to industry policy and wage restraint. After all, we have to have wage restraint if we are to have any chance of ensuring that wage increases relate in any way to productivity.

But when we look at the Opposition's policy we see that there is no policy of wage restraint and no mechanism to ensure wage restraint; there is just this lofty objective of ensuring that wages policy will be pursued in such a way that wage increases relate to productivity. What is the mechanism by which the Opposition will ensure that? It says that it will downgrade the influence of the Industrial Relations Commission-the only vehicle, the only instrument, the only institution in the Commonwealth armoury to deal with the question of wages policy. The Opposition wants to abandon the Industrial Relations Commission in favour of an entirely decentralised system of setting wages. At the same time it thinks it can hold down wage increases and ensure that any wage increases relate to productivity. One does not have to be very clever to realise that that will not work. There is no mechanism by which we can ensure that negotiations held enterprise by enterprise will comply with some fanciful policy objective of someone in Canberra who says, `You are not allowed to have a wage increase unless it is matched by a productivity increase'. Of course, I leave aside what productivity we are measuring and how we are measuring it, in relation to either the enterprise or the economy as a whole.

When we work all that out, when we realise that there is no means of achieving the Opposition's wages policy objective, we come back to this big hole in the Opposition's monetary policy itself. The Opposition is concerned to deal with the central question of inflation, as we are. The Opposition has no industrial relations policy, no way of containing wages and no way of preventing a wage breakout. We realise then that inevitably we are driven to only one possible conclusion-that is, that the Opposition will rely on monetary policy alone in order to deal both with inflation and with wages policy.

What does that mean in the end? It can only mean what it has always meant under Liberal policy in operation in the past: whenever inflation gets a bit of a run on, whenever wages get a bit of a run on, or when they happen together, the one recourse the Opposition has is to jack up interest rates to extremely high levels in order to contain demand, put downward pressure on wages and downward pressure on inflation.

In the end this whole debate has a note of farce about it. The Opposition comes in here and says that it is primarily concerned about interest rates. It waves around its vacuous policy and says, `Where is your answer to high interest rates? Here is ours'. But when we look carefully at what the Opposition's policy actually says we see that it is a prescription for higher interest rates, not lower interest rates. It is not a prescription for steadier monetary policy, unless it is steadier monetary policy at a very much higher level. I think members of the Opposition are really talking about interest rates at around 25 per cent, necessary to contain simultaneously inflation and wages. They would have absolutely no other mechanism for dealing with those problems.

It is not as though these are new issues for the Liberal Party or for Australia. At various times in our history we have had to deal with the coincidence of inflation and high wages growth. Of course, the Opposition has actually had some practical experience of what to do about it. But when we look back at what it did at the time we see that it had only one alternative; it had only one policy prescription-a sort of scorched earth policy of high interest rates, battering the economy into the ground with devastating consequences for the ordinary working men and women of Australia.

The whole of the Opposition's rhetoric is conjured up in terms of the impacts on small businesses and families as a result of the current stance of monetary policy. The people opposite are the ones who ought to know; they are the recession experts. This is one area of policy that they managed to perfect during their years in government. They know about recessions but what they do not understand, because it never actually touches them or any of the people they talk to, is the devastation that is wrought on ordinary Australian families as a result of the kinds of recessions which they have visited upon Australia in the past and which, if they ever got a chance, they would visit on us again.

What about the 600,000 families whose breadwinners were thrown out of work as a result of the policies of the jokers opposite when they were in office? They were all families too. They were the families who had their incomes reduced from a reasonable level, on a reasonable wage, presumably, to the level of welfare. Do we hear any compassion or concern for the interests of Australian families who, under the Opposition's policies, would once again be thrown out of work and onto the dole queues and forced to rely, at least for nine months, on welfare benefits, after which the Opposition says they should get nothing at all or, alternatively, some grudging handout which would come in the form of a special benefit? What about the number of small businesses which would go bankrupt under a policy of high interest rates, which would be the only mechanism which the jokers opposite would have to pursue in trying to run any economic policy at all?

Let me return to this question of the capital gains tax. As obscure as it might be to the question of interest rates, it is becoming increasingly clear that this is centrally involved in the management of economic policy, not just in terms of fiscal policy, the amount of revenue that one might raise from the tax itself and the extent to which its operation ensures compliance with the rest of the taxation system, but in terms of what happens, in the absence of a capital gains tax, in the context of the investment decisions of individuals as they scurry around trying to find ways in which they can distort their investments in a way which will ensure they get a stream of capital rather than a stream of income which then comes to them in a tax free form. It is a massive dislocation of the investment behaviour of people who in this country are so vital in terms of getting the right investments to fortify Australian industry to enable it to compete with the rest of the world. Once again we would see a flight of funds, not into the productive investments of industry, whether it is agriculture, manufacturing or the services industries, but into speculative areas where people know they can pick up a quick capital gain and pocket the money in a tax free form. That is why this debate has a certain air of nonsense about it. The Opposition is simply not interested in having a serious debate. We, of course, are. We will meet members of the Opposition on any other occasion. Because of their appalling performance on this occasion, I move:
That the question be now put.

as demonstrated by the attached representative example of newspaper commentary . . .

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. If the amendment that is proposed is out of order, then it should be withdrawn and amended by the mover. It cannot be amended from the Chair.
