DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SERUM LABORATORIES (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Act 1961 to convert the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) to a public company, called the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Ltd. It will also remove a variety of statutory controls which inhibit CSL's commercial operations. The Minister responsible for CSL will retain strategic oversight of the new company in line with the guidelines for the reform of government business enterprises (GBEs). The Bill is a major step in implementing the reform package for CSL announced on 16 August 1989 and is part of the Government's comprehensive program to improve the performance of government business enterprises.

CSL has a long history of achievements in serving the Australian community. CSL was established in 1916, following World War I, as an arm of the Quarantine Service, so that Australia could be self-sufficient in vaccines and sera in times of war and peace. In 1923 CSL was one of the four laboratories world wide to produce insulin and in 1944 CSL enabled Australia to be the first country to supply penicillin to its civilian population. In 1952 CSL commenced the fractionation of serum, provided by voluntary blood donors and collected by the Red Cross, into life saving blood products, a function which it continues to perform today. CSL has developed anti-sera and anti-venoms against specific Australian pests and diseases, the most recent being the funnel-web spider anti-venom in 1988. CSL is the only manufacturer of human vaccines in Australia and one of only two producers of biological veterinary products.

When CSL became a statutory authority in 1961 its charter focused on the performance of national interest functions, in particular the manufacture of prescribed biological pharmaceutical products and serum fractionation. Provision was also made at that time, however, for limited commercial operations using any excess manufacturing capability. With support from successive Ministers, CSL has since evolved into a primarily commercial organisation. Significant changes to the CSL Act between 1980 and 1985 removed the restriction limiting CSL to manufacturing solely biological products and placed CSL's operation on a commercial profit making basis, whilst continuing to perform some national interest activities for the Commonwealth under a reimbursement arrangement. These changes to the Act also allowed the establishment of subsidiaries, joint ventures and partnerships.

CSL now markets a wide range of prescribed human pharmaceuticals and veterinary products both in Australia and overseas. CSL currently employs over 1,200 staff and has over 2,000 product lines. As such CSL is the largest pharmaceutical company in Australia, and represents a unique pharmaceutical manufacturing capability. Indeed, since 1980-81 CSL's sales revenue has increased from $33m to $127m in 1988-89, and pre-tax profits have increased from $1.5m to $11.5m over the same period. Not only does CSL pay a 40 per cent dividend on its post-tax profit to the Commonwealth but it is subject to State payroll and land taxes as well as the corporate tax. CSL's achievements are significant given the small size of the Australian market.

In its recent endeavours to increase sales CSL has been a winner of several export awards. Indeed, with the globalisation of the pharmaceutical industry CSL's future must lie with the development of new products and new markets, not just within Australia but overseas. This will be achieved not only through CSL's own research activities but also through the continued development of licensing arrangements and joint ventures to access new technology. CSL can succeed in these areas only if it is allowed to operate as a truly commercial enterprise that can respond quickly in the marketplace free from day to day government regulatory controls.

The reform package is therefore a further significant step in the continued development of CSL. The objective is to establish it as an efficient and commercially focused organisation able to compete profitably and effectively with the private sector in the domestic and international marketplace. The reform package will thus achieve the Government's aims of, firstly, fostering a more commercial focus for CSL and, secondly, retaining a key manufacturing capability in Australia without the need for any subsidies from the Commonwealth. This Bill is a major step in implementing this reform.

There are a number of important elements of the CSL reform package. Firstly, there will be new planning and accountability mechanisms for CSL. These will include the provision by CSL of a three-year corporate plan which will define the company's goals, financial targets and strategies to achieve those goals. Financial targets will be set and CSL will report annually giving an account of its performance against goals. CSL's memorandum and articles of association will be registered, as with any public company, with the National Companies and Securities Commission. The Minister responsible for CSL will exercise control, on behalf of the Commonwealth as the shareholder, in a similar manner to shareholders in any other company. The proposed memorandum and articles of association will provide for the Minister responsible to have the power to appoint and dismiss the CSL board of directors. Also the Minister responsible for CSL will be able to issue guidelines to the board.

In addition, as a public company, CSL will be required to operate in accordance with the Companies Code. This will provide for the protection of the interests of the Commonwealth through its rights as a shareholder of the company. Under the Companies Code the company directors have specific responsibilities to shareholders as well as other defined obligations. There will also be revised remuneration arrangements for the Managing Director. CSL's important community service function or serum fractionation will be made more efficient and accountable through use of a formal contractual arrangement with the Commonwealth. The provision for rights to be attached to shares included in a class of shares will also protect the Commonwealth's interests in relation to the land on which CSL is located.

CSL will be expected to continue to comply with Government wages and industrial relations policies, in particular with those guidelines developed specifically for government business enterprises in March 1989. It is intended that CSL start operating as a public company limited by shares and incorporated in the Australian Capital Territory by 31 March 1990. The arrangements proposed for CSL are essentially the same as those already applying to other GBE's such as Australian Airlines Ltd, Australian National Line and most recently the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation.

I will now summarise the key elements of the Bill. The Bill provides for the conversion of CSL, from its current statutory authority status, to a public company under the Companies Act. The Bill comes into effect in several stages, on royal assent and through two proclamations. This is to facilitate the consolidation of the asset base, creation of capital structure, and repeal of sections of the CSL Act 1961 which are no longer required. This also allows for the development of an appropriate balance sheet, financial performance indicators and strategic plan to enable the Minister responsible for CSL to undertake strategic oversight of the company.

As the legislation will come into effect in several stages the Bill ensures the continuity of CSL as a legal entity during this transition in order to preserve all contracts, agreements and the relationship of CSL with its subsidiary companies.

The Bill ensures continuity of employment and staff conditions during the transition. Each staff member of CSL will become an employee of the company on the same terms and conditions as applied to his or her employment by the statutory authority. This includes the preservation of accumulated entitlements such as long service, recreation and sick leave. The existing provisions covering superannuation will be maintained for staff who are members of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. Those staff who have mobility rights under part IV of the Public Service Act 1922 will retain those rights. The Bill also ensures that CSL's taxation position and other assets and liabilities are unchanged upon conversion in recognition of the fact that there has been no change in the beneficial ownership by the Commonwealth.

On the matter of assets, the Bill provides for CSL's asset base to be consolidated before the assets are converted into share capital and fully paid up shares are issued to the Commonwealth. The consolidation of assets entails the transfer to CSL of the remaining land and buildings which had remained vested in the Commonwealth. These `transferring assets' have been employed by CSL since its establishment in 1916 but were not transferred to CSL at the time it became a statutory authority in 1961. In relation to the `transferring assets', the Bill contains specific provisions which ensure that, for taxation purposes, CSL is treated as if it had acquired these assets at the time they were acquired by the Commonwealth.

Provision has been made in the Bill for the issued shares to be divided into classes to which rights can be attached. This allows for the Commonwealth to have rights in relation to the existing serum fractionation operation, which is an important community service operation and will not become part of CSL's fully commercial operations. This provision also allows for the Commonwealth to have rights in relation to the sale of the land at CSL. The Bill then provides for the establishment of CSL as a company through the registration of the memorandum and articles of association for CSL with the National Companies and Securities Commission.

The Bill removes controls, such as the requirement for the Treasurer's approval for individual borrowing arrangements, and investment and banking arrangements. However, CSL will remain subject to the Loan Council global borrowing limits and will be liable for the Commonwealth borrowing levy on any borrowings. It will, however, forgo all forms of Government guarantee and will not be able to claim protection from the shield of the crown. The Bill also contains consequential amendments to other Acts to ensure that the new company remains subject to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987, and exempt from the Freedom of Information Act 1982. The schedule to the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) 1930, which identifies those Commonwealth bodies which are not exempt from sales tax, will be amended to delete reference to CSL. Nonetheless, as a company, CSL will continue to pay sales tax.

The Bill does not involve additional expenditure by the Commonwealth or additional revenue to the Commonwealth; nor does it involve any State and Territory taxes on the transfer of assets in recognition of the fact that there has been no change in the Commonwealth's beneficial ownership.

The Bill implements a further stage of the Government's program of micro-economic reform by removing another Government business enterprise from the restrictions of day-to-day regulatory control, whilst ensuring that strategic oversight of performance and efficiency is maintained. It is also a further step in the Government's efforts to encourage value-added manufacture within Australia without the requirement for underpinning by the Commonwealth. At the same time it recognises CSL's significant contribution to the Australian community in the past and present. I commend the Bill to the House. I now present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NORTHSIDE DEVELOPMENT OF CIVIL AVIATION FACILITIES, DARWIN AIRPORT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Northside development of civil aviation facilities Darwin airport.

This proposed work, recommended by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, involves the development by the Federal Airports Corporation of civil aviation facilities on the northern side of Darwin Airport. Members familiar with Darwin Airport will be aware that the existing domestic terminal is substandard and that it is housed in a converted Second World War Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) hangar. It is also surrounded by operational areas of the RAAF base and is congested and incapable of further expansion.

I know that the local Federal member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) will be delighted, along with his constituents, that this project is proceeding under the Hawke Labor Government. The local member has worked tirelessly in convincing the Government of the need for this work to be done, and he has beaten a well worn path to my door on many occasions seeking this result.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the work is a very major work for the Northern Territory. It will involve the construction of a new two-storey air-conditioned terminal building, with the apron space sufficient to accommodate two international and six domestic aircraft. It will include a new administration building and adjoining workshop and also a new taxi- way link to the main runway. There will be a new access road from McMillans Road, plus ancillary roads within the development areas. There will be parking for 550 cars, plus parking for buses, taxis and staff.

It will include a new general aviation taxi- way and apron capable of providing 100 aircraft parking positions, and it will provide for the servicing of all developments with water, sewerage, drainage and electrical works, which were left incomplete from the previous preparation when that ceased back in 1985.

This proposed work also recognises the unavoidable peaking of Darwin's domestic air movements and allows for anticipated growth in domestic, international and general aviation traffic up until early next century. The total cost of this project is estimated at $72m at May 1989 prices. This amount is exclusive of future cost escalation but includes an allowance of $15m for detailed design and contract management costs and for contingencies. The Federal Airports Corporation's current program anticipates completion by mid to late 1991.

It is estimated that the project will create employment for an average of 225 on-site workers and will peak at a maximum of 500. The proposal will be funded by the Federal Airports Corporation from non-Budget sources and will incorporate measures to meet the needs of the tourist and business traveller. It will greatly assist the Northern Territory by boosting construction activity and providing an attractive gateway to the internationally renowned tourist attractions in the Top End.

However, despite the obvious support for the project by the Public Works Committee, a number of the Committee's recommendations require some comment from me. First, the Corporation has consulted extensively with the airlines throughout this development process, including continuing discussions with the domestic airlines since the Committee's hearing. The main focus of these discussion has been on additions to the work rather than on any reductions. The airlines have not only been given project cost breakdowns, as recommended by the Public Works Committee, but the cost of various alternatives raised by the airlines. The Corporation is currently seeking tenders for the design and construction of the proposed development. In response to the Committee's report, tenderers have now been asked to price two additional aerobridges, the additional taxiway and some other alternatives since discussed with the airlines. However, a decision to proceed on these additions will depend on the prices quoted and on their commercial viability.

Regarding the matter of stormwater discharge, the Federal Airports Corporation has appointed the Northern Territory Power and Water Authority to collect baseline data and monitor discharges into Rapid Creek. Regular reports will also be made to an environmental working group, which includes the Darwin City Council and the Northern Territory Conservation Commission. The Committee's suggestion that it be given quarterly cost estimates and progress reports is not consistent with established practice. The Committee is normally given an annual report on each project referred to it. This report covers construction progress, a revised estimate of cost and advice of any significant changes that may have occurred along the way. The Federal Airports Corporation has to its credit, undertaken to inform the Committee of the outcome of the current tendering process immediately the final contract price is agreed with the successful tenderer, but wishes to discuss with the Committee the requested extent of further reporting. I thank the Public Works Committee for this prompt report. It has a very heavy work load and, by the end of next week, it will have an even heavier one-and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should start by thanking the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) for making available to me most of the statement that he made today. He did not make available to me his preamble on the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), and what I say about that is that I smell a pork barrel. That is, no doubt, why the Minister prefaced his remarks in such a way that he did not communicate them to me. But I thank him for making his statement available.

SPEECH.PARA: It is about time that the development of civil aviation facilities at Darwin Airport received approval. This thing has been going on for five years. People passing through Darwin have been looking at the tower standing there and regarding it as a white elephant. It is interesting to speculate on why the Minister, who admits that the Public Works Committee has a heavy work load, has sought to bring this development on in the middle of the pilots strike. Although the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says the pilots strike is over, the people of the Northern Territory, and the people of Darwin, do not think like that, because tourism has been truncated.

I notice the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) at the table giving me a wry smile, because he knows what has happened to tourism in the Northern Territory. He knows how it has been decimated by the pilots strike and the ongoing difficulties that exist in the Northern Territory. As I say, it is very interesting that at this time, when the Minister acknowledges that the Public Works Committee has a very heavy workload, he should bring on this project. If that Committee has a heavy work- load, this project could have been deferred for a while because, let us face it, no tourists are going through Darwin now.

I notice that the honourable member for the Northern Territory has scuttled back into the chamber. I am glad he is here for my remarks today-he did not stop and listen to them last night after having been a bit abusive. He should take a great deal of notice of what we are saying because the only reason this motion is before us today is that the honourable member is in some trouble in the Northern Territory. He wants to be able to go to his constituents and say, `Look what those in Canberra have done for me. Look at the money they are going to spend up here'. The honourable member should also try to explain to his constituents how the economy of the Northern Territory is being decimated by the pilots strike.

The Opposition supports the proposals contained in the report and we supported the referral to the Committee. We seek assurances from the Committee that it will convey to the Minister certain concerns that we have about this project. Although the airport design allows for the extension of facilities for an extra carrier after deregulation of the domestic airline industry, and there is a common user provision, we want the Committee to ensure that these provisions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I wish to clarify the situation. The motion that the Minister has moved is for the work to be carried out. The project has actually been to the Committee and the Committee has recommended the matter to Parliament.

—I am just telling the Minister what we want from him. We want some assurances. The first assurance that we want is that, although the airport design allows for extension of facilities for an extra carrier after the deregulation of domestic airlines, and there is a common user provision, we want these provisions to be carried out as soon as possible, as we understand that at least one other airline needs space at the airport following deregulation at the end of 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter will be a problem at most of the Federal Airports Corporation airports around Australia. This Government entered into arrangements with the two domestic carriers-that is, Australian Airlines Ltd and Ansett Airlines of Australia-on airport user facilities before the Federal Airports Corporation was formed, and when the Federal Airports Corporation was formed the Government dumped these contracts on it. Airline terminals around Australia are virtually locked up by the two domestic airlines. It has been for me, for some time, the source of some suspicion that the Government should have entered into these arrangements and not allowed the Federal Airports Corporation, which was in the process of being formed at the time, to do so. We want an assurance from the Minister that at this airport there will be a common user provision which will allow additional airlines to operate from the terminal after deregulation. In his speech the Minister spoke about the unavoidable peaking of Darwin's domestic air movements. I can tell the Minister that there are not many domestic air movements going through Darwin at the moment.

It is also of some concern-and I referred to this earlier-that an almost identical report was produced and tabled in this House in 1984. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall very well that at that time the Prime Minister, in his 1984 campaign-in yet another broken undertaking to the Australian people-promised that those plans, which involved very similar proposals to those we are considering today, would be carried out without delay. That was five years ago. All I can tell the Minister is that we do not want another delay of five years. If the Government's policies have provided trouble for the Northern Territory-I notice the honourable member for the Northern Territory squirming uncomfortably in his seat-and, believe me, brother, they have with what has happened with tourism up there, another five years would just about kill it off.

The 1984 report recommended nine proposals at a cost, then, of $95m. This year the cost has been estimated at $72m with only five recommendations. It seems there has been a drastic re-thinking and downgrading of the plans for Darwin. We would like an assurance from the Minister that what he has put in front of us today will do what it is supposed to do, which is meet the needs of the domestic and international airlines at the Darwin terminal.

We also know now-and this is partly as a result of a question by my colleague Senator Tambling-that the Civil Aviation Authority is planning to abolish the air traffic controllers at Darwin and have them at least partially relocated to Perth and Adelaide by January 1991. It is interesting to speculate on how the Government can justify this move or allow it to take place. The Minister cannot tell me the Government has no authority over the Civil Aviation Authority. The Government told the Civil Aviation Authority to waive the landing fees for Australian Airlines and Ansett. How can the Government justify this move of taking away local air traffic controllers when the airport is finally to be developed-and we hope we mean `finally to be developed'-into a meaningful gateway into Australia and the Northern Territory?
Paragraph 1 of the recommendations and conclusions to the 1984 report stated:
Facilities at Darwin Airport for international and domestic passengers and aircraft are grossly deficient and measures designed to rectify the situation should be implemented.

The Committee was then under the chairmanship of Senator Foreman, a member of the Australian Labor Party. Now, in 1989, five years later, it says that the existing civil aviation facilities at Darwin Airport, particularly the terminal division, are inadequate and substandard. What's news?

We would like to stress that the frustration experienced by the public of the Northern Territory is completely justified considering that nothing has happened between 1984 and now and completely justified by the fact that the Prime Minister, during the 1984 election campaign, publicly sat on the bulldozers at the airport and promised that all efforts would be made to rectify this grossly deficient infrastructure of Darwin's link to the rest of Australia. At last the Government seems to be getting on with it, although the timing looks a bit suspect and it is probably for the wrong reasons. We support the proposals contained in the report and urge the Minister most strongly that there be no delays and cutbacks experienced after this report, as there were in 1984.

DEBATE.TITLE: STAGE 2 DEVELOPMENT OF COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT CENTRE, HOBART

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Stage 2 development of Commonwealth Government Centre, Hobart.

This proposed public work is for the construction of stage 2 of the Commonwealth Government Centre, Hobart. It will, when completed, accommodate staff from various government departments, including the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security. The proposal provides for the construction of 9,200 square metres of office accommodation. The building is designed in a form which wraps around the existing tower building and plaza, varying in height above street level from three to six storeys.

Despite actions by my Department over the past three years to rationalise departmental accommodation, Commonwealth departments are spread across 27 buildings in the Hobart area. In total, the Commonwealth currently occupies approximately 48,380 square metres of office accommodation in Hobart, made up of 63 per cent leased and 30 per cent government-owned space. This project will increase the Commonwealth-owned level of accommodation in Hobart to around 50 per cent. At the same time, it will maximise the full commercial development potential of the site. This is consistent with the Government's objective of increasing the proportion of owned office space, reducing overall rental costs and providing accommodation which will enhance efficiency of operation and delivery of services to the public.

The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who is in the chamber now, has closely followed this project from its inception and the realisation of approval for the work is due, in my opinion, in no small part to the local member's efforts. He has consistently drawn my attention to the fact that I have put to the House-that is, that there is a huge spread of leased accommodation across 30 different office sites in Hobart. As a result of the honourable member's work, the Government has agreed to go ahead with this major project in the capital of Tasmania. The project will provide some valuable employment opportunities in the Hobart construction industry, which has been experiencing a moderate downturn recently. About 150 people are likely to be employed on this site at the peak of construction. There will also be benefits with the increased activity in the supply and services industries.

In June 1989 we agreed in this House to refer this proposal to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for examination and report. The Committee has duly tabled its report and has accepted the need for the development. In its report, the Committee recommended that the Department of Administrative Services should complete its current review of the policy on the provision of car parking at Commonwealth offices. I can report that this review is well under way and will take into account the comments made by the Committee in the body of its report. The Committee has recommended that construction proceed on Stage 2 of the Commonwealth Government Centre, Hobart at an estimated cost of $19.9m, at May 1989 prices. When it is completed it will be a major addition to office accommodation in the city of Hobart. I commend the motion to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF ARMY AVIATION CENTRE, OAKEY, QUEENSLAND

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Redevelopment of the Army Aviation Centre at Oakey, Queensland.

The Oakey Army Aviation Centre, situated on 220 hectares of land near the township of Oakey on the Darling Downs, 160 kilometres west of Brisbane, was originally established in 1941 for use by the Royal Australian Air Force during World War II. In 1969 the Army took control of the airfield and since then a number of developments have taken place, including provision of temporary and permanent facilities for units currently located on the base. Today the airfield is home to the School of Army Aviation, 1st Aviation Regiment-with the exception of two squadrons located in Sydney and Townsville-1st Aviation Regiment Workshop, 173 General Support Squadron and Workshop, 5 Base Workshop Battalion and the Royal Australian Electrical and Mechanical Engineers Aircraft Maintenance School. All of these units are administratively coordinated and controlled by the headquarters Army Aviation Centre, which also located at the base. Currently the base houses 55 aircraft and approximately 196 vehicles and trailers and employs 734 Army personnel and 51 civilian staff. This employment figure is expected to rise to a total of 863 persons by 1995. The airfield at Oakey is a joint user aerodrome, the Department of Defence-Army-being the principal user with the Department of Transport and Communications as the tenant accounting for approximately 15 per cent of total aircraft movements.

In line with this Government's commitment to enhance our defence capabilities, and as stressed in the Defence Policy Information Paper of 1987, there is a continued need for Army aviation assets and an extensive infrastructure of bases, airfields, training and other facilities to support the operations of the Australian defence forces. The centre at Oakey is a major part of that infrastructure providing the core for both aviation training and support for the Army throughout Australia. Oakey was described in the Cooksey review of Australia's Defence facilities as conducive to aircraft operations and is the preferred possible site, over Fairbairn, for any tri-service helicopter pilot training school.

The works currently before the House are aimed at rectifying significant occupational health and safety deficiencies and upgrading working conditions at the base. In particular, stage 1 will involve the construction of permanent facilities for 1 Aviation Regiment, which still occupies temporary facilities constructed in 1969, and 173 General Support Squadron. Extension to the existing hangar and technical facilities used by 1 Aviation Regiment workshop and extension-refurbishment of aircraft maintenance facilities for 5 Base Workshop Battalion are also included, along with civil work and extensions to existing engineering services. In addition, the Police Dog Section will be relocated to new facilities on the base.

Once complete these works will provide purpose designed working facilities for Army units located on the base, ensure the continued provision of services undertaken at the airfield and provide a centralised helicopter pilot training school once training facilities are complete next year. As part of the training school, a number of Black Hawk helicopters will eventually be housed at Oakey. A second stage of redevelopment at Oakey is also being planned to address less urgent problems but it is not expected to be undertaken for several years. This staging of redevelopment is due to financial constraints within the Department of Defence.

The limit of cost for the stage 1 redevelopment is estimated at $14.6m at September 1989 prices. The proposed works are expected to go to tender in September 1990, subject to a favourable Public Works Committee report, with progressive completion through to 1994. The proposed works are expected to provide employment for up to 80 personnel on site and substantial opportunities for local contractors and subcontractors as well as suppliers of building materials, plant and equipment in the Oakey area. I table selected plans of the proposed stage 1 redevelopment at Oakey and I commend the motion to the House.

It is a matter of public record that no single body within the defence community understands the strategic rationale on which the Government has based its decision to scrap the Chinooks. Indeed, in responding to the claim of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) this year that scrapping the 11 Chinooks would give him an extra $110m to spend on the big ticket items, my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the Opposition defence spokesman, quite rightly pointed out that the Minister's figures were rubbery and overlooked the capability which the Chinooks provide the Australian Defence Force. Small to medium size business or even large business will be in very difficult circumstances under the penalty arrangements that exist in meeting that 15-day requirement for a payment of 85 per cent of the notational tax payable.

I would like to finish my remarks with a few quick comments on the self-assessment decision which we also oppose. The committee stage amendment will seek to excise those relevant clauses from the Act. There has been a lot of concern amongst accountants about these new self-assessment provisions which substantially reduce what protection taxpayers received under previous legislation when they were able to make a full and true disclosure of contentious issues in their income tax return. The Bill contains no alternative mechanism for obtaining protection against the imposition of substantial tax penalties in such cases, nor does it provide any mechanism for obtaining greater certainty from the tax system by way of binding rulings being obtained from the Commissioner for Taxation. Previously, the submission of a full and true disclosure awarded the taxpayer substantial protection against the imposition of high penalty levels on an adjustment related to an arguable issue.

The new self-assessment provisions require an abridged form of tax return to be submitted which does not offer that protection. In short, the taxpayer will no longer be afforded the protection offered by his submission to the Tax Office of all relevant information. According to the Tax Institute, under the amendments contained in the Bill lodgment of a return by a corporate taxpayer is deemed by the new section 166a to be an assessment made under the hand of the Commissioner. Thus, in its application to a corporate taxpayer, section 169a (2) does not permit a corporate taxpayer to require the Commissioner to give attention to a matter prior to assessment. In the absence of an amendment to section 169a (2) to permit corporate taxpayers to require the Commissioner to give attention to a matter before assessment, or at least prior to the date upon which a corporate taxpayer's return is required to be lodged, a corporate taxpayer has a greater potential for exposure to interest penalties than an individual taxpayer. Unless corporate taxpayers can flag an issue of concern for consideration by the Commissioner without the potential for incurring penalties, corporate taxpayers will either be forced to take a risky course of action and not disclose an issue of concern or, alternatively, be required to incur additional financing costs in paying an amount of tax reflecting the Commissioner's view and seeking to object against that assessment.

Moreover, the existing tax legislation for self-assessment is laced with a number of discretions that have been granted to the Commissioner as to whether to allow a deduction and the appropriate size of a deduction. Extending the self-assessment provisions without addressing the appropriateness of the discretions currently awarded to the Commissioner will just exacerbate the problems already in the system. The second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) refers to the Commissioner reviewing his own internal administrative arrangements relating to the imposition of penalties and the issue of rulings and taxpayers. We do not think it is good enough. We think that the only way to deal with this is to pull it out. I am aware that the Tax Institute has written to the Treasurer basically expressing the view that it does not think that this part of the legislation in its current form is appropriate enough to go forward.

In my final remarks in the few seconds that I have left I will comment on the very considerable work that was done by my colleague Senator John Watson on the issue of the deductability of certain costs associated with the filing of returns and so on. I want to put on record the phenomenal amount of work that Senator Watson did in organising allowable deductions for expenditure incurred by taxpayers in connection with the management and administration of their income tax affairs. It was a tremendous initiative on his part. I am pleased that the Government has picked it up, although Senator Watson has some concerns about the very wide nature of the drafting of, for example, section 69 (2), which he fears will potentially deprive a person of the intended tax deduction. He will deal with those points in some detail in the debate in the Senate. Again, I put firmly on the record the considerable contribution that Senator Watson has made and how well that has been received by the profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is another in a series of taxation Bills which this Government has progressively introduced to make the system fairer and more equitable. Sadly, that point was missing from the contribution of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who went into a long diatribe about the Bill's having nothing to do with tax reform. He said that it involved the rape of the small and medium sized business sector. He talked about the ego and the credibility of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and so on. Of course, that deflected totally from what is contained in this legislation. I will make some comments about his contribution in a moment. However, he will get his wish in respect of some changes being proposed by the Government, which have been introduced this afternoon by way of Government amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major issues to which he referred was the time period by which tax is to be payable and due. In the Government's original proposition, it was to be made payable by the fifteenth day of the first month after the end of the income tax year. Unlike the Opposition, the Government has prided itself on its ability to discuss with practitioners and people who will be affected by many of the pieces of legislation that it has enacted in order to get their feel for it and a full understanding of its implications. The end result has been an amendment moved by the Government to alter the fifteenth day to the twenty-eighth day. I believe that in itself will meet some of the concerns expressed by the honourable member for Wentworth.

The second issue raised by the honourable member for Wentworth was with regard to the amount of tax payable. Again, an amendment is being proposed for $400,000 for the 1990 tax year, which is obviously a substantial increase, remaining in subsequent years at the $20,000 limit which the Government originally proposed. Again, this addresses the concerns raised by small business. It is nothing short of nonsense to suggest that this Government does not understand the workings of small to medium sized businesses. I am sure that all honourable members take a great deal of time to go and talk with those business people, to see for themselves the operations of small to medium sized businesses within their electorates and to encourage the development of those businesses. Ultimately, the development of those businesses means employment opportunities in those towns, cities and electorates that we all represent.

The honourable member for Wentworth talked about none of those things. Rather, he said that this Government had an agenda to try to boost its surplus level and as a result it searched high and low and suddenly hit on small to medium sized businesses and said, `Let us rape this sector of the economy and put legislation through to bring forward the payment date of taxation'. He then went on to say that this surplus would be made to look better than it otherwise would be. He implied that it would be a terrible thing for this Government to bring down a surplus. It would be, in the eyes of the honourable member for Wentworth, because, as we all remember, he was the adviser to the last Liberal Treasurer in the last coalition government, and when it left office `surplus' was a dirty word. When it left office a $10 billion deficit was the flavour of the month-not a surplus. So it does not surprise those on this side of the House that in his comments earlier today on this legislation he tried to suggest that this Government's surplus was fudged in some way and made to look bigger than it really is. He said that this was simply pandering to the Treasurer's ego in trying to build in income sources that would make that surplus larger than it would otherwise be.

The honourable member for Wentworth also said that there was Government greed in tax. It is the same tired old line that is constantly run by the Opposition. It conveniently forgets that this Government, in pursuing a fairer and more equitable tax system, has made some basic changes to the tax mix. What we have done for medium and small companies through this legislation further strengthens that position. It is true that there is a greater tax take now for this Government. But the Opposition conveniently forgets why that is so. It is because there are more people in jobs. One and a half million more people are in jobs than was the case in 1983. So, yes, more people are paying tax. We have made the system fairer and more equitable. We have cracked down on the tax evasion and avoidance industry which, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) remarked in his contribution this afternoon, under the stewardship of the previous coalition government was the fastest growing industry in this country. We have cracked down on that. We have introduced a capital gains tax that is fair by any Western country standards. We have introduced a fringe benefits tax (FBT) to crack down on the free lunch merchants. Of course they are the people that those on the other side still seek to support.

It is absolute nonsense for the honourable member for Wentworth to suggest, as he did this afternoon, that with the introduction of the capital gains tax we were looking after our mates in the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the workers because we did not make the FBT applicable to canteens. By doing that, he said that we were looking after our mates in the ACTU and the workers who are doing their job for Australia. What a hide he has to say that. Let us compare the capital gains tax with the speculative gains tax being proposed by those opposite. Less than one per cent of the Australian population-the wealthiest one per cent-will benefit from the speculative gains tax. What the Opposition is proposing in its grubby exercise is to hand back millions-indeed, billions-of dollars by having--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I draw your attention to the fact that the honourable member is not addressing the legislation before the Chair.
—I gather the honourable member is raising the issue of relevance?
—Yes.

—The Chair is conscious of the issue of relevance but I remind the honourable member for Curtin that we are currently dealing with an amendment moved by the honourable member for Wentworth which rather broadens the scope of the original debate. —I thank you, as always, Mr Deputy Speaker, for drawing that to my attention. But I simply say to the honourable member for Curtin that in the contribution by the shadow Treasurer before lunch he did go into considerable detail--

—As always, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am encouraged by your counsel. SPEECH.PARA: In the few moments that I have left to speak on this legislation. I want to refer to the issue that was raised with regard to tax deductions for the cost of professional tax advice. The honourable member for Wentworth sought to laud Senator Watson for the amount of work that he had done in bringing this matter to the attention of government. I do not know that that was necessarily the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was; there was a Bill passed in the Senate.

—I know that a great contribution was made in the Senate in relation to legislation. But I point out that a report of a committee of this House that was tabled in this place made the same recommendations. I am unsure, but I think at the time the honourable member for Wentworth was a member of that committee. He should perhaps check his records. He might not be as fulsome in his praise for a colleague in the other place if he finds that he was a member of a committee which made suggestions as to how legislation of this type, which includes tax deductability for the costs of professional tax advice, might proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation makes a contribution to the continuing reform of the tax system in this country. The changes proposed in the amendments to be moved by the Government will perhaps soften some of the impact that some honourable members thought could be a concern. I feel confident in predicting that honourable members opposite will indicate that they do not believe that the measure goes far enough.
