SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on one aspect of the contribution made by the previous speaker. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) referred to members on the Government side talking to small business people and others to get their impressions of and opinions on legislation such as that presently before us. I have no doubt that the honourable member is one of the people who do that. He is a conscientious member and I will miss him after the next election. But I doubt whether the honourable member could, in all conscience, attribute that very worthwhile feature of his work to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The possibility that the Treasurer has spoken to anyone in the workplace is very remote indeed. This is reflected in the legislation presently before the House and in many of the Treasurer's decisions and utterances.

SPEECH.PARA: Among the many changes to the taxation laws proposed in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is one which stipulates the earlier collection of company income tax. In making this change the Government is breaking new ground. It does not even offer the defence that it falls back on so often by claiming that, because another country does something, it is justified in doing something similar in Australia. That other refuge for defenders of the indefensible when all else fails, namely, invoking the `public interest' or the `national interest', has not even been attempted. I suppose we can be grateful for that.

Apart from the obvious reason-that is, the need for this grasping Government to raise more and more revenue by way of increases in, and the earlier collection of, existing taxes-we have to go back to the Treasurer's Budget Speech for clues. We find there that the Treasurer offered us another of his little gems, to rank with the others, like the allusion to an effervescing economy. When all the magic figures on the balance of payments were starting to penetrate his thick skull, we were told that our cup runneth over.
In the Budget Speech he foreshadowed this proposed assault on corporate Australia and added another shovelful to the pile of garbage that his words have built during his term in office. He said then:
Because of these delays, companies enjoy an interest free loan from the Government for up to two years. We have decided to narrow this concessional arrangement.

There we have it. All our previous beliefs about the right to the fruits of our labour go out the window. That is the gospel according to Paul. Well, all I can say is, heaven help him. Only someone as arrogant as the Treasurer could come up with that. While the rest of us labour under the misapprehension that property in the form of income belongs to the individuals who or entities which earn it and that governments will take such part of it as will facilitate good government, the Treasurer regards it as being rightfully his from day one. If we should keep it any longer we are receiving concessional treatment and an interest free loan from the Government. That is the gospel according to Paul. Income taxes gathered by any government are an interest free loan to that government, the right having been ceded by the tax paying public, on trust, pending good government. Not so for our latter day apostle, Paul. Apparently it is his, in all his arrogant glory, to do with as he pleases.

One outcome of the Treasurer's doubtful state of mind in this context will be an increase in this financial year of a one-off $880m to the budgeted surplus. The following year the measure will raise a further $130m and, after that, who knows? Some of the $880m this financial year will be attributable to income taxes payable earlier by companies which traditionally close their books perhaps during April or May. With that in mind, it might be assumed that an extra $880m-or more than $1 billion over two years-is not a great additional imposition on the corporate sector.

However, there is considerably more to it than that. Within this and subsequent financial years, the majority of companies with 30 June balance dates will have to fork out huge sums earlier. Instead of the present arrangement involving payment by instalments of 25 per cent by 15 August, a further 25 per cent by 15 November and a further 25 per cent by 15 February, with the balance based on the actual tax payable due around 30 April, 85 per cent of notional profit will now be payable in the following August-within a matter of weeks. Leaving aside the concept of notional profit as distinct from actual profit, it would take someone from among the majority with only a whit more intelligence than the Treasurer to understand what that measure will do to corporate cash flows, or even cash reserves if any companies are left with reserves after seven years of this chiselling Government. That will be something to behold and to fear.

Although less than precise, because as always we are not given the relevant calculations in the explanatory memorandum, it is still possible to illustrate the maximum effect on corporate Australian business if we take as the starting point the budgeted income tax to be taken from companies during this financial year. It is a massive amount. In fact, at $11.205 billion it is, along with all taxes, at a record all-time high. Because there will be some exclusions in the proposals and extraneous matters, an amount of $10 billion might be a good figure to play around with for demonstration purposes, rather than the total estimated company taxes this financial year, as I have just recited.

On that basis and under the present formula approximately $2.5 billion will be payable on the fifteenth day of each of the months of August and November and next February, and the remainder on around 30 April 1990. The net effect of the relevant provisions of the Bill will be to bring forward the collection of something like $6 billion in company taxes to 15 August from November and next February and April. That represents an enormous flow of funds from the private sector into the public purse and it will have to be raised by the tax paying companies. If those same companies borrow, as most of them will have to, to meet the earlier impost, the interest on the borrowings raised for the purpose will not be allowed as a tax deductable expense, and that must be the unkindest cut of all. The interest paid on those borrowings will be at commercial rates, averaging around 22 or 23 per cent but as high as 25 per cent, as a direct consequence of the Government's confessed high interest rate policy.

In the hands of the Government, though, the $6m or so will save it interest at treasury bill rates of maybe 13 per cent or thereabouts. That is how this tired, stale Government goes about robbing Peter to pay Paul. It is so tired and stale and completely lacking in energy and vision that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is governing by suggestion box. The Prime Minister has had to resort to writing to his Ministers to get ideas because his own claimed considerable intellect is unable to come up with deceit of the kind that he concocted before previous elections. His mind has gone blank, it is barren. The Prime Minister had better be careful where he leaves his suggestion box because, if people from suburban or country Australia, or from the corporate sector for that matter, get hold of it, there are likely to be some pretty rude suggestions forthcoming indeed.

Here we have what must rate as one of the biggest raids on corporate Australia by a Treasurer and his Government which, at the same time, is responsible for a national debt and a national balance of payments deficit of dimensions unimaginable only a few years ago. The economic debacle, as verified by the balance of trade figures, the balance of payments, international indebtedness, record high interest rates and high inflation figures, will be further jeopardised by measures such as this. One effect will be to deprive companies of the funds generated from normal cash flows employed to earn funds in the course of generating taxable income. Another will be to deprive companies of in-house cash to invest in productive capital equipment, an objective so often claimed by the Government and equally as often prevented by the self same Government, as has happened in this case.
I turn now to the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who submitted the following:
whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) recognising the plight of small businesses in Australia, calls on the Government to increase substantially the threshold at which the new two instalment company tax arrangements will apply;
(2) rejects the Governments proposals on self-assessment of company tax because of the inadequate safeguards and protection of the integrity of taxpayers; and
(3) condemns the Government for its flagrant disregard in its taxation policies of the circumstances faced by many small businesses in Australia.

I wholeheartedly support that amendment. Because we are in this ridiculous situation again where important and extremely complex legislation is under the guillotine, I will touch very briefly on another matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a scandal.

—It is a scandal, as my colleague says. Once again, it will be left to our colleagues in the Senate to legislate, while we play penny-ante politics in this chamber. When will we ever learn? If we as legislators and political practitioners want to earn the respect of the people of Australia, we must get our act together.
—Don't go along with the Democrats in the Senate.

—Of course, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy trots out the defence of the Senate holding up legislation, the Democrats or something similar. During the past sitting week we debated under the guillotine a taxation Bill equally as complex and equally as serious in its implications for Australian taxpayers. It was introduced on 31 May, but we debated it under the guillotine only during the past sitting week. That is another product of the stale and tired Government with which we must cope.
—Order! I remind the honourable member for Curtin of his earlier point about relevance and ask him to return to the Bill before the House.

—I accept that, Mr Deputy Speaker; how could I do otherwise? I return to the question of self-assessment. I will not be baited by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy who, after all, is waiting for an opportunity to occupy the position of Leader of the Opposition after the next election. I simply state that the self-assessment proposal before the preparation of company tax is entirely inappropriate in the context of the way taxable income is arrived at in the hands of a corporation. Of course, the vast majority of individual taxpayers who self-assess are not really involved in such complicated calculations. In other words, their assessable income is clearly stated in most cases and it is deducted in the process of their earning that income and being recorded on group certificates or paid by tax stamps, and so a much simpler and different arrangement applies in the case of self- assessment for individuals. I suspect that this proposal for companies will be treated as another weapon and bargaining chip in the hands of the Commissioner of Taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of self-assessment and amendment of assessments I have some real concern about the fact that no piece of paper will be issued to prove the assessment process. If the Commissioner of Taxation were to lose a tax return-and I can assure honourable members that he does very often-how would the taxpayer prove that an assessment had been issued? Will taxpayers now be required to obtain receipts for every tax return they lodge? It seems to me that the Commissioner simply has not thought through the proposal and the practicality of this proposed law and, of course, nor has the Treasurer, but that is less than surprising.

Australia's small business community, which will be affected by this measure, is really starting to feel the pinch now as high interest rates are sustained in the 21 to 25 per cent range. Corporate tax flows are squeezed as a consequence and will be squeezed further. The pilots dispute is crippling many in the tourist industry, and the possibility of a significant slump in demand next year grows almost daily as the Government fails to respond to calls to significantly shift its policy mix. Mr Deputy Speaker, my time has expired; I have taken a little longer than I should have and I apologise to my colleagues for that. I repeat that I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Wentworth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal first with some of the comments of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is about an ongoing process of providing much fairer taxation for all Australians. The honourable member almost gave the impression that we are asking companies to pay tax even before they earn the money. However, it is simple to see that they are paying the tax after they have already earned their profits for the year. The fact that they will have to pay 85 per cent by the fifteenth of the month after the end of their financial year should not necessarily create a big problem for companies, because most companies know where they are going in business and how their profits are looking. In many cases, they would determine quarterly profits to give themselves some sort of assessment along the way of how the business is actually operating.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, a prudent business manager would ensure that his company provided for taxation, because it has to pay taxation at some time. Companies have enjoyed a privileged position for a long time. Wage and salary earners certainly do not have the opportunity to defer paying their tax for the periods that they would wish to do so. Therefore, what the honourable member for Wentworth said in trying to defend big business in that way is rather irrelevant, especially when one considers the sorts of profits some large companies are making at present. In the past few weeks, major profits have been announced by two of the largest banks in Australia-the National Australia Bank Ltd and Westpac Banking Corporation-which made profits of about $800m. I am sure that those banks would be able to pay their tax liabilities when they are due, considering the profits they have made. They might have to organise themselves a bit better to announce their June profits a little before September.

I am pleased to be able to support the Bill before the House. The Opposition has expressed concern about the phasing in period. The amendments referred to earlier by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) will certainly help with the phasing in period and help small and medium size businesses and companies along the way. Those amendments should address some of the difficulties raised by the Opposition.

This Bill is another example of the ongoing commitment by this Government to reform the taxation system and ensure that all those who should be paying tax are certainly doing so and at the right time. The decision to bring forward the time for payment of tax by companies, complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds (ADFs) and pooled superannuation trusts was announced in the 1989-90 Budget. The changes will result in additional revenue of some $885m in this financial year.

Currently, companies pay tax in quarterly instalments in the year following that in which the income is earned. The final instalment adjusts the tax payable on the previous year's income and the actual income for that year. Companies presently obtain much greater tax deferral benefits than other taxpayers, benefits equivalent to an interest free loan from the Commonwealth of the deferred tax payment. Companies benefit from deferring the payment of tax until after, rather than during, the income year; from being able to spread such payments over that following year; and from basing the first three quarterly payments on income of two years prior to the year of tax. In comparison, tax instalments of wage and salary earners are for, and based on, actual income earned in a pay period, whether it be a weekly or fortnightly payment, or whatever the case might be. Provisional tax payments of other non-company taxpayers are for current year income and are based on uplifted prior year income. A new tax collection system for companies, complying superannuation funds, the ADFs and pooled superannuation trusts will therefore apply in respect of their 1989-90 and subsequent years of income.

Since these entities are required to pay tax in the year following the year of income, the new arrangements will first affect tax payments in their 1990-91 financial year, or substituted year in the case of early balancing companies. The changes will alter the timing of payments within the financial year of affected taxpayers but not the total amount payable. The bringing forward of payments within the year will reduce the tax deferral available to these taxpayers compared to individuals, thereby enhancing the equity of the taxation system. It will generate a significant reduction in Commonwealth outlays by reducing public debt interest.

The amended collection system will consist of a single instalment of tax, due by the fifteenth day of the first month after the year of income, or substituted accounting period of early balancing companies, with 15 January being the earliest due date, equal to 85 per cent of the notional tax amount or 85 per cent of the taxpayer's estimate of actual tax liability.

The balance of tax owing will be due by the fifteenth day of the ninth month following the end of the income year, or substituted accounting period for those companies with early balancing periods, with 15 September being the earliest due date in that case. Companies which balance after 30 June in lieu of that date will continue to be treated as if they balance on 30 June. To ensure that the appropriate instalment payments are not avoided, the Commissioner of Taxation will be authorised to determine that the instalment payable be based on the notional tax amount rather than the taxpayer's own estimate, or to adjust the amount of the instalment to an amount not exceeding 85 per cent of the notional tax amount if, in the opinion of the Commissioner, the company or its associates have engaged in a scheme designed with the sole or dominant purpose of reducing the level of the instalment.

If the amount of the instalment paid by the company is less than the amount so determined by the Commissioner of Taxation, penalties will apply in respect of the difference. The requirement for an earlier payment of the self-assessed balance of tax will bring forward $150m of revenue from 1991-92 to 1990-91. The bringing forward of the instalment and balancing payment dates within the taxpayer's tax year will result in ongoing savings in public debt interest outlays of about $330m in each year from 1990-91.

Following representations from business groups, two changes have been incorporated into this Bill. First, the time for payments by entities that balance after 30 June has been altered to place them on the same footing as other entities. Secondly, entities with a relatively small tax liability-that is, $1,000 to $20,000-will have the option of making a single payment, generally six months after the end of their balancing period. As I said previously, I believe that the Acting Treasurer, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), has announced that the Government will be moving certain amendments to this Bill which will incorporate certain transitional arrangements to assist small and medium size companies in the payment of their taxation liability. These amendments will ease the financial impact on these companies, and will certainly show a continuation of the Government's assistance to this area.

From 1 July 1989, expenditure incurred by the taxpayer in complying with all Australian taxation laws, including attending to the requirements of an audit by the Australian Taxation Office of the taxpayer's affairs, has become deductable for income tax purposes. The allowable expenditure will be confined to payments to registered tax agents, or to solicitors or barristers who are exempt from the requirement to register as tax agents, but will include expenditure incurred where the relevant services are provided by employees of the taxpayer.

Section 78 deals with the deductability of certain gifts, et cetera. To the range of deductable gifts will be added those for acquisition, construction or maintenance of a building used to accommodate rural students where the Commonwealth, a State or Territory funds all or part of the capital or recurrent costs of the school the students are attending. The measure is complementary to the new system of grants in respect of accommodation for rural students being introduced by the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989.

Following a review of the taxation treatment of life insurance conducted in consultation with industry bodies, expenses incurred by life office companies-that is, excluding friendly societies and other registered organisations, which are eligible for a lower rate of tax-in gaining the investment component of life insurance premium income are allowed as a taxation deduction to apply in respect of expenses incurred on or after 1 January 1990. Life insurance is a major source of long term savings for business investment purposes. The removal of inconsistencies in the taxation treatment of life offices' insurance business removes an unfair tax burden on such investments, thereby increasing the return on savings in this form.

As I stated at the beginning, this Government is committed to taxation reform to ensure that the taxation system is fair to all Australians and that everyone accepts his responsibility to pay his fair share of tax. This Bill is part of the ongoing reforms of this Government and removes the anomaly of companies being able to defer their tax liability for long periods, in many cases at least 12 months and in some cases up to two years, having regard to the beginning of their financial year. I am very pleased to support the Bill before the House and I certainly reject the amendment put forward by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) it has been interesting to hear the comments from members on the Government side of the House about the Government's ongoing commitment to reform, equity and fairness. It is just and proper that all of us, as legislators, should have regard to those things. But I defy anyone to say that, having regard to the size of the existing Income Tax Assessment Act, there is fairness and equity in these additions, particularly when one looks at the amendments that the Government has thought fit to bring forward since this legislation was introduced a few weeks ago. Already, that claim of fairness and equity cannot apply.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that the claim of fairness cannot apply in respect of taxpayers. It is not just a matter of this Parliament enacting legislation and the Australian Taxation Office carrying it out. There needs to be fairness in respect of certainty and often this is not conveyed in legislation and press releases as far as the taxpayer is concerned. Many of the complaints I hear these days-and I have not actually practised under the tax Act for 14 years-make me aware of the size of the Act, its complications and its lack of certainty as far as people planning their financial affairs are concerned.

It is interesting that we are having an argument within the public arena at the moment about the capital gains tax and a speculative gains tax. The claim is made by the Government that a speculative gains tax will be a disincentive to investment in the productive area. I can tell the Government that the capital gains tax is a disincentive to thousands of taxpayers because they do not have the heart to go into an enterprise, whether it be trading or otherwise. In the long term, they would face the prospect of having their capital gains taxed. Instead of investing in this area, their money can more profitably be invested in savings. That is the problem with Australia at the moment. That is the trouble with our economy. There is an active disincentive for people to invest because of the massive amount of tax laws. The penal rates of tax are a penalty against investment.

I could name quite a few people who might have invested in a trading company, or something that was going to be productive in the long term. But there was no incentive for them to do so because of the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the entertainment tax-one could keep naming them-introduced by this Government. What is fair and equitable about that? What Australia needs, above all else, is a productive climate in which people can trade with certainty under a fair system, and that is what is missing from the economy at the moment.

The main portion of the legislation before the House deals with a change in the way companies pay tax. Again, one might look at this from the point of view of equity for the provisional taxpayer, the individual taxpayer and the pay as you earn taxpayer. Even though the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has lifted the ceiling to $20,000, the majority of tax is being collected from a small number of big businesses. One might say that is fair enough. But many small businesses are trying to operate in a very hostile environment. That is why I certainly support the amendment of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), that there should be further relief in terms of the threshold to enable small companies to trade properly. When I talk about a hostile environment I need only mention the record interest rates. I have a fairly close involvement with a company that has faced the situation within the last 12 months where the interest rate on a normal loan-and it is on prime rates-has gone from about 15 per cent to over 20 per cent. That is a hostile environment.

Australia's inflation rate is still soaring above that of our competitors. The exchange rate is penalising many companies in Australia because they cannot trade on the overseas markets as they might do if the dollar was allowed to float free and was not propped up by the interest rates from which they also suffer. I could talk about the centralised wage system. All of these things contribute to a hostile environment into which the Government is now forcing many companies by asking them to prepay their tax.

I want to mention the prepayment of tax and what this Labor Government has done over a period of seven years. There has never been such an incidence of the prepayment of taxes. We have seen the introduction of the prescribed payments scheme (PPS). The Taxation Office has pushed people to contribute on a pay as you earn basis instead of under the PPS. People also make provisional tax payments and quarterly tax payments. The measure now before us also involves the prepayment of tax. Australia is in a situation where there is no more fat to squeeze. We are in this situation because the Treasurer is determined to achieve a favourable result this year.

I am concerned about small business people who are trying to make a dollar and who are now being asked to look at their liquidity. Again, the banks have indicated the lack of liquidity that will occur in the months of July down the track because of this prepayment. Big businesses can hold up. I can give three examples of businesses which are being propped up by the Government at the moment. Banks are being propped up to the extent of $200m to subsidise interest rates because of the failure of the Government in respect of the economy. We are suffering a further deterioration in our balance of payments because this Government is propping up the airlines and continuing a dispute-or a Clayton's dispute, as far as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is concerned. Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd is the last example. Again, it is a big business that is being propped up by the Government. For goodness' sake, the Government should have concern for the small businesses of Australia and what is happening to them.

I would like to say something about the manner in which the Taxation Office itself fails to address its own efficiency. I have had a large number of complaints in connection with the work to regulation practices in some of the tax offices. Perhaps it is going on in all of the tax offices-it is certainly going on in the one of which I have knowledge. This practice is preventing the processing of taxpayers' explanations, refunds and even assessments. There is a deliberate ploy by the Tax Office not to apply itself to these areas. There is a massive amount of confusion. If the Taxation Office wants us to get the legislative process put in order, it should also put its own house in order.

I wish to raise the case of a taxpayer who has had difficulty in getting a new prescribed payment number from the Tax Office. The certificate expired on 30 October this year and, despite having applied for a new number in mid-October, there has been no response from the Tax Office. The holder of this certificate has had to knock back payments until the new number is obtained because otherwise a 20 per cent deduction would have to be made. This might be part of the campaign of delay but there are subcontractors around Australia who are suffering because they cannot use the old forms and numbers. It appears that the Tax Office is deliberately delaying the issue of new numbers so that the 20 per cent deduction might apply.

I have taken this up with the Tax Office and have been told there is a five-week delay. But surely the Office can put itself in order and make sure these things are given out at the appropriate times. What is the point of legislation if it cannot be applied? I have also had complaints from subcontractors who are being pushed from the PPS to the pay as you earn system. They have been bluffed by auditors from the Tax Office into complying with a system they do not want. I certainly support the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are continuing the debate on some very wide-ranging and significant income tax legislation, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989. I want to concentrate particularly on one aspect of that legislation. It is that that deals with the changing arrangements for the payment by companies of their tax liability. It is easy to advance the principle that tax should be paid as it is earned in the year in which it is earned or immediately following the conclusion of the year in which it is earned but, in determining which of those points in time shall be used for the payment of tax, one needs to look at past practice. If there is to be a change, there should also be a change in the tax rates to place companies in an equal situation under both methods of payment.

SPEECH.PARA: On this occasion the Government has chosen to bring forward the dates upon which companies are due to pay their tax, but it has made no compensation in the rates of tax to adjust for that advance in the payments; nor has it taken into account the commercial realities. It has dealt with the matter in theory and from the perspective of the Government, and of the Government only. It has disregarded altogether the effects upon the daily operations of businesses. Many businesses have put the view that, if this change had been announced and then gradually phased in over time, it would have been possible for large businesses, very small businesses and middle Australian businesses, which are the core of the Australian economy, to adjust their financial affairs to cope with this changed date of payment, given that the Government has made no adjustment in the tax that they pay.

Why do I argue that there should have been an adjustment? Let us look at the realities. Under the present legislation-not that which is proposed and is being considered by this Parliament-companies in the main pay their tax in four instalments: on 15 August, in November, in February and some time in May of every financial year. Let me give the House the illustration of a company that under present arrangements pays $100,000 tax in four equal instalments of $25,000. Under the proposed arrangement that company will not have to pay 25 per cent in August but will have to pay 85 per cent of the tax in July and then the remaining 15 per cent, with any adjustments that may arise as a consequence of the income of the current year being different from that of the preceding year, in April. One might say that it is paying exactly the same amount of tax, but let us look at the costs to that company.

The Government has been very forward in asking what is the revenue forgone, what is the benefit to the revenue of getting revenue in earlier and the benefit in interest saved. But let us look at the effect on a company that has to pay $85,000 in income tax in July rather than $25,000 in August, $25,000 in November, $25,000 in February and so on. The chartered accountants Deloitte Haskins and Sells have sent to their clients a newsletter which has revealed that, if the company were paying 20 per cent interest on borrowed money, or alternatively if it had the tax money in its hand in cash and were able to invest it at 20 per cent, on a revenue forgone basis or on an expenses incurred basis the loss to the company would be approximately $7,000. In effect this legislation is increasing company tax by 7 per cent-not by the normal way in which company tax is adjusted, by increasing the rate, but by making it payable earlier-and in circumstances in which the business community has had little time to adjust.

In 1989-90, it is estimated, $11.5 billion worth of company tax will be collected. The changed tax collection in the year, we are told, because of this legislation, will advance into this financial year $885m of tax, largely coming from early balance date companies; and $150m will be gained in 1990-91 for the same reason. The earlier payments comprise not only those made by the early balance date companies but also those made by the 30 June balance date companies and by the late balance date companies.

In addition, it is said that the measure will reduce public debt interest. In 1989-90 it is estimated that it will reduce public debt interest by about $22m-we are not told how it is calculated-in 1991 by $350m, and thereafter by $330m per annum, a difference of $20m between 1990 and 1991 and years in the future. How have these calculations been done? Here is another piece of evidence that indicates that the present Labor Government believes that interest rates will remain as high as they are now not only in 1989-90 but also through 1990-91 and indefinitely into the future, because at 4.5 of Budget Paper No. 1 it says:

This measure will reduce outlays on public debt interest by $22m in 1989-90, $350m in 1990-91 and $330m per annum in subsequent years. The estimated revenue impact of the changes in 1991-92 and subsequent years is nil.

I make that point in passing about the horrendous rates of interest that both individuals and companies are now required to pay. The Government saves this money by selling treasury notes at a discount. The cost saving is the effective rate of interest by the revenue brought forward by the months of payment in advance for the tax paid. Presumably that is how the Government has calculated the $330m, but the Budget Papers do not tell us that.

If at the moment we assume that $1.5 billion of the corporate tax is paid by small companies liable for $20,000 or less, the $10 billion will be subject to earlier payment requirements. If we use the figures of Deloitte Haskins and Sells for a company paying 20 per cent interest or forgoing 20 per cent return on its investment in which that money would otherwise have been invested, the cost to the corporate sector will be $700m. If the Government T-note rate is 15 per cent it may be that the figure should have come out at $525m of interest saved. But to try to get to the $330m, I can only assume that $195m of the transfer will be as a consequence of the number and size of payments by the late balance companies. On a day when yet another bank has indicated record profits for the current financial year, I might point out that the banks are some of the big corporations which are late balance date corporations.

A $700m reduction in profits earned by the corporate sector or an increase in companies' expenses will reduce their taxable income. If they have expenses or they forgo income of $700m, the tax that will not be collected will, at current rates of taxation, amount to $280m. So if the Government is saving $330m on interest that it does not have to pay out, it is going to lose $280 on tax forgone on profits that are not being earned or on expenses that are being claimed. So one wonders whether disturbing the corporate sector for the sake of a net $50m is going to be worth the damage that it will do to the Australian economy. The Government cannot argue that the difference will be made up by economic growth because this would involve double accounting. Indeed, the decision implicit in this legislation may, in the view of many, actually retard the potential for growth because of the liquidity reduction in the corporate sector.

I have talked about interest being claimed as a deduction against tax. It is in that regard that I express the gravest concerns. I refer to an English decision, in the Smiths potato crisps case. I do not know whether they had salt with the potato crisps then, but certainly the Government is putting salt into the wounds that it is inflicting on the Australian corporate sector. That case dealt with whether interest and expenses incurred in finding the funds to pay tax should not be a deduction for tax purposes. That case, which occurred a long time ago, and a line of authority of cases was simply picked up and adopted in an Administrative Appeals Tribunal case in Australia in 1988 called V48. But the practice and the law have been different. I have tried to find out why, but without success. I have failed because I do not believe that there are any significant corporations which identify in their tax returns that the interest they have had to borrow on a higher overdraft or other forms of borrowing has been increased because they need the money to pay the tax. Yet everyone knows that at the four quarterly dates there is a draw-down on banks-the banks even call it `the tax draw-down'.

Up until today there has been some uncertainty as to whether the principles in the Smiths potato crisps case related to individuals-one could see the logic in their relating to individuals-or whether they related to corporations in the same way. In this legislation, under the stalking-horse of giving to taxpayers a relatively small concession-the right to deduct certain expenses in the tax administration of their affairs, appeals before tax tribunals and the like-the Government has codified what has been an uncertain law and made it a certain law. In giving the concessions that it describes in clause 8 of the Bill, the proposed amendment to section 69 of the principal Act, it states:
A deduction is not allowable under subsection (1) for expenditure that consists of:
(a) income tax-
I have no argument about that-
or
(b) an amount payable under part vi-

which is other taxes. There is no argument about that on the surface of it, although if I have time tonight I will deal with the effects of certain charges that are given the definition of `income tax'. The clause continues:
or
(c) a financing cost in relation to an amount covered by paragraph (a) or (b)-

which is a financing cost in relation to the payment of any tax. The practice has been for business enterprises to have a conglomerate borrowing arrangement. They have borrowed to keep their inventories, to finance their debtors, to purchase their fixed assets, to pay their wages and to pay their taxes. It has all gone into the melting pot and no-one until now has suggested that some proportion of that borrowing should be attributed to the tax that they have paid, notwithstanding the fact that it has been possible to look at corporate borrowings and to see the peaks and troughs. The peaks have occurred at the time of liability for corporate income tax. The Commissioner of Taxation has not taken action because he has been uncertain about the law. He has used small concessions as the stalking-horse and introduced into this legislation a specific legislative provision that the financing costs in relation to an amount covered, that is, payment of income tax or other taxes, shall not be tax deductable.

What will happen with the Tax Commissioner's audit army on 15 July 1990? My forecast is that, unless the Treasurer makes it quite clear that the practice will be as it was in the past, rather than in accordance with the electoral interpretation of the law, every corporation-large, small and medium sized-will fear the arrival of the audit army in June and July because the audit army can come in and say to a corporation: `You had an overdraft last year in July of $300,000. This year after you have paid your tax, allowing for inflation in your borrowings, your inventory has changed and your debt has changed and you now have an overdraft of $400,000-$100,000 more than you should have.

Under this legislation I forecast that the Tax Commissioner will use his power to go to those corporations and say that the interest is calculated against a benchmark-what benchmark I do not know-of the previous practice of payments on four quarterly dates, the principal is phased down and a pro rata formula is applied to the interest. Or will the Tax Commissioner say that he has made a mistake? He is not beyond doing that, saying `I did not administer it according to the law before, but I am going to now, and because you did not attribute your profits on an income earned basis week by week, or an end of year basis to 30 June, and did not put that money neatly away in a cash form so that you could pay me-if it was a part of your overdraft arrangements globally for your whole enterprise, whether it is a corner store, shoe manufacturing company, Smiths potato crisps or Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-we will now disallow your claim for that proportion of the interest'.

This legislation could be disastrous to the liquidity of Australian business enterprises if they cannot claim this as a tax deduction in the way they have done in practice in the past. There is no certainty that they will be able to do so under this specific piece of legislation, making it non-taxable but with no guidelines as to how one will calculate the non-taxable element of the interest paid by a corporation. This legislation is a disgraceful piece of vagueness which gives to the Tax Commissioner such immense powers that it is no wonder Australian industry is fearful of the consequences that might arise from it. The loss to Australian businesses is not only related to the interest that they may pay on money they need to pay their taxes early and the fact that the interest rate will not be 20 per cent but also could, in effect, be 35 per cent because of the non-tax deductability. Because of the slow-down in liquidity, companies are anticipating that their additional borrowings, as a consequence of their having to pay tax, and others having to pay tax, could well be double their tax liability. We will then see the immensity and unfairness of the non-tax deductability of this element of the legislation.

One may say that some businesses could then rearrange their affairs. They would have professionals to tell them how they could make quarantine arrangements so that no interest is apparently showing. Many small and middle sized Australian businesses will not be able to achieve that. This provision should be deleted from the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 November, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is totally opposed to this quick fix, mishmash legislation which comes on after the legislation that the House has just disposed of when the Government caved in and involved itself in an extraordinary about-face for which it will pay an awful price. I make it very clear that we have examined the Broadcasting Amendment Bill. My colleague the shadow Minister for communications, Senator Richard Alston, has examined this legislation in extraordinary detail and we have found it absolutely wanting. Indeed, we have found that it is yet another product of Rip Van Willis, the Minister for Transport and Communications. He has been sleeping on the sidelines for so much of this year while the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) has got itself into trouble, while the television networks have got themselves into trouble and while the legal position of broadcasting for radio and television in this country has fallen apart.

SPEECH.PARA: In the dying hours of the Thirty-fifth Parliament-I remind honourable members that we are now in the dying hours of the Thirty-fifth Parliament-the Minister has produced this quick fix legislation which ought to embarrass Government members because of its failure to address comprehensively the quagmire of the legal position on broadcasting in Australia in 1989. At the end of my address I will be moving a clear-cut second reading amendment and then in committee, if the opportunity permits given the gagging situation here tonight, I will seek to move further amendments to make very clear the intentions of the Opposition with regard to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill.

This Bill fails on several counts but two particular counts which it fails to address are the need for a fundamental overhaul of broadcasting legislation and the need to reduce the present complex plethora of regulations. The Government cannot have it both ways. The Government has initiated a comprehensive review and speaks of a comprehensive approach at some later date-perhaps next year-although the legislative timetable of the Parliament will clearly be disrupted next year with the forthcoming Federal election. So the Government has turned up here tonight in the dying hours of the 1989 session of the Thirty-fifth Parliament, and probably the closing stages of the Thirty-fifth Parliament before its dissolution for that election, with a Bill that is totally inadequate, that is regarded by the industry as totally inadequate and that is regarded by many learned people, including Sir Maurice Byers, as failing and going in many areas beyond the powers available under the Constitution with regard to the licensing and control of broadcasting of radio and television. I say to the Minister here tonight that, on this occasion, if he likes he should put to one side the arguments that will be advanced by the Opposition with regard to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill, but he cannot put aside the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers, which is clear cut, which is available no doubt to the Government, and which arrived like a dead cat on the Cabinet table and in the office of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), who is now leaving the chamber and who is responsible for the Broadcasting Amendment Bill.

Let me deal with the opinion of Sir Maurice Byers, a former Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia, and a man held in high regard by honourable members on both sides of the House. I am sure that the Minister has had the opportunity to read the advice given. Sir Maurice Byers says in part that a number of questions are raised by the Bill and he deals with each of those. He points to the fact that, under clause 3 (a) and (b), the new expression `suitability requirements' is introduced into the legislation. He points out that on any objective examination this represents a big increase in the powers of the Tribunal. He also brings in another concept which may be at fault with section 51 (v) of the Constitution. He says, and I quote specifically:
It is manifest that many of the powers conferred on the Tribunal-
by the Broadcasting Amendment Bill-

to give directions could not survive if read literally. Thus, if the licence holder is no longer able to meet the suitability requirements because of lack of financial capability, directions may not validly be given to bankers to lend it money or managers or technicians to enter its employ notwithstanding the power of 92m (2) by making failure to comply with directions under the proposed (1a) and (1b) an offence for each day the failure continues.

He goes on to discuss this in some detail. Clearly, what he is saying is that proposed new subsection 92m (2) (a), (b) and (c) is invalid as it is in excess of power. The coalition is not saying this; Sir Maurice Byers is saying this in a very comprehensive opinion which I hope the Minister has seen and studied closely. Indeed, Sir Maurice Byers goes on to discuss other aspects of the Bill and, as other honourable members wish to participate in this debate, I cannot dwell on all of those, other than to say that the conclusion in respect of the third part is whether the proposed power to order divestiture is compatible with the requirements of the Constitution. Again he ends up with a very clear-cut statement which should terrify the Minister as he presents this Bill to the House. Sir Maurice Byers says:
Both subsections are invalid. I answer this question accordingly and all questions as above.

That was in the more comprehensive part of his opinion. So here we have Sir Maurice Byers saying that this legislation before the House tonight exceeds the powers of the Constitution. The Minister can look forward to the testing of this legislation in another forum on another occasion. So we have a shoddy piece of legislation, one which has clearly been challenged by a very senior counsel in Australia. The coalition supports the opinion given because the Bill manifestly fails to meet the task at hand and to provide some form of consistent, comprehensive approach to the massive problems gripping the broadcasting areas of legislation in relation to both radio and television.

In one sense it is food for thought that there is a great deal of wisdom on this side of the House. Some honourable members will remember that the last time some major broadcasting legislation was before the Parliament Christopher Skase arrived in town. Christopher Skase decided to click his fingers in the hope that the coalition would buckle under completely to accommodate a situation that the mogul was putting forward at that time. We did not buckle under. We took a stand. It was not necessarily popular and was greeted that way. We did take a stand on that occasion in respect of a different context, albeit one in relation to the audience reach of television at that time. We will not buckle under with regard to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill before the House tonight. We will expose it as the quick fix, impossible solution that it offers to the Parliament and to the nation.

I believe the Minister should be ashamed to bring this type of approach before this House at this late part of the session of 1989. It could be likened to some form of leaking house roof-comprehensively leaking at that-and getting up with sticky tape to try to patch all the holes in such a roof, rather than getting on with the more fundamental job required if we are to overcome the problems which I have referred to.

In looking at detailed aspects of the legislation, I want to say that the power to refuse to renew a licence is one which ought to be examined very closely. Currently the Tribunal is required to exercise this power in the public interest, having regard to specified exclusive criteria, which include the suitability requirements, such as being a fit and proper person and having the necessary financial, technical and management capabilities. The Tribunal itself has identified the absurdity of the current uniform inquiry regulations. On 3 August 1989 the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, in a speech to the National Press Club, said:

. . . once every three years the Tribunal will conduct 54 separate licence renewal hearings where up to 98% of the programs on each service are networked. These renewals will each take a minimum of four months-
and be costly at that-
and they will all canvass the issue of adequate and comprehensive service; that is, 98% of programming will be looked at 54 times.

I added slightly to the quote but the meaning is very clear. It simply means that under the cumbersome renewal procedures 98 per cent of the programs will have to be looked at 54 times in repetition because of the way the legislation is structured. Yet the proposed amendments in the Broadcasting Amendment Bill do nothing to rectify this totally unsatisfactory situation. Instead they would effectively render the special criteria irrelevant by giving the Tribunal carte blanche. It would now be allowed to have regard to such other matters as the Tribunal considers relevant.

Let us look at the question of the power to suspend or revoke licences. Again, this centres around the question of suitability requirements. The amendments introduce this new statutory construct of `suitability requirements' which must be satisfied before the Tribunal can give third party directions in a virtually unlimited range of circumstances. The proposal is an implied rebuke to the ABT over its reasoning in the Bond decision and an implicit endorsement of the Federal Court of Australia's strong criticism of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. As the matter is currently before the High Court of Australia-actually, not quite-there is also a clear attempt to pre-empt the outcome. The Federal Court made it clear that the fit and proper conduct of a person such as Alan Bond had to be directly related to the continuing fitness and propriety of a licensing company. However, while the amendments emphasise the necessity to establish the link they offer little guidance to the Tribunal as to how this will be so. They ignore the inherently unsatisfactory and subjective value judgments upon which the existing licensing regime depends: firstly, the artificial attachment of personal qualities of a fit and proper person to the licensing company as a corporate entity and, secondly, the multifaceted and social engineering potential of notions such as `the financial, technical and management capabilities' necessary to provide an adequate and comprehensive service. The introduction of the suitability requirements concept, therefore, merely adds a further layer of complexity and contributes very little to the overall efficiency of broadcast regulations.

We could look at this other area of power to give directions. I will just touch briefly on the fact that that could lead to enabling the Tribunal to give directions to program suppliers whose contracts may be held to contribute to a licensee's lack of financial capability-that is a Pandora's box-and to banks whose credit policies may have a similar effect; to preventing or requiring the termination of employment of a news director, program manager or engineer; to preventing the reduction of a daily news service from one hour to half an hour or the reduction in the number of bulletins telecast each day; to requiring the employment of an expert in Australian children's films, a psychologist to advise on violence or an additional journalist to prepare weekend news; to preventing the closure of a studio or the sale of an outside broadcast van; and to requiring the purchase of particular technical equipment. The area of direction is one which is quite frightening and is not a comprehensive approach to the requirements for broadcasting legislation to be introduced in this Parliament.

The other particular area that time will allow me to highlight relates to the power to extend the grace period. Currently, the Tribunal can extend the six-month period of grace allowed for divestiture following a refusal to approve a share transaction because an applicant has failed to meet the suitability requirements. Past experience demonstrates that a six-month period for forced divestiture is inadequate. Extensions of time have been essential in facilitating Bond's sale of certain television stations. Under the amendments the power to extend the period would be removed. This is not only harsh but commercially unrealistic, A forced fire sale would unnecessarily punish innocent shareholders. It presumably proceeds on the assumption that a guilty party does not deserve to remain licensed, yet the very provision of a grace period recognises the need for some mitigation and breathing space-not unreasonably-to allow for an ordinary disposal.

We have just passed legislation which introduced amendments at the last hour to produce a doubling of the period of grace from 15 to 30 days in respect of the savage taxation requirements on small business. The Bill disposed of is one which I know you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will not allow me to dwell on. But we are going in the other direction in this section of the Broadcasting Amendment Bill. If inadequate efforts of disposal are made during the six-month period the Tribunal would undoubtedly decline to extend the term.

There is no policy basis for distinguishing between divestiture arising out of a failure to meet the suitability requirements and divestiture arising out of breach of the cross-media ownership limits. Provided that the integrity of a service can be safeguarded in the interim, any licensee facing forced divestiture should be able to apply for an extension. It is quite unacceptable to suggest that a person who fails a suitability test is not entitled to any special consideration in attempts to realise an adequate sale price. Such persons are not necessarily guilty of any moral wrongdoings. They may be no more than victims of the Government's current high interest rate policy.

Other members speaking for the coalition will make it very clear why the Opposition is so totally opposed to this approach by the Government in relation to this legislation. The Government and the Minister responsible must be embarrassed at the Bill coming in at this late hour. The Minister is one of these Ministers who operate out of a small but quite powerful ministerial office. He has a small inner court of very close contacts and advisers. At times he almost stands alone and away from his various departments, from his various authorities and from his various government business enterprises. The Minister looks quite surprised at my remarks. He could hardly describe his relations with Qantas Airways Ltd throughout 1989 as cohesive, congenial and in any way of a constructive nature, particularly with regard to the question of the successor to the Chief Executive of Qantas and the successor to the Chairman of Qantas. I think the reputation of the Minister around Canberra is just that-one of being somewhat of a loner who stands aloof from the industries relating to his portfolio, one who has failed to make real progress in the challenging area of micro-economic reform. That was laid down by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as the absolute imperative at the start of this parliamentary term and in terms of the Prime Minister's 1987 election promise to `urgently reform this nightmarish legislation'.

What have we had? We have this Broadcasting Amendment Bill, which does nothing to reform comprehensively this nightmarish legislation. We are now at the eleventh hour. I know that my good friend the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson), will be speaking later. We will address this issue by way of amendment and it will be addressed also in the Senate. The Opposition is totally opposed to the approach in the Broadcasting Amendment Bill. For that reason I move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``the House declines to give the Bill a second reading, and deplores the Government's hasty and ill-conceived attempt to bestow a vast new range of unpredictable and unnecessary powers on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in a desperate attempt to divert attention from its total failure to introduce any meaningful reforms of broadcasting regulation despite the Prime Minister's unequivocal 1987 election promise to `urgently reform this nightmarish legislation' ''.
I commend the amendment to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1989. I suppose what first of all surprises me is that the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), speaking on behalf of the shadow spokesperson for communications, Senator Alston, had the gall to oppose the Bill, given that probably just over 12 months ago he supported a report to the House which recommended amendments to the Broadcasting Act basically identical to those being proposed by the Government. That seems rather strange, given that the Government has introduced amendments which provide power for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to implement and make effective its decisions, certainly in relation to the issue of fit and proper persons, which was the major issue addressed in our report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. But we find that the Opposition opposes the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the difficulties we have is that the Opposition now seems to base its decision on whether to support or oppose legislation on a single advice from external people with no relationship to recognised bodies. Retired people or anyone with an interest can write in and say that they have a view that legislation is perhaps outside of the role of the Government, against the Constitution, or whatever. Based on a single letter written in that vein, the Opposition will now determine its policy on communications and, I assume, therefore, its policy on every other matter that will be presented to the Parliament. Its policy will be determined by whoever writes to it at any particular time.

The fact is that the Opposition has no policy on communications. I will give a couple of examples to show that. The Opposition spokesperson has called for the Government to take urgent action to deal with the crisis in broadcasting. He has called for the Government to abolish the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. He has called for the Government to have the Tribunal hold inquiries into certain matters relating to the crisis in the industry. But, when the Government takes some action to give the Tribunal power to implement decisions and make effective determinations that it has made, the Opposition says, `You cannot do that. We cannot support it because it is done in haste'.

Let us look at the history surrounding these matters. A report was presented to the Parliament in December 1988. So almost 12 months ago we began discussion on this matter. Prior to that, there were discussions about the effectiveness of the Broadcasting Act and the need to take action in certain areas. Numerous reports have been presented to the Parliament. Numerous reports have been made public for discussion on this issue. Virtually everybody in the community accepts the need to do something. We need to give the Tribunal the effective power to implement the intention of its decisions.

The Government's amendments to section 92m and other sections allow it to place conditions on a licence, and to allow divestiture of a licence where a person is found to be not fit and proper to hold a licence. I suppose it is not surprising that the Opposition has opted to quote selectively from the Bond Media Ltd press release of today, given that it made its decision in haste; it did not have much substance behind it. Luckily for the Opposition, a 15-page document has come out which has given the Opposition 15 minutes of speaking time today. Bond Media complained that six months was too short a time in which to dispose of an asset. It failed to mention that that short restrictive time applies in one circumstance only, that is, where, after all the legal avenues have been allowed, a person-or a licensee in the case of a corporation-is found guilty of being not fit and proper to hold a licence. To suggest that, having found that a person or body is not fit and proper to hold a licence, it is then adequate to give unlimited time in which to dispose of a licence makes an absolute mockery of the Act. Clearly, in the circumstances where somebody has abused the privileged position of holding a broadcasting licence, and has been found guilty of not being fit and proper, that person ought to dispose of that licence in the shortest possible time. Many would consider six months to be more than adequate to dispose of a licence. In other circumstances a longer period is permitted. While six months is the notional time, there is the option to extend the period.

The honourable member for Farrer made the comment that the Bill gives carte blanche to the Tribunal to make all sorts of judgments about whether a person is fit and proper. That is not the case. It is clearly a misunderstanding of the situation. The prerequisites to finding whether a person is fit and proper are the same as they have been for many years. The processes are the same. The rights of the licensee are the same. All we are doing with this amendment is extending the options that the Tribunal has when it reaches a decision at the end of the day. Instead of just being faced with the option of cancellation of the licence, therefore removing service to the community at large-to the people who have not committed any offence, but who would suffer the loss of service-we are extending the options for the Tribunal to ensure that that service continues but that the integrity of the Tribunal's decision is applied correctly.

We have not seen a solution in the Opposition's amendment. It has no idea what to do. It has no answer. Since we have been in office, we have seen major reforms to and a major restructuring of the broadcasting industry, with changes to ownership rules, cross-media rules, et cetera. The Government has continued its process of inquiry and its encouragement of public participation. For the Opposition to stand up and say that these decisions are made in haste is to ignore the historical facts of what has been going on over the last two or three years.

The other telling point is that these amendments, to some extent, have been sponsored by major sections of the industry which have approached the Government and said, `Look, in consideration of the trustee arrangements, we believe there are better administrative ways of dealing with these problems'. The extension of subsection 92m was one way of dealing with this. Rather than acting in haste, we have been responsive to some of the points that have been raised by the industry itself. Of course Bond Media is not happy about the amendments. It does not want any change because it is under fire. It is the one in the frying pan, so to speak. It would rather that there be no solution to the problem. Should Bond Media lose its case, the fact that the legislation is deficient at the moment would almost certainly mean that it could continue to hold a licence for quite some considerable time. It does not want a solution; it will oppose any possible solution. So we ought to ignore the arguments being put forward by the Opposition.

The previous speaker said that part of the problem was that the Tribunal would be able to put all sorts of conditions on the licence, like preventing the termination of employment, preventing the reduction of daily news services, requiring the employment of additional journalists, and so on. I am not too sure whether people in the community would not consider those to be very good and reasonable powers for the Tribunal to have. I can recall the problems that occurred with the purchase by Fairfax of Channel 7 in Melbourne and the demand from the Melbourne metropolitan public for the Government and the Tribunal to take action to prevent the cancellation of shows that people in Melbourne wanted, to prevent the termination of employment, and to prevent Sydney based programs being forced on the Melbourne community.

What people forget is that broadcasting is different when it comes to the normal range of industrial rules and regulations. Broadcasting is something that affects the community, and people demand a say about what they receive in their homes and about the sorts of programs provided and the standard of them. This requires regulation and an effective administering body. Some of the powers of the Tribunal that are being criticised relate to things that are wanted by members of the public, who recognise that the power that is given to certain individuals by the bestowing of a licence is more than such individuals should have and that there is a need to control it. So I am not worried that the Tribunal should have these powers. Rather, I want to ensure that the Tribunal is effective and fair in administering its decision making process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite what the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) has just said, it cannot but be argued that the Broadcasting Amendment Bill must surely join the ranks of the mounting list of ill-conceived, hastily prepared and politically motivated decisions of the Hawke Government. I do not need to remind the House of the 1987 election promise from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that `by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty'; of his Government's attempt to woo the environment vote by deferring a decision on Coronation Hill until after the next election; of the recent decision to hand out $36m in industry assistance to one of the world's most profitable enterprises-Kodak; and of his inflammatory handling of the dispute that apparently does not exist-the pilots dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have the `Bond Bill'-a piecemeal and unnecessary Bill with amendments of such complex implications that they will worsen rather than assist legislation which the Prime Minister himself has acknowledged as being `nightmarish'. Australians have a right to ask: Why this legislation and why now? The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) admits himself that comprehensive reforms to the Broadcasting Act are being developed quickly and will be introduced in the next autumn and Budget sittings of Parliament. I ask the Minister: What is so urgent about the amendments in this Bill before us tonight that they could not be held over for a few months and incorporated in a consolidated document early in 1990? I notice that the Minister, who is at the table, does not even look up when these questions are asked. I wonder whether he is even listening.

As we all know, the reason has more to do with politics than with any rational commonsense approach to the needs of the broadcasting industry. There is a public perception-one which the nature and timing of this Bill does absolutely nothing to dispel-that the legislation contains `Bond amendments' in the event that the High Court of Australia upholds the original Australian Broadcasting Tribunal finding that Bond Media, as licensee of the Nine Network, is not a fit and proper person.

The Minister's second reading speech would have us believe that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is presently faced with extremely limited options with regard to the Bond case and that revocation of the Nine Network licence is either inevitable or mandatory. On the contrary, the Federal Court's ruling on the Tribunal's findings expressed the opinion that the Tribunal has a wide discretion to take into account all aspects of the public interest in deciding whether to suspend or revoke licences, to impose conditions or to accept undertakings.

It is still a puzzle to many of us why the Tribunal was not prepared to use its conditions and undertakings powers in the Bond Media case. The fact that they are uncontested powers is surely not a sufficient reason, since this is true of almost all the Tribunal's powers. In any event, the course of action adopted by the Tribunal has led to Federal Court and High Court action-and amending legislation, the result of which is arguably less satisfactory than if the conditions and undertakings powers had been contested in their own right.

The Tribunal has expressed the opinion that its powers to give directions are inadequate and it seems to have in mind that circumstances could arise in which corporate structuring might prevent its directions from reaching the person responsible for the breach of conditions. This was clearly not so in the Bond case, yet the amendments in this Bill go far beyond that perceived weakness and will give the Tribunal what can only be described as sweeping powers to give almost unlimited directions to whomever it wishes-for example, involving itself directly in commercial aspects of a licensee's operations, such as programming decisions, the employment of key personnel, and the relationship with program suppliers.

There is serious industry concern about the implications of these amendments and their ultimate influence on commercial decision making. I believe that this measure constitutes an incredible extension of the regulatory powers of the Tribunal, potentially into the minutia of the administration, management and operation of broadcasting functions. I remind the House that it comes only months before the Government, on its own admission, is to make reforms to which it is committed and which will simplify what is acknowledged to be complex and unwieldy legislation. The Bill is incompatible with that objective.

We in the coalition parties believed that the Government, the Opposition and the broadcasting industry were in broad agreement about the need for a fundamental overhaul of broadcasting legislation which would simplify its operation and introduce a degree of deregulation to the industry. Despite that, we see the Government introduce a Bill which is so convoluted in its wording and potentially so intrusive and complex in its operation that it is the very antithesis of the rationalisation process proposed by the Government for 1990.

Furthermore, the Government is doing this at a time when the Bond case is before the High Court, and its actions will be viewed with concern by those who, quite correctly, question the propriety of changing the rules while the game is still in progress. The truth is that the amending legislation smacks of panic. In fact, it is very typical of the actions of the Government at the present time. Industry has not been consulted. The legislation has obviously been prepared in great haste and is badly presented. The need for its extended provisions is not convincing. They fly in the face of the generally agreed goal of simplification and deregulation and they provide the Tribunal with controversial new powers.

One is bound to ask why this is so. Even if one was generous enough to overlook the implications of this measure for the Nine Network, the reason, sadly, comes down to pure political expediency and, again, poor judgment. This is a face saving exercise to disguise the fact that the Prime Minister promised before the 1987 election that his Government would `urgently reform this nightmarish legislation'. The amending legislation before us tonight is really nothing more than a hurried piece of theatricals to show that almost three years after the Prime Minister's promise of reforms the Government not only is doing something but can make promises, expansively, in a second reading speech about the reforms that it now intends to bring down in 1990. It is for these reasons and for the reasons outlined by my colleague that the Opposition opposes this Bill in its totality and has moved the second reading amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to speak only briefly on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill, and particularly in relation to the principal amendment, which is referred to as section 92m. I will also make some comments about other aspects of the Bill which hitherto have not been debated, and I refer to the proposed amendments in relation to public radio. I have a particular interest in that area as a public radio station is located contiguous to my electorate of Bendigo, and I refer to radio station 3ccc FM. The general thrust of the legislation and the principal amendment is to give the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) a more flexible range of remedies as an alternative to licence suspension or revocation where an adverse finding is made against the suitability of a commercial radio or television licensee.

SPEECH.PARA: As we have heard already in the debate, the proposed alternative remedies will enable the Tribunal to revoke, vary or impose licence conditions, issue directions and if necessary direct interests to be divested within six months. As I have said, the Bill contains a number of other amendments, including a number which relate to public radio, and I will say a few words about those in a moment. I note that the Opposition has moved an amendment in relation to the second reading motion and really I must concur with the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson), who really described the amendment as totally meaningless and totally worthless. It is meaningless and worthless because it does nothing at all to clarify the Broadcasting Act and it does nothing at all to clarify the position which the Government has attempted to make clear through the proposed amendments in this Bill.

Basically, the Opposition is simply saying that this is a hasty piece of legislation, it is a little bit hard for Parliament to come to terms with and therefore we should do nothing and let the existing legislation continue. From the Government's perspective that position is not satisfactory and we believe that the Act needs amending. I think it is pertinent to refer to the description of these changes by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) when referring to this legislation. The Minister said that at present the Tribunal would be faced with extremely limited options if, after conducting an inquiry which it was required to hold, it found that a commercial licensee was no longer fit and proper or no longer had the financial, technical or management capacity to provide an adequate and comprehensive service. At the present time the Tribunal may only impose licence conditions or suspend, revoke or not renew a licence.
