However, if a licensee's unsuitability were due to the conduct or character of a person in a position to control the licensee company or its operations, quite clearly licence conditions may not be an effective remedy. That is simply because, as the Minister put it, the conditions may not be capable of affecting the influence of the relative person on the licensee company.

The only other remedies available-suspension, revocation or refusal to renew a licence-would put the service off the air. Quite logically, it follows that cessation of the service penalises not only the licensee company but also the viewing or listening public and innocent shareholders and creditors. So there is a need, as the Minister says quite clearly in his second reading speech, to give the Tribunal more flexible and less draconian remedies. That is really what this Bill is all about-it is about achieving those objectives. I must say that I believe that the Bill has been properly worded. There is a need to amend the principal Act and really in simplistic terms the Bill provides a range of more flexible remedies to deal with the problem whereby a licensee may not be considered to be a fit and proper person to hold a licence.

The honourable member for Aston referred to the need for regulation in the broadcasting industry, and the fact is that there is a need to regulate the industry. Also, there is a need to let market forces operate, but it would be foolish in the extreme to suggest that there should not be regulation in the public broadcasting industry, which has such an impact on viewing audiences and on people who listen to the radio. So, there is a need for rules and standards to be applied. With this legislation the Government is simply providing a more flexible range of remedies to deal with problems that might arise in relation to the fitness or propriety of people who hold licences.

In respect of the Opposition's amendment, I should say that one of the claims made by Opposition speakers in this debate tonight is that the Government has done nothing in the past two or three years to reform or change the Broadcasting Act. I point out that in 1987 this Government made very substantial changes to the Act-in fact, the biggest changes that have been made to the Act for many years. The following year we reformed the limitations on the ownership and control of commercial radio stations. As an example of just some of the things that we have done in those reforms to the Act and subsequently, I indicate that we replaced the old two-station rule in television with limitations based on audience reach-a major and dramatic change introduced by this Government. We replaced the old limit on radio station holdings with new limits which recognise the growth, development and changes which are occurring in the radio industry. We have also introduced, of course, the historic media limits between radio, television and newspaper outlets in the same marketplace. These reforms in the life of this and previous parliaments-and I refer to the cross-media ownership laws-were quite historic. This Government has a record of change and reform, and broadcasting ownership and control policies have been clearly stated at all times by this Government.

The other part of the legislation which I said I would refer to this evening relates to public radio. Amendments included in this Bill enable aspiring public licensees when conducting test transmissions to broadcast sponsorship announcements in accordance with the rules applying to public broadcasters, and they also permit public radio licensees to broadcast community promotion material. It is really on the question of promotion material that I will comment tonight. Over the past few years there has been enormous growth in Australia's public broadcasting industry. Public radio broadcasting was introduced in 1972. It is a non-profit, non-commercial, community owned and operated form of broadcasting and its objective is to complement the commercial and national broadcasting sectors. I understand that today there are more than 80 public broadcasting radio stations on air and that something like a further 20 licensees are waiting to receive approval for licences next year.

The Government does provide and has provided funding to the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia over a number of years at a level of $300,000. While the Government has maintained that amount in recent years in nominal terms, in real terms there has been some decline in the commitment that the Government has been able to make to the public broadcasting industry. I guess the Government has had to juggle resources, and it has had to turn around a $9.6 billion deficit. In fact, the Government has turned it into a $9 billion surplus. That has been appropriate to set the macro-economic agenda correctly in Australia. The Government has not been able to increase funding in real terms for public broadcasting, but it has maintained that funding level of $300,000 a year in nominal terms. I would like to see that amount increased in the future if that is possible because, as I said, next year it is likely that another 20 public radio stations will come on air. Last year I think something like eight or nine public radio stations went on air and the year before it was three or four. Clearly, their share of the available resources of the Public Broadcasting Association was somewhat greater than that which will be available if 20 new stations come on air next year. I think it would be desirable if the Government were able to provide additional resources to the Public Broadcasting Association to assist those 20 stations which will come on air next year.

There is another sense in which I am talking about the financial viability of public broadcasting, and that is that public radio stations have traditionally relied for about 70 to 80 per cent of their income on sponsorship announcements. Typically, they are announcements for local firms, shops and industries in the broadcast area. In a non-advertising but informative sense the announcements can provide information which is broadcast on public radio for a fee. That has provided, as I said, about three-quarters of the income for public radio stations. Over recent years, the Broadcasting Tribunal has made a number of what seem to me rather ad hoc decisions that have made it very difficult for the public broadcasting stations to plan ahead with any certainty in relation to sponsorship.

A decision was made earlier this year in relation to the licence renewal of one radio station which, it appeared, had been breaching the spirit of the Act. As a result, the determination made by the Broadcasting Tribunal imposes some difficult and rigid standards on public broadcasting sponsorship. For instance, I am told that, under the new rules set by the Tribunal-the precedent from its ruling on the licence renewal-it is not possible to mention a sponsor's name twice in a particular sponsorship and it is not possible to mention the phone number of a sponsoring body or firm twice in a sponsorship announcement. This has really meant that public radio is uncertain about the sponsorship rules and standards that apply.

In the Bill before the House, the Government makes clear that community sponsorship announcements in future will be acceptable. I very much welcome that commitment and that alteration to the legislation. It also basically implies that we are now looking to the Tribunal to establish standards in relation to sponsorship and that, if the Tribunal does not come up with standards in the future, the Government may have to look at incorporating those standards by amending the legislation in future.

Personally, I would welcome the Tribunal looking at the issue of sponsorship as soon as possible. It does not seem to me to be a difficult task to establish a set of standards, rules and guidelines that will provide the framework on which public radio stations can work out their future cash flow, income and potential sponsorship. I do not think it will be a difficult task to establish those standards, and I hope that the Tribunal does that soon.

The Minister has made clear in his second reading speech on the Bill-and other members on this side have made clear-that we are asking the Tribunal to examine the question of standards. If the Tribunal does not do that, the Government has indicated that it will consider amending the legislation in future. I believe that it is vitally important to the future of public radio in Australia that the standards for sponsorship are outlined clearly, so that public radio stations can plan ahead over the years and make decisions about what forms of sponsorship will or will not be acceptable in terms of the Act.

In conclusion, I support the changes outlined in the Bill. I support the principal change to broadcasting ownership and control in relation to fitness. This is a simple measure that gives the Tribunal more flexibility in the remedies that it can apply. In relation to public broadcasting, I support the changes we have outlined, and I hope that the Tribunal will soon address the question of standards for public radio broadcasting sponsorship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many members of the House will recall that in his policy speech in 1987 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made it clear that one of the ambitions of the Australian Labor Party would be to clean up the Broadcasting Act, which he damned as it was then written. This Broadcasting Amendment Bill is really the first attempt by the Government to simplify and clarify that extremely complex and cumbersome legislation. While all honourable members would agree that the Broadcasting Act does require clarification, revision and simplification, the fact is that the proposal the Government has brought to the House today is a piecemeal, and not a comprehensive, approach.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of how these matters have developed only illustrates how true it is that this is indeed a piecemeal approach. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) set up a task force in his own Department of Transport and Communications headed by a Deputy Secretary to the Department, and they worked up some proposals that I and many members of the Labor Party, including the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson), let me add, thought were not terribly well considered. Perhaps the Minister agreed with those proposals. In any case, the Deputy Secretary to the Department committed what the Minister regarded as some sort of solecism by speaking to the media about his view-and I think I am right in recalling this-that the market could decide the standards for children's television. So horrific was the concept of the market of ordinary people making a decision and recommendation to the Minister and of a public servant suggesting that heresy that the Deputy Secretary was removed as Chairman of that task force and has subsequently been replaced by the Secretary to the Department as Chairman of that task force.

That was the first accident that happened in this process, and the second has clearly occurred within the Labor Party Caucus. The Caucus has now set up a watchdog committee headed by the honourable member for Aston and including-I think I am right in saying-a couple of senators and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). This watchdog committee will keep an eye on the Minister and ensure that any future proposals he brings forward are properly considered, rational and comprehensive proposals. This is the sort of Caucus revolt we used to see in the days of the Whitlam Government. What we have here now is a Minister who doubtless remembers well the catastrophe of the Whitlam Government and who is finding his own integrity as a Minister undermined by the Caucus zealots who are interested in this issue.

As I have said, this is piecemeal legislation, not legislation that will simplify, clarify and rewrite the Broadcasting Act. It is piecemeal and messy legislation because, as previous speakers have pointed out and as will be pointed out in another place at some length, there are real questions about just how constitutional the legislation is. There are also real questions about how successful it will really be in achieving the objectives it sets itself, such as the objective of simplifying the way in which the Tribunal can handle the circumstance that nearly arose-but did not quite arise-in relation to Bond Media and its ownership of Channel 9. Whether this legislation would successfully deal with that is, of course, hypothetical as a result of the various court proceedings that took place in that instance. However, the fact is that this legislation raises real questions about constitutional validity. Therefore, it is messy, ill-considered, piecemeal legislation. The Government must come forward with the legislation that it once said it would introduce-legislation that will simplify, clarify and make much more comprehensive the operation of the Broadcasting Act.

In pursuing these sorts of objectives and, indeed, in introducing this type of legislation, the Government really needs to rethink the whole rationale of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and how it works. It needs to stop and ask itself several basic threshold questions, as they are called nowadays, of the kind that have been drawn to the attention of a number of members of this House by the Business Regulation Review Unit. That Unit is not some think-tank out in the community supported by the business community; it is an arm of the Federal Government. It has successfully raised some of these threshold questions about the role of the Broadcasting Tribunal and indeed has raised the question of whether we truly need a Broadcasting Tribunal at all.

I have personally concluded that we do need the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. However, in coming to that conclusion, the Government needs to consider basically what the Tribunal is set up to do and how more comprehensively and intelligently it can pursue that role. After all, when it comes to regulating the electronic media, we must remember that we already have the Trade Practices Commission, the Trade Practices Act, the National Companies and Securities Commission, foreign ownership requirements and a whole range of regulatory mechanisms. The Tribunal comes on top of those mechanisms. We need to understand how the Tribunal fits into that pattern, rather than have it operate as though other pieces of legislation do not exist.

There are two basic arguments why we would want to have the Tribunal. First, there is a desire to regulate the power of broadcasting to influence attitudes in the community. This is the popular and usual approach to the justification of the existence of the Tribunal. In its July 1989 discussion paper entitled Review of Broadcasting Regulations, the Department of Transport and Communications stated:
. . . the rationale for regulating the content of broadcasting services . . . lies in the power of broadcast services to influence public opinion and attitudes.

This view marks out broadcasting as being strikingly different from any other form of business. It also represents broadcasting as being qualitatively different from other media, arguing that broadcasting should be `subject to controls on content which need not apply to those other means'. That is one of the justifications for having a tribunal. The spectrum is a commonly owned resource and that warrants, as others have said in this debate already, some community control over that resource-whatever `community control' may mean. I suppose one could go on to argue that we do not want to see the electronic media-broadcasting-used to influence so-called political attitudes. That does not mean just party political attitudes but general political attitudes-attitudes to social, economic and other issues in the community. It is worth remembering that those restrictions are placed only on the electronic media; the same restrictions do not apply to the print media. In other words, there is a real inconsistency in approach when one considers that proposition.

The other aspect of this argument is that the Government should set minimum community standards. There is a strong argument in favour of that, but I think the strength of the argument lies ultimately in the protection of children. It is not an argument along the lines that the Government should decide what is good for adults in the community. Ultimately we want people to be able to make decisions about what they would like to watch on television and what they would like to listen to on the radio. It will not be for the Government, or some tribunal arbitrarily established by the Government, to make that judgment. After all, if they make the judgment that people should watch certain types of programs, that is it: they simply will not watch the programs. There has to be an intelligent attitude to that. I really think the basic argument for setting minimum standards revolves around the protection of children.

The other aspect of this argument is that of national identity, that our television and radio programs have to have an Australian look. Australians probably want an Australian look on their television and radio, and that is understandable. I am a good example of somebody who wants to see that. Given that we want to see the Australian look, particularly on television, I would have thought the market would naturally ensure that one was provided. We can see that from the degree of Australian content that is provided by most, but not all, of the networks. We cannot see that from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), by the way, but the ABC is not subject to the guidelines of the Tribunal and it ought to be. That is not just my view; it is the view of many members of the Australian Labor Party as well and it is the view of the House of Representatives Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

The second argument for a role for the Tribunal is the argument that somehow the marketplace has failed and is not going to work. That argument revolves around the scarcity of the spectrum. I think all of us in this House want to avoid monopolies, although the Labor Party enjoys monopolies in the public sector and is quite happy to have them there. On this side of the House we do not like monopolies at all. Of course, the issue of the avoidance of monopolies is addressed by the Trade Practices Act, so whether the Tribunal plays any part in that is probably a peripheral issue. We on this side of the House want to avoid the concentration of market power. In some areas of the media the Government has shown a distinct reluctance even to address that issue. I suppose that is another debate.

The scarcity issue is an interesting one. One of the consequences of scarcity of the spectrum is the accumulation of what economists would call monopoly rents. It is interesting to look back a couple of years-perhaps three years-at the prices that were paid for networks Seven, Nine and Ten. When one looks at the prices and the then valuation of the assets one can see that the difference is in the vicinity of $500m, although that is a very loose back-of-the-envelope estimate. That represents the monopoly rents that were involved in those licensees having the privilege of access to a scarcity of spectrum. Because of that privilege there is a strong argument for giving the Tribunal a very real role. I rest by the report that I was prepared to sign of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure in November of last year-just a year ago-which drew that very conclusion.

Changing technology will render superfluous the argument about market failure. Eventually when we move to pay television and new forms of communications technology it simply will not matter because the scarcity of spectrum issue will no longer be relevant. There will be such diversity, such a choice, that scarcity will not be a problem. In the meantime the Government needs to ensure that the Tribunal does its work smoothly and that its work is comprehensible and fair.

I come back to where I started. Some of the objectives of this legislation are fine, but it is piecemeal legislation. The Minister has had plenty of time to consider putting together a comprehensive package. He has found confusion and chaos everywhere and has doubtless suffered enormous cross-pressures-I am a little sympathetic towards him-with the networks bullying and cajoling him and some of his colleagues doing the same thing. We all know who amongst his colleagues are close to some of the media moguls. I need not go into that, but we know who they are. He is subject to those pressures and, presumably, to pressures of integrity and the like. I hope the Government comes up with an intelligible, comprehensive package instead of this piecemeal nonsense which has been thrust into the House tonight in order to deal with the so-called Bond contingency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter the debate tonight in support of the Broadcasting Amendment Bill. I do so mindful of some of the comments made earlier tonight in this debate by my colleagues on this side of the House. I am particularly mindful of comments made by the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) because he clearly demonstrated that, contrary to those on this side of the House, those on the other side are totally confused as to what they really stand for. He was able to demonstrate-and I am sure any person who cares to flick through the newspapers of the last couple of months will see this amply demonstrated-that on the one hand the Opposition spokesman on broadcasting suggests that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) needs to carry out a full inquiry into broadcasting in this country. The next day he makes a statement that the Tribunal needs to be abolished, and in fact the headline of the Melbourne Herald on 16 October this year reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Coalition plans to abolish the ABT.

Clearly, there is total confusion as to what the Opposition wants. On the other hand, this legislation is a comprehensive attempt by the Government to clean up a problem and it has been referred to in colloquial terms as the Bond amendment. Quite simply, rulings handed down by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, challenged in the High Court of Australia, and subsequently appealed once again, have led to a deal of confusion.

One of the things that concern me greatly about this is the effect the ramifications decisions made under the existing legislation might have in areas such as my own. The Government's broadcasting policies-I am referring here to the aggregation proposals which have been put in place-clearly demonstrate that there can be a disadvantage to the people in the south-east of New South Wales if this legislation does not go through. What could happen if this legislation does not go through is that basically the Tribunal would have two options. If the appeal in the High Court about being a fit and proper person to hold a licence is upheld or thrown out or the legislation stands as it is, the Tribunal can do two things: it can do absolutely nothing, and there would be a tremendous hue and cry within the community if it did nothing; or it can revoke the licence.

Can the House imagine what it would mean if the Nine network went off air? The Nine network is the premier network in Australia. I am pleased to see the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) here because he knows full well that the premier network in the south-east of New South Wales is the Nine network, which is taken through WIN Television. One would see WIN Television going off air as well. It has just spent millions of dollars upgrading all of its equipment so that it reaches from Wollongong down to the Victorian border and, under aggregation, is putting in millions of dollars worth of equipment to get into Wagga Wagga, Orange and Bathurst. All of this has been put at risk, and yet we hear Opposition members say that the legislation is not comprehensive enough, that it is dreadful, again it is looking after mates, and all that sort of rubbish that they continue to go on with.

Clearly the legislation fulfils a necessary role of giving the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, as was said in the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), access to more appropriate remedies in cases where a commercial radio or television licensee does not meet the basic suitability requirements that are currently applicable to a licence. That is what it is all about. Again, going through the history of what happened in the Bond case with the network, in June the ABT found that, because Bond had made an improper payment of some $400,000 to the former Queensland Premier, Bond himself was not a fit and proper person to hold a broadcasting licence. Bond subsequently appealed to the High Court, as we know, and in September the High Court overturned that finding and ruled that the ABT findings against Bond were `impossible in logic and common sense'. It went on to say that the Tribunal had made errors of law by ignoring positive evidence about the management of Bond's broadcasting interests and by failing to distinguish between Bond's fitness and that of the licensee companies.

According to what the High Court ruled, the functions of the Tribunal are unclear in that respect. Surely everyone in this place would agree that there is a need to understand what constitutes a fit and proper person in terms of holding a licence. But, more importantly, out of all this it is important for everyone to understand what the ramifications would be if nothing was done. I for one am not prepared to sit here and say, `Let it go. Don't worry about all of those hundreds of thousands of people in the Illawarra and in the electorates of the honourable member for Gilmore and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), not to mention out in the west and so on'. I am not prepared to say, `Let us forget about all those and let one of the television stations go off the air'. I would not suggest that we should not worry about all of the job losses that will come or about medium business enterprises that those on the other side suggested that this Government was kicking to death in other legislation in this House this afternoon. I would not suggest that we should not worry about them going to the wall or about WIN television, the journalists and the people that work for them having to go to the wall because of the Opposition's failure to endorse what this Government is trying to do.

I come back to the point that we have seen a realistic attempt by this Government to do something about cleaning up what clearly is a situation that is not sustainable. The Government has also indicated that further reforms will be developed and that that legislation will be introduced next year when we come back. I think it is fair to suggest that the operation of key areas in the ABT's responsibility-ownership and the control enforcement scheme-need to be looked at in that regard. But there is a need to give the Tribunal more flexibility and less draconian remedies. The remedies can be described simply as that-draconian. What could be more draconian than the premier television network going off the air? What could be more draconian than failing to provide a television service to people through a major part of New South Wales, that part of Australia where aggregation was first implemented and which is a trial for the rest of Australia?

I conclude by saying that there is clearly a lack of understanding by those opposite as to what the Bill seeks to do. In his second reading speech the Minister clearly outlined the ramifications for broadcasting, television, and perhaps in future in terms of radio, if people were found not to be fit and proper persons to hold licences. Additionally, the question of whether it is the management or the person is subject to interpretation. The Tribunal ruled in one way, the High Court overturned that, and now there is an appeal pending. We are getting down to matters of law. The Tribunal rightly said in October, when it decided to appeal the High Court decision, that its appeal was on the ground that the ABT was concerned with `the real world and not legal fiction'. The real world as far as I am concerned and as far as the people of the Illawarra are concerned is that people have access to the television networks that they have had ever since WIN television started broadcasting out of there with local news and a whole range of programs with local content. We do not want to see that jeopardised. We do not want to see that lost.

I am pleased that the honourable member for Gilmore is present because I feel quietly confident that he will support me on this. He, for one, would not like to see the network lost. He gets good coverage on WIN television, just like the rest of us who represent the best part of New South Wales. To lose that when the company has such an incredible audience reach is something I am sure no politician in that coverage area would like to sustain.

I say once again, in conclusion, that there is a need to clarify this point. This legislation does that. It is a pity that those on the other side do not understand what it is all about, but that is not surprising because day after day confusing signals come out of the latest spokesman on communications. One day the Opposition is in support; the next day it says that the Tribunal should go; the next day it says that there should be full inquiries based on what the Tribunal's powers are. It is a nonsense. This legislation will do something positive, and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution made by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) was interesting to follow. He referred to an area that he and I both know very well as we represent portions of an area that is covered by a significant regional television station. One assertion he has made in his contribution tonight has been that the Opposition is in chaos and confusion as to its approach to communications matters. I point out to the Parliament that Australia currently suffers from a communications industry which is in chaos. Many people would say that the chaos that reigns in it is equal to that in the ranks of the Government at the present time. Nobody who knows anything about the communications industry in Australia today would argue with the fact that, at whichever level of communications one looks, the industry is in a mess. I suppose that the Government recognises that in part by introducing the Broadcasting Amendment Bill tonight, which it is trying to force through using the guillotine to cut off debate as it tries to bully the Parliament into accepting the legislation that it imposes upon it.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation does not tidy up the mess that this Government has created in our communications industries today. Indeed, it could be argued successfully that the mess that Australia's communications industries find themselves in today will be further advanced as a consequence of this legislation. Some of the legislation which we are debating tonight is totally unnecessary; some makes the situation worse; and some will see the situation of some of our commercial television stations actually deteriorate rather than get better. The legislation that we debate tonight will see the situation of our commercial radio broadcasters and, indeed, our public radio broadcasters deteriorate. As the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) reminded me a few moments ago, the situation we are debating tonight will be made worse because the legislation questions the very validity of the Constitution upon which this Parliament and this nation is built. The advice the members of the Opposition have had-which has been made available to the Government-seriously questions the constitutional validity of the legislation that is before the House tonight.

The honourable member for Macarthur has said to us that if this legislation is not passed, television stations like Channel 9 will go off the air. That is just extremist. It is exaggerating the situation and using an argumentative point for the purpose of trying to win the argument. It is not using that point for the purposes of trying to establish the truth of the situation. There is no question whatsoever, if this legislation is not successful in this House tonight, about the future of Channel 9. It will continue to broadcast on regional stations, such as WIN 4, that broadcast into my electorate. It will continue to do the job it has done in the past.

The honourable member for Macarthur has touched on a number of important issues in his contribution tonight. He talked of such things as jobs in regional television. He talked about such things as local content in regional television. Those are issues which concern me greatly because the quality of regional television touches the homes and hearts of my constituents. Over the last 12 or so months under aggregation, the quality and local content of regional television in the electorate of Gilmore have been seriously reduced.

The Minister would argue that, as a consequence of aggregation, viewers have more choice. Perhaps they have more choice but the argument that we would put forward and that many of my constituents would put forward is that local content in regional television as a consequence of aggregation has reduced considerably. Why has it reduced? The answer is very simple. As the honourable member for Macarthur pointed out, many of these regional television stations have had to outlay amounts of between $15m and $20m in order to comply with the conditions of aggregation. That extra capital outlay, coupled with the additional running costs and additional interest costs, has forced regional television into a situation where it is no longer making money in aggregated areas.

Whilst the honourable member for Macarthur spoke a great deal about WIN 4-it had its annual general meeting only last week-from reports that I have received it is losing money hand over fist. Indeed, the three commercial television stations in the first aggregated market area are all losing money hand over fist. When commercial television stations are losing money, there is really only one area of flexibility in their expenditure, and that is local content: local news, local current affairs, local sporting coverage and so forth. So under aggregation we have experienced a significant reduction in local content produced by regional television. As the financial situation of regional television in these aggregated market areas continues to decline, we can only expect to see further declines in local content and in the quality of the product that is being sold over commercial television.

There are some other very serious issues which relate to my electorate which are affected by this legislation tonight. I happen to have a public broadcaster in my electorate situated in Goulburn which could only be described as having been at the front line of public broadcasting over the last couple of years. I speak specifically of FM 103, Goulburn community radio station. This community radio station has been taken up by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. It has been charged with having breached the guidelines and having exceeded the normal terms and conditions of what would be perceived to be a proper sponsorship announcement for public broadcasters. Of course, FM 103 is very concerned about that. It has found that, despite all the resources and the alleged skills of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, it has not been able to come up with a clearly defined specific definition of what a proper sponsorship announcement on a public broadcaster ought to be.

Because of that, FM 103 has received conflicting advice, be it from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, from the Federal Court itself or, indeed, from various so-called legal experts. As a consequence, FM 103, which is so typical of many public broadcasters throughout Australia, has spent in excess of $15,000 representing itself at the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal hearings, money which has been spent to no avail. The situation that prevails at FM 103 prevails for the majority of broadcasters right around Australia.

So it can easily be said that the chaos this Government has created through its own legislative processes has helped to put at risk the very viability and future of public broadcasting throughout Australia. Because of that, the public broadcasters of Australia have now, I believe, put at risk the commercial viability of commercial radio station broadcasters in this country.

If one looks at the status of commercial broadcasters in this country one will find that about 50 per cent of them at present are losing money. If one scratched the surface of any commercial radio station in Australia, one would probably find that most of them are up for sale or are prepared to be sold at a reasonable level. Why? It is because of the legislative processes and the management that this Government is engaged in, because of the way it has managed our radio system in Australia, be it public or commercial. That situation of chaos prevails throughout this portfolio which relates to transport and communications. When one asks why this portfolio is in such chaos, one starts to realise that what this Government set up after the 1987 election in the form of super ministries is totally unmanageable. The portfolio that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), who sits opposite me tonight, has to deal with is humanly unmanageable.

The roles that this Minister has to perform are beyond most people's capabilities. This Minister has to deal with the chaos which besets our commercial television industry, with the problems of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, with the problems that beset our public broadcasters and our commercial radio broadcasters and with the out of control situation that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has got itself into. He also has to deal with other matters which relate to the waterfront, which he has been unable to deal with satisfactorily, coastal shipping, matters that relate to our roads, the pilots dispute and such matters as additional runways at Sydney Airport.

Each and every one of those issues should take up the full time effort and resources of one Minister, but they have to be spread far and wide as one Minister deals with all of those issues. So it is under this regime that we find commercial broadcasting and television services, our public broadcasters and our Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in a state of chaos. The state of chaos is, I am afraid, the product of this Government. It will not go away until we have a change of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As chairman of the Opposition's transport and communications committee, I wish to add a few words to reinforce what has been said by the speakers on this side of the House. We are concerned at the haste with which this legislation has been brought in. We are aware of the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We are aware that there need to be vital amendments to the Broadcasting Act to update it to meet the requirements of both television and radio throughout Australia. The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) has outlined the situation so far as aggregation is concerned. Following the aggregation news, a number of the smaller television stations have been sold. That will certainly make a difference. We are already seeing this in many of the rural parts of Australia, particularly the rural areas of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: We are very concerned at the powers that the legislation gives to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal because they are very wide in scope. It will be interesting to see the way the Tribunal deals with them. There are some principles that we stand by. One of the principles-and I am sure that the three major political parties and industry should stand by it-is the need for a fundamental overhaul of broadcasting legislation on a considered, not a piecemeal, basis. Secondly, there is a need to reduce the present plethora of extensive and inefficient regulation. Those two issues spell out the matters that we are concerned about. At this time, before Christmas, we do not want to see the Government bringing in the legislation hurriedly if it is not consistent with those basic objectives as far as this Parliament and the public are concerned. An article in the Australian newspaper this morning states:
Labor backbenchers yesterday moved to create a broadcast group to keep the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, under close Caucus scrutiny as he changes the Broadcasting Act.

I doubt whether the Minister really wanted to change the Act at this time. The Minister, whom I respect very much, has had very strong pressure placed upon him to change this Act and so, as we said earlier, he has brought some piecemeal legislation into the Parliament which gives tremendous powers to the Tribunal which will enable it to determine basically the road that it will tread in the future. We know what the High Court decided on the Bond matter. I am pleased to see that changes were made to the Broadcasting Act. I think that the changes were necessary. We would like to see the Government financially supporting public broadcasting more than it is.

I say in conclusion that it is important that, no matter what legislation comes before this Parliament, special attention is given to the ownership of television and the quality of broadcasting generally throughout Australia to make it fair. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) referred earlier to the protection of children in regard to films and entertainment. We have to think of the consumer. It is the consumer who is important. We must maintain high morals in this country. When honourable members go home at night at 10 o'clock or 11 o'clock and switch on the television for the news broadcast, they might see something that is inappropriate not only for children but also for adults. It worries me that Australia is putting some of this out. I want Australian content, but it should be like the English content-humorous, acceptable and for the benefit of the country. I strongly support the amendment that has been moved by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I am sorry to see the legislation coming before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Communication is a vital element of our society. The freedom to speak to one another, the ability to communicate between people and to communicate between nations I guess is the symbol of the breaking of the Berlin Wall. As one who has been responsible for legislation in this sphere, however, I can say to the Government that I do not see that the Broadcasting Amendment Bill in any way enhances the facility to communicate. Indeed, to my mind one of the tragedies that the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) has bestowed upon the Australian community is the thesis which he pursued and which was the product of the 1987 amendments to this legislation, which saw the structural change in the ownership and control provisions previously existing under the legislation that determined the basis by which the ownership of the various media could be held and the extent to which the breach of that ownership was permitted.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the financial crisis that is now besetting the major network proprietors is not peculiarly a product of those changes. There is no doubt that the trans-media prevention that has been introduced has contributed to the fact that the individual media today are in fewer hands. It has meant that not only are there enormous difficulties for the major networks, but also there are significant problems for those in rural communities.

Aggregation is turning out to be a very costly experiment. There are enormous problems in maintaining the quality and quantity of Australian input and Australian programs. No amount of legislative restraint will ensure that this will change. Frankly, this legislation will achieve nought. I think the legislation is a disastrous mistake. It has been introduced in haste and without adequate examination of what is needed in the community. It is the Bond amendment, if you wish. The Bond amendment is not going to address the problems of what I see as the inadequate consideration given by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to the affairs of one individual licence holder. In fact, I have a great respect for the contribution that Alan Bond as an entrepreneur has made to Australia. I thought it was quite impudent for the likes of those members of the Tribunal to reach the conclusion that they did. For the Government now to respond by introducing inadequate legislation is just as impudent. What it is seeking to do is fundamentally change the law on an ad hoc basis without considering the proper and correct way by which what is an extraordinarily complex area can be resolved.

There are two things I want to say about the Tribunal in the little time available to me. There are a lot of other things I would like to have said about this legislation. First, there has now been a plethora of inquiries into the Tribunal. I know that the inquiries conducted by the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure of this House have addressed some of these problems, but the character of the Tribunal is not going to be changed while there is this proliferation of administrative law; while, as I understand it, there is to be restraint on appeals from decisions of the Tribunal; and while in legislation like this the powers of the Broadcasting Tribunal are going to be enhanced. It is essential that there should be a recognition that the Tribunal should not be a legal body. It would be far better, if one is going to have a body like this, to reappoint people who used to be on it, such as Ken Archer, who had come from the industry. Of course, one would have people who had been in public broadcasting-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) in particular-on the Tribunal, but I would suggest that somebody is needed who is aware of the commercial realities of the marketplace. Certainly, so far as the chairman is concerned, I am afraid that she in no way matches the high standard that David Jones, the former chairman, set during the term that he was there.

Indeed, the more legalistic administrative law becomes the more the views of Mike Hutchinson of the Department of Transport and Communications are vindicated. There is no basis for the interventionary processes which are inhibiting the four principles to which the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) refers regarding ownership and control in his second reading speech. A way has to be found by which one can ensure then that the minimal criteria that must be set for the administration of television are met without unduly intervening in the ordinary commercial process. I would suggest to the Minister that really it would be far better if he withdrew this legislation, understanding full well the quandary of the fit and proper person definition, understanding the difficulties that there are; but I would suggest that in the financial predicament in which the major network proprietors now find themselves this legislation now could properly be set aside and considered, as he says, in one of these other two tranches of amendments that he is going to introduce next year. He talks about an amendment in the autumn session and another amendment in the Budget session, albeit that that is conditional on the change of government that I have little doubt will take place whenever the next Federal election might be held.

I submit to this House that if this legislation were to be examined, somebody like David Jones, who has been on the Tribunal, somebody like Ken Archer, who has been on the Tribunal, and perhaps Mr Oswin should be appointed. Why not appoint Professor Leonie Kramer, who has also been a Chairman of the ABC? If there was a group like that who looked at the legislation dispassionately, not on an ad hoc basis, the traumas of aggregation might be overcome and both a better quality of media presentation and better competition might be provided.

Frankly, we are not getting better programs; we are getting worse programs. We are not getting better Australian content; we are getting less Australian content. We are not getting proper adjudication of the airwaves, but what I see as an increasingly finicky legalistic adjudication on the affairs of a very important part of the protection of the freedom of speech in this country. The Tribunal is being inadequately administered. It is far too legalistic in its structure. It is time that it was totally reversed, and I would suggest to the Minister that the proper course would be that when this legislation gets to the Senate it be set aside and not passed before the end of this year.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Mr Simmons:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 is an omnibus Bill which proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901, with minor amendments being made to the Customs Administration Act 1985, the Customs Amendment Act 1981, the Customs and Excise Amendment Act 1982 and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1985. I hope that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who is due to speak next in this debate, will give some attention to what I am saying. If he does not give any attention to what I am saying, I will speak for the full 30 minutes and give him no time at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1) notes that the Bill proposes to amend the Commercial Tariff Concession System to enable the Comptroller-General to make Concession Orders only in respect of broad classes of goods, rather than particular goods, thus potentially providing excessive and hence damaging protection to local manufacturers at the expense of other enterprise and commerce generally; and

(2) is of the view that the introduction of a new statutory concessional entry scheme for imports in advance of the planned review by the Industry Commission is an inappropriate way for the Government to proceed in an area of such economic and commercial sensitivity''.

In regard to the termination of manufacture in bond, manufacture in bond was introduced to assist local manufacturers by allowing them access to imported goods without paying import duty where manufacturing takes place in Customs licensed warehouses. A couple of features of this scheme are that payment of duty on imported goods used in the production of goods for home consumption can be deferred until the products are sold and, with regard to goods produced for export, no duty is payable on the imported components. No duty is payable on imported material wasted in the production process. The Industries Assistance Commission in its 1987 report found that little manufacture was undertaken under this arrangement. The Industries Assistance Commission stated:
It is evident, however, from the small number of manufacturers using the scheme and the restricted range of goods produced that the original objectives of the system have not been pursued.
With regard to the possible abolition of the system, the Industries Assistance Commission commented:

The abolition of manufacture in bond would mean that current users of the system would be required to operate under the same conditions as all other manufacturers. This would not only remove a major inequity but should also improve the pattern of resource allocation between activities which are currently permitted to use manufacture in bond and those which produce close consumption and production substitutes-such as other electronics and computer equipment.

Following the Industries Assistance Commission report, the Government's 1988 economic statement recommended the abolition of the scheme. The Opposition does not oppose this change. Changes which are being proposed to the bottling of bulk spirits in licensed premises, which involve amendments to section 9 of the Customs Act 1901 and to section 37 of the Excise Act 1901, will now be reviewed. Currently, bulk potable spirits can be entered for home consumption. This amendment proposes that all potable spirits be bottled or packaged into non-bulk containers, and this Bill defines a bulk container as `a container that has the capacity to have packaged in it more than 2 litres of spirit'.

Both the Public Accounts Committee and the Industries Assistance Commission have examined the current practice and have expressed their concerns that the possibility exists that illicit spirit can be mixed with spirit on which duty has been paid. Recommendation number 10 of the Public Accounts Committee states:

The Committee agrees with the view of the Distilled Spirits Industry Council and recommends that spirits bottling only be permitted on licensed premises which are subject to control of the Department. This would eliminate one category of operator, and should reduce the risk of illegal extension of duty-paid spirit with duty free spirit.

Following its usual practice, one that in the course of the last six years has been followed faithfully on many occasions, of legislation not through this Parliament but by press release, these changes were announced by the Government in a press release back in December 1988. However, the Opposition has no difficulty with this amendment, nor does it intend opposing the clauses of this Bill that seek to repeal unproclaimed sections of related Acts. The matters involved deal with the reporting of ships, the treatment of ships' stores, the use of bulk depots for containers and the imposition of penalties on officers who engage in collusive seizures or other corruption. Some of these have been on the books since 1981 and the point should be raised about why these have been allowed to sit unproclaimed for some years. I regret that the Minister will not have an opportunity to do so tonight, but he should explain to the House at some stage why, for instance, legislation dealing with corrupt officers was not proclaimed.

Finally, the Opposition turns to those clauses that deal with changes to the commercial tariff concession system. This system was the successor of the old commercial by-law system, which was the subject of an Industries Assistance Commission report in 1982. Briefly, this system has allowed goods to enter duty free where goods serving similar function are not produced, or are not capable of being produced, in Australia in the normal course of business. The requirements to be met to gain a concession are spelt out in section XVa of the Customs Act and, in general, apply to particular goods. This Bill proposes to delete the particular goods sections of the Act and replace them with guidelines promulgated by the Minister. In general, these guidelines will relate to class of goods.

A brief examination of the tariff concession orders currently in force shows that about 90 per cent of the concessions are for particular goods. For example, under item 8501 in the electrical motors classification, all the 110 concessions are for particular goods. Similar circumstances exist in the case of concessions for pumps, valves, bearings, and so on. Under the approach adopted in this Bill, for instance, if a motor is included in a class which is manufactured in Australia, it would lose its concession, even though the particular motor is not made in Australia and no manufacturer intends producing this particular motor in Australia.

The Government is arguing that a broader definition will allow it to grant more concessions. In practice, however, it will most likely mean that it will be harder to obtain a concession because the field will be widened from `particular goods' to `class of goods'. If this occurs there will be an increase in industry protection. Under the existing system, a number of applicants have had to take the extreme measure of making an application under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 for orders of review with respect to decisions taken by Customs under the Act. Customs had been refusing concessions for `particular goods' on the basis that they were included in a `class of goods' manufactured in Australia. One such case that is extensively used by the Government as the rationale behind these changes is the case of Corinthian Industries, which was heard in the Federal Court and concerned imported door skins. In this case the ruling of Customs was overturned. The issues of function, identical goods, particular goods and cross-elasticity of demand were all canvassed during this case.

In its 1982 report the Industries Assistance Commission recommended that, whether the by-law was revised or replaced, the system should reflect commercial reality. In introducing the legislation the Minister commented on the need for practicalities. The urts have twice said that the simple test of goods serving similar functions is whether they are identical goods or whether they are interchangeable on a market test. Further, the Customs Act provides that when eligibility for concession is being assessed reference should be made to the marketplace. The changes proposed in this Bill would destroy this concept and in its place users of the system would have to revert to the use of a series of guidelines. This is not good enough. Applicants and industry in general must have review mechanisms available to them, the basis of which is an argument of law and not an argument based on guidelines which will quite naturally allow for personal interpretation. In referring to the legislative provisions in the judgment in the Corinthian case, it was stated by Justice Davies:
Sections 269b and 269c of the Act are not ambiguous. They should be applied having regard to the words used, not according to some background philosophy.

With what is being offered in this legislation, background philosophy would be the relevant criterion and dissatisfied applicants would not be able to fall back on unambiguous legislation. What is being proposed here is the removal of a number of definitional clauses. These clauses meant that Customs was obliged to adopt an objective assessment criterion.

Finally, both the Law Reform Commission and the Industry Commission are examining or are going to examine this whole system. In that context we seek an assurance from the Minister-whether he is able to give it himself or whether he can tell the honourable member for Calwell to give it on his behalf-that whatever the outcome of the reviews by the Law Reform Commission and the Industry Commission the Minister will ensure that the recommendations they make that move more objectively to the proper application of what is intended should be implemented. If the provision amending this section were passed tonight, from 1990 applicants would have to work under a new regime, and then more changes would probably be made after the reports to which I have referred have been considered. This is hardly conducive to creating an atmosphere of stability in the marketplace.

Additionally, these reviews will allow for input and consultation with the industry, which has not occurred prior to the drafting and moving of the changes to the system as proposed in this Bill. What is needed is more precise directions for the benefit of both Customs and users-that is, firm and unambiguous legislative direction and not departmental guidelines. The Opposition believes that these changes should be put on hold until the reports that contain industry input are available.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill seeks to authorise a new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement relating to the provision by the States, with assistance from the Commonwealth, of housing assistance for rental housing and home purchase. The agreement will be for 10 years with a commitment in the current year and a three-year forward commitment of funds. Commonwealth assistance moving to a per capita basis will be in the form of grants rather than a combination of grants and concessional Loan Council borrowings. The States will be required to match half the value of untied Commonwealth grants and the funds will be used mainly for rental stock acquisition or construction. The other half of the States' matching grants will be met through the provision of home purchase assistance loans. The Bill will appropriate just over $1 billion to the States and the Northern Territory for each of the next four years. In addition, $9.8m will be granted for housing assistance for young people and $14.8m for mortgage relief payments, both in the 1989-90 year.

There is little doubt that significant public funds are necessary to provide a housing safety net for those disadvantaged in our society who cannot adequately house themselves. The coalition may disagree with the Government on certain aspects and emphases of this legislation-mainly the emphasis on public housing stock rather than on rental assistance to the private rental market, where help is really needed; the inefficiencies associated with public housing and the culture of dependency which it creates; the unnecessary influence of the Commonwealth in setting States' housing preferences, goals and plans; and the confrontationist approach to the States in the preparation of this agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its:
(1) undue emphasis on public housing stock at the expense of rental assistance to the private rental market;
(2) confrontationist approach to the States in the preparation of this new Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement;

(a) pushing house ownership beyond the reach of many families, and
(b) making it more difficult for those who are now receiving housing assistance to bridge the gap to housing self-sufficiency''.

Housing purchase assistance loans are, in essence, government-provided payments-cash payments or other forms of payment-designed to bridge or lessen the gap between available household income and the income required to obtain appropriate housing. This assistance might normally take the form of rental or home purchase assistance and can be topped up by State governments to overcome regional difficulties in housing affordability. Independent evidence supports the view that a switch from public housing to housing assistance of some form substantially increases the number of households assisted for any given annual housing outlay. For example, one such study in South Australia by Pugh and Catt has measured the number of households accommodated per million dollars of annualised costs. At one end of the scale, 187 households would be assisted by medium density public housing construction. The purchase of existing housing by public authorities would assist about 190 to 250 households. However, some form of housing assistance program would assist 280 households and is clearly, therefore, the favoured option and explains why the Opposition in its second reading amendment condemns the Government for its undue emphasis on public housing stock at the expense of rental assistance to the private rental market.

The capacity of this form of assistance to increase the number of households helped from a given budget compared to public housing can be attributed to a number of factors. These include the fact that public housing places a higher demand on capital resources; inefficiencies in public housing arise from the difficulties that large bureaucracies have in controlling administrative overheads and housing maintenance costs; higher income tenants in public housing have no incentive to vacate in favour of less well-off tenants; and a housing assistance scheme can be integrated with other social security payments, leading to lower administrative costs.

We have referred in our second reading amendment to the confrontationist approach taken by the Commonwealth to the States in the preparation of this new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. We have had representations from some of the States about the way in which the Commonwealth has acted; the way in which this arrogant, out-of-touch and completely disinterested Government has approached the negotiation of this new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. In summary, those concerns include the lack of consultation with the States and Territories in the development stages-the fact that the details of the proposal were communicated to the States and Territories in a piecemeal fashion during the four months following the announcement of a new agreement in May and, as a result, its implications and, in particular, the financial impact, were not immediately apparent. I point out that, although this Bill is before the House tonight, none of the States has signed the agreement and South Australia will not sign it until after the election on Saturday. Mr Deputy Speaker, I think you would know this and we can understand why that is the case and the States are still, in a sense, negotiating with the Commonwealth about this agreement even though the Bill is before us tonight.

There are as yet unresolved issues associated with the home purchase assistance account, the financial implications of the deduction of principal and interest repayments to the Commonwealth from rental capital account and the Commonwealth's attempt through the new agreement to impose on the States and the Northern Territory its particular wishes on the way in which it, the Commonwealth, wants to force the States and the Northern Territory to deal with the funds on housing.
