SPEECH.PARA: The Bill deserves the support of the House because it takes the Commonwealth into a new 10-year housing agreement with the States and the Territories, including, for the first time, the Australian Capital Territory. A couple of the points that were well made by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) in his second reading speech bear repeating. The Bill will represent the most significant reform of public housing since the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA) was first put together in 1945, with the principles that were overhauled and developed by the Hawke Labor Government in 1984 intact-to alleviate housing related poverty. Housing related poverty has never been an issue for the honourable member for Deakin. It has never been an issue for people on the other side of the House.

Now we have the Opposition's tax policy. Mr Elliott talks about taking money off the bludgers. Here is another area for him: public housing funding. The honourable member for Deakin started his contribution by talking about bludgers, relating this very Bill to where the coalition will be going, taking money out of public housing to go back down the road of the million dollar land developers, the bottom of the harbour schemes and all that kind of thing that Opposition members not only supported and turned a blind eye to but that they now want to encourage all over again with their capital gains tax policy. That is the bottom line-take public money off the people who need it. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister have said, it is public theft. That is the basis of the policy. It will not stand up to scrutiny. Under this legislation for the first time over $1 billion will be made available in the annual grants. That level of funding will be retained for each of the three years from 1990 to 1993. That is a $4 billion guarantee. It is unprecedented. It is a commitment that the Hawke Labor Government makes to the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

Let us look at the effects of that commitment in some areas. Let us look at public rental accommodation, an area identified by members of the Government. I notice in the House tonight the chairman of the Government's social justice committee, the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb). He has been very adamant about the fact that there had to be more provision under our social justice strategy for public rental accommodation. Now, the bulk of Commonwealth and State matching grants will be used for the direct provision of public rental dwellings. We are expecting that during this period there will be 52,000 net additions to the public stock and that will provide affordable rental public accommodation for over 650,000 people-an increase of 20 per cent on the effort of the past five years which, in itself, has been dramatic when compared with the efforts of the previous Liberal-National coalition.

Let us look at the question of home ownership. A lot has been said about home ownership. There has been a lot of preaching by those opposite, whose very first action in this field, in government, would be to lift the ceiling on home loans that is at present held in place by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did we say that?

—When did those opposite say that? The honourable member should go and ask Mr McLachlan. He will be running the show when he gets in here, mate, not you. That is his policy. You have consistently pressed that the Government lift this ceiling. You will not come out and honestly say it now. You will ride behind it, but it will be there, do not worry.
—Where is the quote?
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Mayo and the honourable member for Burke to address their remarks through the Chair.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. Over the past five years, particularly in the lower and middle income areas, we have seen over 200,000 people assisted into home purchase agreements under the CSHA program. We have seen dramatic assistance given by the first home owners scheme. I cannot recall the figures exactly, but I think over 300,000 home owners have been assisted. I know that in my own electorate in the vicinity of $12m was allocated through the first home owners scheme. Nobody should forget the mess that the first home buyers assistance arrangements were in the day the Hawke Government took office. The arrangements between the various Liberal State governments and their Federal counterparts were in a such a state that I remember the Victorian Liberal leader at the time, Mr Kennett, coming up to Canberra and saying, `For heavens sake, get this mess straightened out. We can never do anything'. Those opposite could not do that. It took the Hawke Labor Government to tie it up and make it work.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a passing reference to the Victorian Government's equity share proposal that is now being developed by the Premier and the Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr Pullen. This is a classic example of using funds wisely and targeting them to people who need help with their first home. The social justice strategy that I mentioned before that is accommodated under this program has special provisions for people needing special kinds of accommodation, be they aged people, young people, or people with disabilities. In my own electorate, in places such as Bacchus Marsh, Kyneton and Woodend, I have had the very great pleasure of seeing programs for special housing come on stream through the initiatives under the CSHA, and especially through joint ventures with local government. Built into the legislation is also a specific provision for programs for young homeless people. I will not spend time on this now, other than to say that, although the Burdekin report was handed down not very long ago, this legislation makes a response which is matched with the dollars that make things happen.

A Liberal pigeonholing government thought the best way to get something off the agenda was to send some committee out, get a report, stick the report in the pigeon- hole and do nothing about it for years-like the bottom of the harbour stuff that sat in the Perth Crown Solicitor's bottom drawer. The Liberals did nothing about it-they are pigeonholers. With the Burdekin report came money and action. That is the name of the game. I remember that in the formulation of the last Budget there was a lot of discussion within the Government about the issue of mortgage relief. I am personally very pleased to see $14.7m appropriated in this legislation to provide special mortgage and rent relief through joint ventures with the States. Again, that is an initiative which also demonstrates responsiveness to the needs out in the community.

Let me refer to some events that occurred today in the House. The Prime Minister, in his speech following Question Time, spoke of the major differences between the philosophies of the Opposition and the Government and made special reference to education. Let me say that there is a major difference, too, regarding a roof over people's heads. The first home owners scheme, the cleaning up of the mess left to us by the Liberals, is a classic case. Our commitment to public housing has never been matched. In fact, the Opposition's commitment to public housing is so substantial that it cannot even find an Opposition shadow spokesman who can hang in the job for any more than a few months; The Opposition has now had four shadow spokesmen, if I remember correctly. Is it such a hot potato to go out there and actually explain that the Opposition has not got a policy and an approach that no-one can even hack the job? There have been four people in the task. The Opposition should see whether it can at least get together some policies and an approach that means something. Public housing was miserably run down. It has received very substantial boosts over the time of this Government.

I am aware of the time, and I just want to finish with one brief point. I commend the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), for his approach. I mention a particular event that took place in my electorate four or five months ago when, along with the Housing Industry Association, we sponsored a housing seminar. We brought people from throughout the industry, from local government and from planning to a special function to discuss some of these issues. Bearing in mind that the Commonwealth was carrying out a review of the agreement, and before the Minister made his mind up on which direction he would go, he was prepared to go down and talk to the builders, the tenants and the people who are at the coal face, with the result that they feel that they have been listened to. They can see the suggestions they were making and the priorities they were putting forward represented in this legislation. I can go back to those people and say, `Here is continuing evidence of the fact that the Minister was prepared to go and listen, talk and take the constructive suggestions back and have them reflected in the legislation'. I am very pleased that that has taken place.

Finally, let me say that another aspect of this debate concerning the housing industry-a very significant feather in the cap of the Hawke Labor Government as compared to the performance of the Opposition when it was in government-is the health and viability of the building industry. Many of my friends are in the industry. They had become conditioned to the boom-bust psychology: the fact that the business might be around for a couple of years, but there was no point taking on an apprentice because there was going to be a downturn and they would have to put them off. So the whole industry was conditioned to the Opposition's boom-bust strategy; the fact that the Opposition let it go and then pulled it off. In 1982, if I recall correctly, we were down to a miserable 95,000 starts for an industry that is placed for 130,000 to 140,000 starts. The industry was in a recession, and unemployment and training suffered in that industry through the Opposition's boom-bust mentality and management approach.

The Hawke Labor Government since then, via a managed growth strategy in the building industry, has shaved the peaks and troughs off. We have seen an industry that has moved forward. We are now seeing people in training and with a future in the building industry. When the point was reached-and all of us understand this, on this side of the House anyway-that interest rates had to be used to slow the economy down, and we have had to slow down particularly the private home market, the first thing that happened was that, via the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, the Government made the shift for an increased priority for public sector housing. That means that the building industry itself remains strong and viable in the place it counts-in the local community, building the things that matter; that is, houses for people who need them.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I apologise if I have gone a bit longer than I should have. It has been my pleasure to enter this debate tonight. I feel that the Hawke Labor Government and Minister Staples have a very proud story to tell in relation to their housing policy and the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. I am fully in support of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the people of the electorate of Burke were listening to the speech made by their representative tonight. I do not think I have ever heard anybody take so long to say so little, and there was so much inaccuracy in the little that the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) did say. For example, he made an utterly dishonest attempt to claim that we on this side of the House would abolish the pre-April 1986 13 1/2 per cent interest rate ceiling. That is the absolute basest hypocrisy that I have ever come across. Not only have we at no point said that we would do that but also it was the Australian Labor Party that abolished the 13 1/2 per cent ceiling for post-April 1986 loans, not us. It is those people over there who did it. They are the people who abolished the ceiling; the Fraser Government did not abolish the ceiling. So that sort of hypocrisy is the basest kind of politics, and I hope the people of Burke heard it.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also mentioned some nonsense about boom and bust. He does not talk to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), I suppose, or the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Of course not; they do not have time to talk to people like the honourable member for Burke. Probably his constituents do not have time, either. Why does he not talk to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister? He does not talk to them because they want to achieve a bust. That is what they are telling us the whole time. Guess why they are putting interest rates up so high. Some people know the answer, and the answer is to dampen down the economy, to head the building industry into a bust. That is the policy. That is what they say at the dispatch box every day, but the honourable member for Burke is comatose during Question Time.

The Housing Assistance Bill is not about the honourable member for Burke who, although he was allocated 10 minutes, took 18 minutes to make his two points; it is about the Labor Government providing $4 billion for a public housing program over four years, including $1.028 billion in 1989-90, and boosting public housing by 52,000 homes over the next five years. I appreciate that members of the Government think there is something pretty good about that. I want to make three basic points in the nine minutes left to me tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not enough.

—It is probably not enough, but I will make those three basic points. First, as the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) pointed out, the housing policy of the Labor Party is really one of the last vestiges of socialism left in Australia. We have seen the Berlin Wall crumble and people giving up on socialism in Eastern Europe, but here we have the old Labor way-public housing, more public housing and still more public housing. No matter that public housing waiting lists get longer and longer under the Labor Government-the solution is to keep building more public housing and reject any alternative. Apparently every alternative is wrong. Rental assistance? A little bit of that, but basically the Government wants public housing. Assistance for people to purchase their homes? A little bit of that but we all know that is for electoral reasons. Basically, no, the big thing Labor wants is public housing; government going out and building housing for people. That is what the Labor Party has always been about. It is the last gasp of socialism-basically, nationalised housing.

SPEECH.PARA: There are perfectly good examples in South Australia of what Labor has been doing. The people can go to the polls in a couple of days and make their judgment about some of these things. Under this legislation the Government will provide this year $82m for public housing in South Australia. Guess what the Government has also done at the same time? It is providing funding for public housing but in the same financial year it has decimated the first home owners scheme. Nationally it has knocked $85m off the first home owners scheme. Those young people who want to go out and buy a home with the highest interest rates in the Western world-the highest rates Australia has ever seen-are having $85m worth of assistance knocked off them so that the Government can put some more money into nationalised housing. That is pretty smart, I suppose.

In South Australia the Government has reduced funding for people to buy their own homes by 32 per cent this year. Is that something that the Government is proud of? Is that something that the Labor Party feels pretty good about? We see all this breast beating about its marvellous housing policy. It knocked 32 per cent off housing assistance programs in one year. How much has it knocked off the first home owners scheme in South Australia since 1983? In real terms it has knocked off 73 per cent. We see little Johnny Bannon, the politically dying Premier of South Australia, running around suddenly in the middle of an election campaign. He has put his hand in his pocket and pulled out $50m. He says, `Guess what this is'-he has been in power for about a decade-`this is money for home purchase programs'. He farms out the money. That is fair enough but at the same time the people here in Canberra are chopping it all off. The Government thinks it is a bad thing. He thinks it is a good thing. The Government wants to nationalise more and more housing. It is just an intellectual nonsense. The Government has been caught out by its own pork-barrelling contradictory ideology and it has ended up with a nonsense. That is the first point I wanted to make.

The second point I want to make is the point that the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) made when he said that all these things are happening at the time of the worst home affordability since records have been kept. If we look at the Housing Industry Association's home affordability statistics we find that since December 1984 in the State of South Australia-it is going to the polls on Saturday; I will be voting and I will be voting Liberal-there has been a 14.2 per cent decline in home affordability. Instead of futile interjections, members of the Government should think about this. Is this a good thing? Is this a record to be proud of? Is it smart to have a 14.2 per cent decline in home affordability? Do members of the Government go back to their electorates and think that that is pretty swell, that they have done a great thing for the people of South Australia? What a miserable record. Monthly repayments over that period for the average home buyer have gone up from $538 to $1,026. I know that the Government is not interested in statistics but that is a 91 per cent increase in monthly repayments. In that period incomes have gone up by 43 per cent. That is less than 91 per cent. That is what the Government has done to the capacity of ordinary people in South Australia to buy their own homes.

What a miserable record. It is the old Labor way of doing things. Every time there is a Labor government it declares war on home ownership. There is more and more nationalised housing with more people going into socialist housing. The Government looks after them but if people want to buy their own home the Government gets the tanks out and drives over their hopes for the future. That is the old Labor way. It always does it. The Whitlam Government did it. The members of this Government are doing it. All the previous Labor governments did it. Chifley was a great fan of public housing, as was Scullin. This is not the time for a history lesson, but Labor governments always do it. This Government changes its rhetoric because it reads opinion polls. We know what its opinion polls say. Behind it all is the same ideological commitment to put everybody into public housing and smash private property rights-that is, capitalism. Labor does not really like that. The world has given up on its sort of ideology. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is not here-presumably he has gone out to the chemist tonight to get a prescription-is one of the real ideologues of the Labor Party. In fact, we always have an ideologue in the housing portfolio.

Finally, in the last couple of minutes left for me to speak, I make one very positive remark about the way in which I think housing assistance could be changed. What the honourable member for Deakin said is absolutely right. One of the things we have to look at is the viability and the effectiveness of housing allowances so that we pay a housing allowance to assist low income earners to make a choice about the sort of housing they wish to go into. Government members say that they all have to go into nationalised housing. I say that we should give them a housing allowance and they can make one of three choices on how to spend that housing assistance from the Commonwealth Government. They may choose to use it to purchase a home. That is anathema to those opposite but something we think is pretty important. We would give them that choice with a housing allowance. Secondly, if they are stuck in the private rental market, where there is the greatest incidence of housing related poverty in Australia, they could get the housing allowance for support in that market. Finally, if they choose to go into socialised housing, public housing, that is their choice; they are entitled to that choice and they could use that housing allowance to pay the local State housing authority. That is pretty equitable.

Those opposite sometimes pretend that they care about equity. That proposal is equitable because it means that whether one purchases a home, goes into rental accommodation or goes into public housing, one gets the same level of assistance. I cannot understand, for the life of me, why those opposite think it is fair to give to people in public housing more assistance than the 80,000 people on low incomes on the public housing waiting lists and having to rent in the private rental market. Why do those opposite give people in public housing more assistance than those in the private rental market? Why is that fair? Of course, that is not fair.
Mr Kerr interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair has put up with persistent interjections from the honourable member for Denison. If he wishes to participate in the debate, he should resume his seat and await the call.

—Presumably the honourable member for Denison has no interest in the issue of equity. It does not matter to him. It is the old Labor way. It does not matter how inequitable something is as long as, behind the facade of reasonableness, those opposite pursue their ideological goals. It is all very funny to the honourable member for Denison that people are suffering in the mortgage belt. It is all a big laugh for him and does not really matter. He believes we are all in Parliament just to have a jolly good time, I suppose, and not to take any of these issues seriously. Those opposite can say what they like about Michael Hodgman; he would bulldoze the likes of the honourable member.
—Order!

—This is very relevant to the debate, Deputy Speaker. He would bulldoze the honourable member. I will not repeat the mistake made by the honourable member for Burke. I know there are others who want to speak in this debate. My time is certainly running out. The Government is heading in the wrong direction with housing and I have been able to demonstrate very successfully how it is heading in the wrong direction. Its boasts about its housing record are empty boasts. Anybody who has been doorknocking or to community functions in Australia knows that the community thinks that the Government's boasts are very empty boasts. Government members would not dare to go to a mortgage action rally in Adelaide or anywhere and make those sorts of empty boasts because people know that they are false. People know only too well that the Government has failed and they will throw it out. One of the main reasons that they will throw the Government out is that its housing policies have been a monstrosity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would think, from all the hype offered by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), that there was an election in South Australia on Saturday! But, when listening to any speaker in this House, one must assess whether that speaker has any credibility. There have been two speakers from the Opposition. The first speaker, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), is a multimillionaire and his relationship with anyone in need of public housing would escape any listener to his speech. The second speaker from the Opposition was the honourable member for Mayo, who would have very little in common with those who either require by choice or need public housing. That is because as a child he boasted a full house--
—A house?
—Yes, he boasted a house-the sort that others try to get into-purely as a plaything; a doll's house. On that gentleman's large property in Adelaide he was able to boast--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Some honourable members have a fascination with the accommodation that I grew up in. I do not know why. I submit that it is not relevant to the Bill.
—We are talking about credibility. If someone can come out with the hype--
—Order! If the honourable member for Streeton will resume his seat the Chair will rule on the point of order and call the honourable member for Streeton.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sorry but I thought that you had given me the call.
—There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Streeton.

—You are quite right, Mr Deputy Speaker: there is no point of order, because the honourable member for Mayo himself boasted that he had a full villa as a doll's house. He said that in one of his first speeches when he became a member of this House. Let us compare that with the honesty of the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) and with my background. In earlier years I was in private rental housing and later, for many years, I was in a Housing Commission house before being able to have access to privately owned housing. I will put that sort of credibility and background against those of honourable gentlemen opposite anytime.

SPEECH.PARA: The Housing Assistance Bill ushers in a new 10-year housing agreement with the States. It puts into place this Government's social justice policy towards housing-that is, to bring together the economic policy and the social policy, providing shelter for people, under one sustainable policy that recognises the principles of access to housing and equity of treatment towards housing. The Bill initiates a four-year program outlaying some $4 billion over a range of programs to house people. It recognises the importance of a public and a private sector in providing houses. The honourable member for Burke clearly enunciated the need for there to be a sustainable housing industry, with all the employment and other attendant economic matters, through a combination of public and private housing. We recognise that many people cannot afford or do not choose to have their own houses, particularly those on low incomes and beneficiaries of government pensions. What we recognise is a basic requirement of all people to have shelter. We do not turn our back on those 30 per cent of people who do not go for privately owned homes. Despite the vicissitudes of our economic situation and with interest rates as they are, we still see a constant level of between 70 and 72 per cent of private home ownership in Australia. We recognise the needs of the other 30 per cent. We do not turn our back on those people. We have policies which will cater for them.

Let us look at the Government's record in the area of public housing delivered largely through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement which is our major housing program. Over the last five years we have expended a record $3,400m. We can compare that with the $1,600m expended by the Fraser Government in its last five years in office-that is, the Government which the honourable member for Mayo extolled so greatly tonight. If one works it out, one finds that it is an increase of some 52 per cent in real terms. At the end of June 1983, 245,000 people were in public housing. We saw that figure increase to 316,000 five years later. The number of people who required public housing and were successfully housed in it increased by 30 per cent.

Five per cent of Australian householders are in public housing-the non-privately owned housing sector. Seventy per cent of people in public housing are on pensions or benefits-that is, over a quarter of all pensioners and beneficiaries who rent are capable of being housed in public housing. One in four families with children who rent are in public housing. That is hardly an insignificant sector for those who require shelter. In the last five years, that was the proud record of the Government.

Let us see what the Bill provides for the next four years. We will continue that basic principle of social justice-accessible, well-targeted housing for those in need. Through that, we will alleviate the housing-related poverty which exists. We will deliver assistance equitably to people resident in different forms of housing, not just standard module housing. There will be a range of housing assistance to accommodate the various needs and tastes of people in the public sector. We believe there should be an even greater focus on those most in need-the low income earners and social security recipients for whom home ownership is not even a dream. We will see that 200,000 low and middle income earners will receive home purchase loans over the next five years. We will boost the affordability of home ownership through the scheme for low and middle income earners.

Honourable members opposite talk about affordability of home ownership and it is quite right to talk about it, but they lauded the benefits of a deregulated economy but did not have the guts to bring in deregulation. They left it to this Government to have the courage to introduce it. The conventional wisdom amongst those in commerce and academia is for a deregulated economy. They recognise that this requires a different attitude and a different level of interest rates to bring about the same effect on demand that occurred previously. It used to be the case that when governments wanted to restrict demand they put a curb on credit. We had a credit restriction situation which mean that we either got a loan or we did not. Even if we had the money to buy a house, if we could not get a loan because of the government's prescription of the day, we had to go without.

We now see a completely different situation. The bankers who used to extend credit are now credit salesmen; in other words, there is as much credit as we like. The place is awash with credit, as long as we can afford it. Unfortunately, the change to deregulation means that, in the transition period between the non-deregulated economy and when it settles down, we will see higher interest rates than normal in order to achieve the same prior restriction on demand. Affordability, however, is not dependent only on interest rates. If we compare the price of a housing and land package with interest rates, we will see that the cost will dictate the size of the loan and therefore the amount required for repayment. People can take a one or two percentage point temporary increase in interest rates, but if there is a huge jump in the price of housing, as we have seen in Sydney and Melbourne, the result will be for lower house affordability.

When we look at the reasons behind the increase in the price of houses, we see that the forces at work are the very things which Opposition members strongly support. They say that they support deregulation, negative gearing and the removal of the capital gains tax on what they term speculation, but what we know is a form of capital growth, so they can avoid taxation. Their position with respect to the capital gains issue is part of their new package. All those sorts of reasons are pushing up the price of the land-home package and putting it out of reach of ordinary people. Therefore, if we are to talk about house affordability, we should take into account the size of the package and the level of interest, although that is a smaller factor.

The last matter to which I refer is whether people can service a loan. Under the Liberal-National Party Government, 10.2 per cent of the work force were unable to service a loan because they were out of work. People without jobs cannot pay their loans. We have reduced unemployment to 6 per cent and we know that everybody who has a job will keep it under this Government and will be able to service a loan. These people also know that the Opposition's only method of countering inflation, the foreign debt problem or balance of payments trade problems is to bring about a recession, which means increased unemployment. If the Opposition ever gets into office we will see people lose their houses by the thousands. They would be unable to meet even the smallest repayments because they would not have the basic income that comes from a job.

There is the choice. It is not a matter of a temporary change of one, two, three or four percentage points in the home mortgage interest rate. It is these other factors which would be exacerbated under a government led by the Opposition parties. I reject the comments made by the honourable member for Mayo and the honourable member for Deakin, and I support the Bill before the House.
Thursday, 23 November 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to support the Housing Assistance Bill, which authorises the Federal Government to enter into a new 10-year housing agreement with the States and Territories. The Housing Assistance Bill 1989 embodies the most significant reform of public housing funding since the introduction of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA) in 1945. What pleases me is that the debate on this Bill, besides giving Government members the opportunity to speak in support of the major social reforms contained in it, exposes the Opposition's philosophy on housing to the scrutiny of the public. It also gives me the opportunity to comment on an example of coalition housing policy in action, that is, the housing policy of the Greiner Government in New South Wales. By the way, that is the only coalition government in Australia at the moment. The New South Wales Minister for Housing, Mr Joe Schipp, has presided over a substantial downgrading of the commitment of his Government to the provision of an equitable public housing system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party in action is destroying public housing, just as tonight it has tried to destroy the concept of public housing. Opposition members speak of it as nationalised housing. I suppose it is part of their view of what they like to call welfare housing, in the same way that they like to talk about welfare child care. They will be talking one day about welfare education. It is something that governments are forced to provide for a class of people who are not equal with the rest of society. That seems to be the Opposition's concept of public housing whereas, of course, public housing is in demand as a right by the people of Australia.

As I said, the Government in New South Wales is presiding over a substantial downgrading of public housing. It has also been attacking private tenants. The private rental housing market is being squeezed harder than ever before in New South Wales and the Greiner Government has made things substantially worse. The failure of the private rental market, with uncontrolled rents, and the subsequent increase in the levels of housing-related poverty are the main reasons why we need a boost in public housing stock, and this Bill will provide that boost through the new CSHA.

But back to New South Wales: in only 20 months the New South Wales Government has sold off public housing and land to private developers, including many sites in the inner city of Sydney earmarked for quality public housing by the previous State Labor Government. The incidence of housing-related poverty is severe in these areas. It is absolutely disgraceful for the Greiner Government to sell this land when it could have been used for housing. The Government has closed nine Department of Housing rental offices, with plans to close a further 20. This has forced pensioners to travel many kilometres from their lodgings to pay the fortnightly rents. A public housing tenant from Woolloomooloo in Sydney was quoted on 12 November in the Sun-Herald as saying that she waited for more than 1 1/2 hours just to pay the rent. She continued:
It cost me $3 to get to the office and took out half my day to pay the rent.
I saw an old man on crutches in the queue and he was shaking. The rent office closure has made his life just that bit harder.

That is the real life outcome of Liberal Party housing policy in action. The people the Liberal Party thinks should be in public housing are in a separate class from anyone else and are without equal rights. The New South Wales Government has substantially increased rents for public housing and the Public Tenants Advisory Services, so popular and so much in demand, have been effectively abolished because they have been defunded.

These and other decisions have represented an unprecedented attack on public housing in New South Wales. Of course, as has been stated clearly again and again tonight, it is on the agenda of the Liberal Party to downgrade public housing to a second rate form of housing. The fact that a very large proportion of the community, that is, low income earners, are unable to purchase their own home means that they are forced to compete in the private rental market-a market which is driven by the need of property owners to generate profits from their property. Of course, there is no need to have a profit motive in public housing.

The New South Wales Liberal Party policy sought to redirect emphasis away from increasing the public housing stock for rental, towards home ownership assistance. As the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) said in his second reading speech, the substantial public housing commitment embodied in this Bill will allow a greater focus on those in greatest housing need-very low income earners and social security recipients, for whom home ownership is not an option. This Bill therefore emphasises the need substantially to increase public housing stock.

The Opposition has discussed housing allowances. The previous Opposition speaker, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), spent some time talking about housing allowances. The Opposition discusses this rather than the issue of the actual provision of housing stock. I say to the previous speaker-he is no longer in the House, but I will make sure he hears about this-that the Government's national housing policy review, which developed the policy framework we are discussing, looked at and compared the cost-benefits of housing allowances as against the provision of public housing. The report, entitled Housing Allowances in the Australian Context, was prepared by Econsult (Aust) Pty Ltd last year. It concluded that, in terms of cost effectiveness in providing poverty relief, public housing emerges as the lowest cost, long-term strategy. By committing resources to the actual building of public housing, as opposed to the Opposition's idea of housing allowances, the result 15 years down the track is very clear.

The report gives a comparison of accommodation yield. It states that, by the year 2008, 79,800 households would be assisted by way of housing allowances, while 123,400 households would be assisted by way of public housing. It states that by the year 2018, the allowances proposed by the Opposition would assist 63,700 households, while public housing, which we are talking about and providing, would assist 186,800 households. So much for the argument that housing allowances are preferable.

The Government would be in a vastly superior position in terms of ongoing generation of low income housing opportunities if we proceed as we intend to proceed. The new CSHA takes this long-term view, just as our retirement incomes policy takes a long-term view rather than attempting a short-term quick fix. If there were any attempt at a short-term quick fix on interest rates, we would have heard about it from the Opposition, but it does not have one. In the major changes that this new CSHA seeks to implement, all funding from the Commonwealth will be in the form of grants rather than a mix of grants and loans. This will reduce the long-term debt servicing and interest payments of the State and at least half of any required matching funds from the States will be grants rather than the more expensive loans, as is the case at present.

The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), talked about confrontation with the States. The Opposition's amendment refers to the Government's confrontationist approach to the States. This CSHA is all about negotiations with the States-negotiations which are resulting in a real partnership on this issue. I cannot understand what the Opposition is talking about when it refers to a confrontationist approach. Would it prefer us to continue to provide the real money but in the form of a blank cheque? This is an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. Of course, it means negotiation and partnership. There is not a confrontationist situation.

This Bill also gives a substantial boost to funding to tied programs for special needs groups like Aboriginals, the aged and youth; and they are certainly groups that could well be forgotten were it not for this agreement. As a result of the new CSHA, around 650,000 people-360,000 adults and 290,000 children-will be offered public rental housing. Around 20,000 home loans for low and moderate income earners will be provided and an estimated 52,000 extra additions to the public rental stock will be achieved. I remember the delight with which this new agreement was received by members of this Government and the pride in achievement that something so worthwhile had been presented to the States, negotiated and agreed to. I not only commend the Bill to the House but congratulate and thank the Minister involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up, I would like to thank all honourable members who have contributed to this debate on the Housing Assistance Bill-in particular, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), who has just finished one of her usual eloquent speeches full of truth and fact. I also thank the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) and the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) for their obviously very strong commitment to housing. As the honourable member for Burke indicated, I had the pleasure to be in his electorate a short while ago to talk to probably well over 100 people involved in housing, building and real estate, including developers and consumers. That was very useful for me, and I hope it was useful for the community. Just the other day I had the opportunity to be a guest in the electorate of the honourable member for Streeton. Again that was a very useful event. I talked to many builders and people involved in finance in his electorate. I congratulate both those honourable members for their attention to their electorates and particularly to the issue of housing.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to congratulate the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) on his speech. It was obviously his first contribution as the latest shadow Minister for housing. I was quite happy with his speech. In fact, I think I will circulate it to as many industry bodies and consumer groups as I can find. I am only disappointed that I cannot have it on video, which would be much more interesting. Certainly I would be able to use his speech very positively to show what a stark contrast there is between the Government's comprehensive strategy and policy in housing and those of the Opposition after all this time. I think the honourable member for Burke mentioned four shadow Ministers. I think that was the only incorrect part of his speech-there have been a lot more than four. Some of them have actually been recycled.

I will not say too much about the contribution of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). He spoke a lot about ideologues and things like that. When he talks about housing allowances and so on, we see the real ideology coming through. As the honourable member for Phillip again quite capably showed in reference to the document that she was using, the concept of the housing allowance-other words were used by the honourable member for Deakin to describe it-has been demonstrated quite fully to be not as good as investing capital in the development of public housing stock as a cost efficient way of providing houses for the community with the taxpayers' dollar.

I think that the reality of that is also quite clear in the fact that there is not a major housing industry group in this country that would support housing allowances, because they know what the real risks are in terms of cost effectiveness to the community and the taxpayer and that they are of very little real value to their industry. I think that one of the greatest successes of the Hawke Government is the fact that it has been able to keep the housing industry going along very strongly, as you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would know, compared with the ups and downs that it faced from very low levels back in what are sometimes referred to as the good old days.

The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement is the result of a major renegotiation of Commonwealth-State programs. Sometimes it has been difficult, but the issues we are dealing with are extremely difficult, both in the structure of the agreement and in what the Commonwealth and the States and Territories want to achieve. We have seen quite a dramatic realignment of the involvement of the Commonwealth in housing policy and a real partnership with the States and the Territories. I want to put on record my appreciation of those officers in my Department, the officers in the State and Territory departments and the various Ministers of all political persuasions who have come together to develop this new agreement. It is a credit to our federal system that despite a lot of quite drastic changes, we have been able to achieve that.

On top of that, $1,000m has been guaranteed-it is more than $1,000m this year-for the next three years. When we consider the insecurities of the past and the vagaries of the Loan Council and the mixtures there, and the fact that we are now talking about 100 per cent grants instead of a mixture of loans and grants, we see the real value of those new 1989 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement dollars compared to the much reduced overall building value of those 1984 agreement dollars. That comes through in the real structure of the agreement. We now have a viable agreement through which we will be building houses instead of debt. We will be building more and more stock because we are not building into the system the debt that was accumulating under the old arrangements.

It has been said by those opposite from time to time and by those who do not understand the new structure of the agreement, which is a vital part of it, that it is anti-home ownership. The reality is that for virtually no more dollars but by using the new financial systems much more efficiently than we ever have before, we are able to move from about 68,000 home loans over the last five years to 200,000 loans under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement in the next five years. That is a tremendous difference. That has been done by using the new financial arrangements and without loading up the system with debt. We have been using different projects that are operated by the State governments under their home loan and home ownership programs for those on low incomes. That is the real chance for home ownership for people who would not otherwise have a chance. Well over 130,000 extra Australian families over the next five years will have access to home ownership in a way they have never had before and they will have the security that goes with it.

The reality of this agreement and the way it fits in with the Government's housing policy is that it covers all areas-home ownership, public housing, the development of public rental stock, and the development of private rental stock. The honourable member for Deakin spoke about the `undue expansion of public rental housing stock at the expense of private rental construction'. We can make a number of excuses for the honourable member. He has not been long in the job, but I would be quite happy for the officers of my Department to take him through a few of the changes that are going on. If he looks at the Budget and at the agreement, including the private rental side of this issue, he will see that the Government is committing $65m over the next five years in rental property trusts. This will mean the expansion of 35,000 units for private rental stock for people on low incomes, or for low rents. That is a tremendous boost to an area of housing stock development in Australia that has suffered greatly over the last few years in a variety of ways. As our community changes and as our cities change, things like strata titling have reduced the level of stock.

One of the important aspects of this Bill that has been totally missed by those opposite is that in the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement we are not just talking about bricks and mortar and all the rest of it. We are starting to talk now about how we can better integrate and plan the development of stock to suit the needs of the community. One of the groups in the community that suffers most, particularly in regard to private rental accommodation where high proportions of income go on rent, is the elderly, particularly the frail elderly. What we have been able to achieve, particularly by going from loans to grants, is an increase in the amount of money that can now go to the pensioner housing program and to housing for the disabled. These are the areas where we can assist those frail, elderly people who spend 60 and 70 per cent of their incomes on rent. They can get into public rental accommodation that is basically design built for them and their needs. That is what gives people quality of life. We can start to work with the State governments to better plan our priorities, whether they be for old people, young singles, people with disabilities or whatever. We will be able to make better use of the stock we have. We can start to develop that stock in a way that suits the real needs of the population, particularly those who are most in need.

There are many other elements of the new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement which in the months and years ahead will become evident in the shape of our cities. Apart from the fact that 650,000 Australians will be offered affordable public rental housing under this new agreement, over the next five years, as I said before, over 200,000 low cost loans will be approved for people to get access to home ownership. We are seeing the whole arrangement centre on the more efficient use of money, using the new financial structures far more imaginatively and putting the emphasis back where it belongs, giving people security and an affordable roof over their heads-something that so many people have not had before.

There is always a temptation for any government to think in three-year cycles, concentrating on short-term targets and quick fix solutions. But often these quick fix solutions have hidden costs that only become apparent after several years. Many of our major cities are surrounded by huge estates opened up rapidly and cheaply with little or no thought given to what people who live there would actually do for a living, how they would get to work, how they would get access to services and so on. I am sure that many people have been housed quickly, but the community is still picking up the tab for many of the problems that arise.

One of the benefits of the new agreement is that the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments will now be able to work together in a cooperative way to develop housing with services. That is what the future is all about. We have to learn to make better use of our housing stock than we have in the past and give people the opportunity to live better lives as a result. I thank again the honourable members who have contributed to the debate. I commend the Bill to the House.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to part (2) of question No. 1651, will he take steps to close the loophole in the Income Tax Assessment Act which enables organisations not eligible for tax deductible donations to receive such funds in a tax deductible form.
(2) What sum of potential revenue has been forgone during the last three financial years through tax deductible donations to the Australian Conservation Foundation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that there are certain organisations which, under the gift provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, are able to pass on funds in the form of grants to other organisations. These organisations are known as ``umbrella organisations'', one of which is the Australian Conservation Foundation. The Commissioner said that, where an umbrella organisation is used in fund-raising activities, his office has consistently applied two conditions:
(i) although the donor may express a preference as to how the donation is to be used, the umbrella organisation must have a completely unfettered discretion as to how it uses the donation; and
(ii) any organisation to which money is passed by the umbrella organisation must have objects which conform with the objects of the umbrella organisation.

Based on the Commissioner's advice I do not consider it necessary at this stage to amend the income tax law. However, as I advised you in answer to your earlier question, the Commissioner is monitoring the matter to ensure that the law is being complied with.

(2) The available income tax statistics do not identify separately deductions for donations to the Australian Conservation Foundation. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is (a) the projected life span of the Jindalee radar system and (b) the estimated cost of its construction and maintenance over that time.
(2) Has any decision been made on the siting of the Jindalee radar system; if not, when is a decision expected.
(3) If a decision has been made, is it intended to site the system near Longreach, Qld.
(4) Has an environmental impact statement been prepared on the possible siting of the system at Longreach; if not, why not.

(5) If the system is to be sited near Longreach, (a) when will construction (i) begin and (ii) be completed, (b) which properties will be affected, (c) what compensation will be paid to the affected property owners and (d) what are the implications of the siting for the ``Macsland'' property belonging to Mr D. A. Scarr.

(6) Has his Department received requests from Mr Scarr and other property owners in the Longreach area for information on the possible siting of the Jindalee radar system there and the potential effect on their properties; if so, has the information been provided or will it be provided in the near future.
(7) If such requests have been received and the information has not been or will not be provided, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Approximately 20 years.
(b) Definitive costs cannot be indicated at this time because tenders are currently being evaluated. However, an estimated capital cost of $600m has been assumed for planning purposes for the system.

(2) The Jindalee Radar System will eventually comprise 3 radars sited in northeastern Queensland, mid-western Western Australia and central Australia. Specific site decisions have not yet been made although a decision on the first radar, in Queensland, should be made late this year.
(3) The Longreach district is one of several areas which have been considered. A decision on siting based on Departmental Studies has not yet been taken.

(4) No. The need for an Environmental Impact Statement will be determined by the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories on the basis of the Defence Department's Notice of Intention (NOI). The NOI will be based on specific sites and cannot therefore be finalised in advance of a siting decision. This procedure is in accordance with the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. Those requirements will be strictly observed.

(5) (a) (i) and (ii). This construction schedule will depend on the approach adopted by the contractor selected for the project. The aim, however, is that a contract be let by mid 1990 and that the system be operational by early/mid 1994.
(b) No decisions have been taken to site the radars on specific properties at Longreach.
(c) Compensation will be determined in accordance with the Lands Acquisition Act 1989.
(d) It is known that Mr D. A. Scarr is not willing to sell ``Macsland'' and this fact will have influence on Departmental recommendations.
(6) Yes; the Department has received requests for information and has provided as much information as possible pending actual site selections.
(7) See (6), above.

(4) Did a licensed aircraft maintenance engineer certified for the type of aircraft inspect VH-LTJ on either 16 or 17 September before it departed for a gear-down flight from Albury to Sydney.
(5) Was a permit to ferry taken out for a gear-down flight on 17 September; if so, were all guidelines in relation to ferrying fully complied with.

(6) In respect of the subsequent flight of VH-LTJ from Albury to Sydney, (a) how many persons were aboard, (b) were there two persons aboard other than the minimum required of a pilot and co-pilot, (c) was an instrument flight plan filed rather than a visual flight plan and (d) were fuel consumption figures and icing factors known to the pilots when the flight plan was filed.
(7) Is the VH-LTJ incident the third serious incident involving Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) aircraft so far in 1989, following those at Mangalore, Vic., and Goolwa, SA.
(8) Is there a major problem with CAA training procedures.
(9) At what time and date was the incident involving VH-LTJ at Albury on 16 September reported to the Independent Bureau of Air Safety Investigation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes; (a) (i) and (ii) it has not been possible to verify whether the pilot complained about the steering mechanism on LTJ. The pilot has since left the CAA to work for an overseas airline.
Importantly, the maintenance record for the aircraft on 9 September through to the time of the mishap at Albury reveals no reported problems with the nosewheel steering.

Had the pilot-in-command of the aircraft at Wagga on 9 September been aware of anything to do with the steering mechanism that might have affected safe operation of the aircraft, he would have had an obligation to report this in writing. There is a well structured system for the reporting and rectification of any airworthiness defects in aircraft. `Informal complaint', which the pilot-in-command is suggested as having made, has no place in this system. This would have been well known to the pilot-in-command who would have been negligent had he failed to report any real or suspected airworthiness defect in the recognised way.
(b) Yes; relating to three minor defects, e.g. blown bulb in a landing light.

(2) The pilot who was undergoing training on the G.1000 has no recollection of any query by air traffic control (ATC) staff at Albury whether the aircraft was operating normally. However, ATC staff at Albury have reported that they queried earlier manoeuvres prior to the aircraft leaving the runway and becoming bogged and received the reply from the crew that they were involved in training.

(3) The aircraft came to rest in a position in which it infringed on the runway. This rendered Albury Airport closed until the aircraft was removed. CAA air traffic control staff at Albury arranged for a local licensed aircraft maintenance engineer (LAME) to move the aircraft. There was urgency to this task as the runway was closed to other aircraft movements until the aircraft was removed. The LAME did not have either the time or appropriate facilities in accordance with the procedures laid down by the manufacturer for hoisting of the aircraft. A crane was therefore employed with slings attached to the engine isolator mounts to lift the aircraft.
(4) Yes. The aircraft was released for flight.

(6) (a) Four, (b) yes, (c) yes, (d) yes. In regard to fuel consumption and icing factors, the aircraft's performance and characteristics were fully known to the pilot-in-command who allowed generous margins in satisfying the en route and reserve fuel requirements.

(7) The only occurrence which may be defined as serious involves the incident at Mangalore, (Vic.) on 17 July. The incident at Goolwa, SA involved the main wheel of the aircraft breaking through the light bitumen seal on soft wet ground during a U-turn whilst taxiing at the end of the runway.
(9) The incident occurred at 1342 hours on 16 September. It was reported by the crew to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation at 1430 hours on the same day.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: For each of the (i) boards, (ii) councils and (iii) committees to which the Minister has the power to appoint members, what (a) proportion of the positions is now held by women and (b) change in that proportion has there been since the ALP Caucus passed the motion in August 1988 requiring that a minimum of 25 per cent of all appointments to Government boards, councils and committees be women.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is shown in the table below. The following information is also of interest:

ANSWER.PARA: As regards members of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the proportion of positions currently held by women is 57%. The change in the proportion of positions held by women since the Caucus motion in August 1988 is +4%.

The Minister has nominated members of two Committees of the Social Welfare Research Centre: the Research Management Committee and the Advisory Committee. However, these members have been appointed by the University of New South Wales.
The Minister nominated two of the four members of the Research Management Committee both of whom are men. The overall proportion of positions held by women is 25%.
The Minister has nominated four of the eleven members of the Advisory Committee one of whom is a woman. The overall proportion of positions currently held by women is 18%.

The Centre will become the Social Policy Research Centre and these Committees will be replaced by a seven member management board. Three members will be appointed by the Minister. These appointments have not yet been finalised.

The Australian Institute of Family Studies comes within the portfolio responsibility of the Minister for Social Security. Members of the Board of Management of the Institute are, however, appointed by the Governor-General. The proportion of positions currently held by women is 57%. The change in the proportion held by women since the Caucus motion is +17%.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs: Office Movements Study

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 30 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Bureau of Statistics undertake an initial study of the Minister's Department's office movements in Queensland in the 1990s; if so, did the study cost $1,364.

(2) If such a study has been undertaken, has it been completed; if so (a) has the report been made publicly available, (b) if it has been made publicly available, (i) when and (ii) to whom was it made available, (c) if it was not made publicly available, why not and (d) if it contained recommendations, have they been implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Bureau of Statistics did undertake an initial study-a feasibility study for a larger study to be undertaken. The study did cost $1,364.

(2) The initial study has been completed. It did not result in any data outcomes. Rather, it was conducted to determine an appropriate methodology for the main study. The larger study aims to project client locations in the 1990s in order to help determine appropriate office locations. The report was not made publicly available as it was regarded as an internal working document. It did not contain recommendations, as such, apart from the proposed method of conducting the larger study, which is now in progress.
